DOC.HEAD: Men Sought in Texas Murder Jump to Death From 12th Floor of Hotel
DOC.TEXT: Two men wanted for questioning in the slaying of a university student jumped to their deaths Friday from the 12th floor of a hotel as police approached, authorities said. Matthew Michael Novatny, 22, and Jason Smith, 19, leaped from the window as officers tried to enter their room at La Mondrian Hotel, said police spokesman Fred Nixon. Novatny was wanted on charges of killing Tiffani Ann Bruce, whose body was found Oct. 21 in the bathroom of her home near the University of Texas in Austin, said Austin police Sgt. Mike Lummus. Ms. Bruce was shot twice in the head and once in the chest, police said. A medical examiner said the 18-year-old was probably killed Oct. 18 or Oct. 19. Novatny and Smith, who were roommates, disappeared after the killing. Acting on a tip from a Texas woman, Los Angeles police officers went to the hotel and asked the manager to escort them to the room. ``As they knocked on the door, they heard moving inside and asked the manager to let them in,'' Los Angeles County sheriff's Sgt. Robert Stoneman said. ``They saw an open window, walked over to it, looked out and saw two people 12 floors down.'' Novatny may have met Ms. Bruce canvassing the neighborhood for Clean Water Action, a grassroots environmental organization, said Terrence Keel, an assistant district attorney in Travis County, Texas. ``It's a very strange case,'' said Keel. ``This may have been someone infatuated with her and went back and killed her.'' In Newark, N.J., on Friday a 25-year-old man on trial for murder leapt to his death from the 11th story of the Essex County courthouse while eight people watched. Jeffrey Lemon, dashed for the window as lawyers interviewed a prospective juror, authorities said. He was charged last year with hurling a 14-year-old boy to his death out a 14th-floor apartment building balcony after arguing with the boy's father.

DOC.HEAD: Panelists Discuss Minorities and the Media
DOC.TEXT: Journalists who cover blacks and other minorities often hold negative preconceptions that are reflected in their studies, a panelist at the Associated Press Managing Editors convention said. ``When reporters come to me, many times they don't come with an objective outlook. They come with preconceived notions,'' Rae Parr-Moore, acting chief of public information and community affairs for the District of Columbia, said Friday. Ms. Parr-Moore, representing Washington Mayor Marion Barry at the 56th annual convention, said most journalists she deals with want to photograph black juvenile delinquents or black drug addicts. ``I don't get calls for chances to interview or photograph the health commissioner,'' Ms. Parr-Moore said. Blacks should be sought for their opinions on a wide range of topics, including foreign policy and health, she said. Poverty and drug abuse are often unfairly presented as being ``black problems,'' she said. Editors also were urged to resist hiring minority reporters only to cover minority affairs. Washington Post reporter Juan Williams said he does not feel obligated to be the voice of the black community simply because he's black. In fact, he said he's often criticized by other blacks who feel he should try to censor negative stories. ``I'm aware that the black community wants stories that generate positive images,'' Williams said. ``But I think silence is a greater sin than anything any newspaper has written.'' Williams said newspapers cannot be afraid to cover stories, such as the federal drug case against Barry, that might upset some blacks. He said the media should demand accountability from black elected officials as well as white politicians. Many people have criticized federal authorities for a sting operation that led to Barry's arrest and conviction on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. Some have also labeled as racist the six-month prison sentence Barry received. Dr. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Barry is another example of a government official who overstepped his authority. But Hooks said he, too, felt black elected officials were often harassed by federal investigators. Blacks compose about 1{ percent of elected officials. Hooks said, however, that black officials are the targets of 17 percent of the investigations of public officials. ``There has been a double standard of justice and we need to examine all of that,'' Hooks said. APME is comprised of managing editors and other news executives of the 1,500 member newspapers of the AP, the world's largest news gathering organization. The four-day convention, which ended Friday, drew 263 editors from across the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Dog Returned By Burglar
DOC.TEXT: An apologetic burglar returned a nearly-blind dog to a family whose home he had burglarized. ``It was out of order and totally out of my profession,'' the burglar said in the note to victims Pam and David Crandall. ``I definitely can't return your property - materials, that is. But I can return Taffy, which is something very loved and treasured in your family.'' The burglar signed the note ``Respectfully, ... Let's just say, `Kind-hearted.' '' The Crandalls' home was burglarized Monday. Also taken were stereo equipment, a VCR, jewelry and frozen food. A newspaper article about the burglary included the Crandalls' telephone number, and early Friday a man called and told them their dog was in a used-car lot. The burglar left the note in a pet carrier that also had been stolen. Mrs. Crandall said Taffy was doing fine - after having her morning coffee.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Puts Lincoln, 17 Other S&Ls Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, whose collapse left taxpayers with a record bailout bill of about $2 billion, is among 18 failed thrifts being put up for sale by the government's Resolution Trust Corp. The RTC, which is responsible for disposing of hundreds of failed S&Ls, said Friday that it is accepting bids from potential buyers for the 18 institutions. They have a total of $31.8 billion in assets and $24.3 billion in deposits, the agency said. Federal regulators recently proposed a plan to sell or close 192 failed S&Ls, with assets valued at $119 billion, over the next six months. But Congress adjourned last weekend without providing more money for the cleanup. That failure to act will cost taxpayers millions or even billions of dollars more to cover insured deposits, officials and analysts say. By the time legislators return in January, the RTC's borrowing authority could be exhausted. Even then, approval of more money is far from certain. The Office of Thrift Supervision has brought a $40.9 million civil action against Charles Keating Jr. and five others connected with American Continental Corp., the former parent of Lincoln S&L. Lincoln, based in Irvine, Calif., has assets of $2.7 billion and deposits of $2.4 billion. Keating has been charged in state court in California with 42 counts of fraud. He is free on bail pending the outcome of that case. Separately, the Senate Ethics Committee is investigating whether five senators improperly intervened with regulators on Keating's behalf. Besides Lincoln, the thrifts put up for sale Friday are: -Pima Federal Savings and Loan Association, Tucson, Ariz. -Security Savings & Loan Association, Scottsdale, Ariz. -Imperial Federal Savings Association, San Diego, Calif. -Commonwealth Federal Savings & Loan Association, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. -Pioneer Federal Savings Bank, Clearwater, Fla. -American Federal Savings Association of Iowa, Des Moines, Iowa. -Statesman Federal Savings Bank, Waterloo, Iowa. -Horizon Federal Savings Bank, Wilmette, Ill. -Mid Kansas Savings and Loan Association, Wichita, Kan. -Security Homestead Federal Savings Association, New Orleans. -First Fderal Savings Bank of Annapolis, Annapolis, Md. -City Savings Bank, Somerset, N.J. -ABQ Federal Savings Bank, Albuquerque, N.M. -Sandia Federal Savings Association, Albuquerque. -Security Federal Savings, Columbia, S.C. -Alamo Federal Savings Association of Texas, San Antonio, Texas. -Commonwealth Federal Savings Association, Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Package Bomb Explodes, Injuring Several
DOC.TEXT: A package bomb exploded early today in the doorway of a police residence, injuring two people, including a 7-year-old girl, Spanish National Radio said. The bomb went off about 2 a.m. in a three-story residence of policemen and their families in this northern Spanish Basque town, the radio said. The radio said there could be more people injured in the rubble of the building. There were no other details available immediately. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the bomb, but the radio said it could be the work of the Basque separatist group ETA. ETA, which stands for homeland and liberty in the Basque language, has claimed responsibility for more than 600 violent deaths since 1968, including 15 this year. The group wants independence for the three-province Basque country.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Warned of Unauthorized Changes in Long-Distance Service
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Consumers may file complaints with: Kathie A. Kneff, Enforcement Division, Common Carrier Bureau, Federal Communications Commission, 2025 M St. N.W., Washington, D.C. 20554. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Communications Commission is warning consumers to beware of clever salespeople who try to switch their long-distance telephone service without permission. ``Unauthorized switching sometimes happens as a result of unfair sales tactics,'' the FCC said in a statement Friday. It noted that some long-distance companies hire sales groups known as telemarketers to sell their services over the phone. ``The telemarketers can provide you with useful information about special promotions and reduced rates. Telemarketers may also misinterpret any agreement on your part to let them send you information about their company to mean that you are ordering their service,'' the FCC said. ``No one has the right to switch you to a company you don't want,'' the commission added. People who do get changed can switch back or to another company. Consumers who agreed to the first switch must pay a small charge. Those who didn't agree don't have to pay. ``However, you must pay for any long-distance calls you made using the unauthorized long-distance service,'' the FCC said. State and federal authorities and local phone companies have received tens thousands of complaints about unauthorized switching, particularly in the wake of recent advertising wars among American Telephone & Telegraph, MCI Communications and US Sprint. An AT&T official told a congressional hearing last month that 90,000 of the company's customers had been switched to another long-distance service against their will in the past six months. Most complaints have been against MCI, but the other companies have been accused as well. AT&T has sued MCI and its telemarketing agent. MCI said honest mistakes can be made. The FCC urged consumers to make sure a telemarketing agent knows they don't want to change service. It also suggested they watch out for letters thanking them for choosing ``XYZ'' phone company - they've already been switched - and to inspect monthly phone bills for any changes in service. Consumers should notify the new long-distance company immediately if they did not order the service and should also tell their local phone companies.

DOC.HEAD: Politicking President Picks Up the Tab at the Big Boy
With PM-Bush Bjt
By RITA BEAMISH
DOC.TEXT: President Bush didn't make any bones about it - sometimes you try to buy votes, even if only for the price of a cup of coffee. Bush stopped by a local coffee shop after a campaign appearance here Friday for Republican House contender J. Kenneth Blackwell. To the astonishment of the patrons at Frisch's Big Boy, the president and Blackwell worked the booths, shaking hands and saying hello. Then they took seats at the counter, Bush pulled some bills from his pocket and ordered coffee all around. ``Trying to buy votes?'' a reporter asked. ``You're darn right, that's what this is all about,'' the president replied with a laugh. It also turned out to be celebrity day at Frisch's. Two burly young men approached the president for autographs, and one began to explain, ``Typically we're asked for autographs, but ....'' Bush looked up to see two of this city's better-known residents - Jim Breech and Lee Johnson of the Cincinnati Bengals football team. One of the guys at the counter, truckdriver Lee Smith, was happy to sit next to candidate Blackwell. ``I'm voting for Blackwell because he voted against gun control,'' Smith said. By the time the president's entourage left, everyone was in a jolly mood. Even White House chief of staff John Sununu, not usually given to frivolity, was gamely snapping a photograph of a woman who wanted her picture with Bush.

Bush's next campaign stop was in Rochester, Minn., at a high school set amid rolling hills and wide expanses of grain fields. The John Marshall High students were pumped up, the gymnasium was rocking and an American flag as big as the side of a barn was stretched behind the stage. It seemed a bit odd to have Mr. Las Vegas in the midst of all of this. But there he was. And Wayne Newton gave a Vegas-style rendition of ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' to welcome Bush. Newton was dressed down for the Rochester crowd, in a dark suit instead of his glitzy stage togs. But he did show a touch of flair - with a black tie that was red at the knot. Nobody seemed to know exactly what else Newton was doing in Rochester, but Bush thanked him as ``a friend of longstanding who flew all the way from Las Vegas here for this, and now back tonight.'' Some of the high schoolers who professed to have knowledge of advance planning for the event said that an invitation to rock star Prince was seriously weighed. They did not know how Newton was chosen instead.

DOC.HEAD: City in Trouble; Two Vying to Come to the Rescue
DOC.TEXT: The city's finances are a shambles and its drug problems seemingly insurmountable. But the District of Columbia is preparing to put the era of Marion Barry behind it by electing a new mayor. The race features political novice Sharon Pratt Dixon, a former vice president and attorney with the Potomac Electric Power Co., and onetime city Police Chief Maurice Turner. Turner, a Republican, is running in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 9-to-1 margin. Dixon holds a commanding lead in the polls and she regards the job of mayor as ``a great opportunity to turn the city around.'' There are ``problems - serious ones - but I've never been one to turn away from an opportunity to make things better,'' she said. Dixon upset four experienced politicians in the Democratic primary. She pledged to root out waste and fraud in district government. That was just the right message for an electorate that spent the summer watching Barry's drug and perjury trial. He was convicted of one count of cocaine possession and sentenced to six months in jail. Turner has sought to improve his slim chance for victory by pounding away at Dixon's relative political inexperience. Stressing his 32-year police career, Turner has accused Dixon of being soft on crime. He's also called her cruel and insensitive for promising to immediately drop 2,000 workers from the city payroll to cut costs. ``You don't correct the ills of a government run by Democrats by coming down on the worker,'' Turner said. ``I have a lot more managerial experience, and I know there are better ways to cut expenses.'' The Republican nominee proposes eliminating 6,000 people from a 48,000-person work force through attrition. Dixon describes Turner as a ``born-again Republican,'' criticizing him for his GOP conversion last year. But as the campaign neared its end, political observers expected Dixon to coast to victory. ``I think the only chance Turner had to win was if he was running against Barry, because then he could have been running against crime and corruption,'' said Ron Richardson, a local labor leader and political activist. ``But Sharon is perceived as a clean government candidate ... and that has really left him with no issues,'' Richardson said. Barry announced before he was convicted of misdemeanor cocaine possession that he would not seek a fourth, four-year term. He is running instead for a City Council seat. He was sentenced Oct. 26 to six months in prison, fined $5,000 and placed on one year's probation. If she wins Barry's job, Dixon's first challenge will be to get the city's fiscal house in order. The district ran a deficit of $100 million for the year that ended Sept. 30, and the deficit could be at least as high this year. Budget officials predict Dixon could have difficulty meeting the city payroll in January or February, which are traditionally low-revenue months. The city also appears well on its way to a new annual murder rate. A total of 382 people had died on city streets through Oct. 29. There were 438 murders in 1989, and police blame more than 60 percent of the killings on drugs, particularly turf battles among crack dealers. And the city is haunted by an infant mortality rate higher than that of many impoverished nations, a public school system that traditionally ranks among the worst in the country and a chronic jail crowding problem. ``We've got to reinvest in this city, every part of it,'' said Dixon, who has pledged to extend economic opportunities to the city's poorest neighborhoods. ``If we can do that, we can begin to see some progress in other areas.''

DOC.HEAD: James, Hughes Involved in Heated, Nasty Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Republican Craig James eked out a congressional victory two years ago by taking advantage of a defense procurement scandal that engulfed his opponent, 10-term incumbent Bill Chappell. Now James is in trouble, faced with a strong challenge from Democrat Reid Hughes in one of Florida's nastiest congressional campaigns. One of Hughes' campaign themes: James' acceptance of money from political action committees, the same issue that James used against Chappell in 1988. ``He's (James) being financed by PAC money which he campaigned against two years ago as unethical,'' Hughes charged. There is ``nothing inappropriate about it,'' replied James. ``It is legal. I never said I wouldn't take PAC money.'' And James has criticized Hughes, a millionaire, for spending so much of his own money for the campaign - $622,100 to date. ``He said he wouldn't'' spend his own money ``and he did,'' said James. ``I wouldn't be surprised if he didn't spend $1 million for the campaign.'' Hughes replied that a great deal of the money in his election effort ``is coming from small people. This is a citizens' campaign versus a special-interest campaign.'' The two have clashed over abortion and their environmental records. James threatened to file a libel suit over one Hughes ad. Both defend their negative campaign ads, saying they merely point out their opponent's record. ``In our case, we had to attack his very negative record,'' said Hughes. ``He is an extremist, not just on his voting record, but for his off-the-wall, nutty statements.'' ``Negative campaigning I don't mind as long as it is truthful,'' James said. ``We felt it especially important to point out he clais to be an environmentalist and he is not. We felt it was necessary to bring out facts not flattering to Mr. Hughes.'' While Hughes is pro-choice on abortion, James opposes abortion, except in cases of rape, incest or to save the life of the mother. James said he's been misrepresented in Hughes ads on his position. Hughes' ads say: ``He (James) said that pregnant women are too confused to make their own decisions whether or not to have an abortion.'' But James said he merely said that pregnancy is a confusing time for women. Hughes is chairman of The Nature Conservancy, which purchases land to prevent it from being developed. He has been attacked by James in ads about leaking gasoline tanks at stations owned by Hughes Oil Co., which Hughes sold three years ago. James' ads say: ``Hughes had to pay a million-dollar settlement after his string of gas stations leaked gasoline into our drinking water.'' ``There is no record, nor reality, of any state, federal, local government or city fining me,'' Hughes said. ``It is a lie what he is saying. It's a scare tactic by a desperate opponent.'' Hughes did pay $1.3 million to the buyers of gas station properties after leaking tanks were discovered. But there is no evidence that the tanks polluted drinking water. Both candidates were not pleased with the budget compromise worked out in Congress and say it hurts middle-income, poor and elderly Floridians. Whatever the outcome of Tuesday's election, the results can't be much closer than when James, a virtually unknown Republican, defeated Chappell by 791 votes out of 250,000 cast. ``I think it will be close, but I hope it's not that close,'' James said. Each candidate says he is leading in a close race.

DOC.HEAD: `Voters Revenge' On TV For Texans
DOC.TEXT: For most Texas voters, it's been the year of living dangerously close to the television set. In the race for governor, Texans have been bombarded with poll results, slipups and million-dollar mudslinging during what some say is the nastiest gubernatorial race in recent memory. Enough already, said public TV station KERA, which turned its airwaves over to viewers this week for a show called ``Voters' Revenge.'' It featured the best of 18 homemade video parodies and skits of the gubernatorial race between Democrat Ann Richards and Republican Clayton Williams. One imitated Williams during a campaign ad. ``Yes folks, I plan to service Texas,'' said the video. It referred to Williams' admission that he was ``serviced by prostitutes'' as a young man. One segment featured a Dallas disc jockey playing a sleazy talk show host and interviewing the two ``candidates from hell.'' A much younger looking ``Sat-Ann Richards, capped in a large curly white wig, told voters she once dated Elvis.
DOC.HEAD: Letter by Rabbi Causes Flap in House Race
DOC.TEXT: An endorsement letter sent to 50,000 Jewish voters was written by a controversial rabbi using a different name, a Republican congressional candidate has acknowledged. Scott Shore faced a jeering political crowd when he confirmed the endorsement was written by former Boca Raton Rabbi Mordechai Winyarz. Winyarz was once censured by the local rabbinical association for inappropriate behavior, but the censure was later withdrawn. The letter was signed by Rabbi Marc Gafni, a name Winyarz said he adopted when he moved to Israel two years ago. It also was addressed to ``my fellow Democrats,'' even though Gafni's last registration was as a Republican. Shore refused demands from the audience at Temple Beth El that he apologize for the letter. The audience of more than 250, including many supporters of the incumbent Democratic U.S. Rep. Harry Johnston, hooted when Shore claimed he wasn't trying to deceive voters about Winyarz's true identity.
DOC.HEAD: Kerrey Hopes Talk of Invading Kuwait is Political Rhetoric
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Kerrey says he hopes that talk of invading Kuwait is nothing more than political rhetoric by President Bush. Bush ``doesn't want to talk about the budget or other domestic issues because they are tough issues and they are not winning political issues at this time,'' Kerrey said Friday. Military action is not needed, said Kerrey, who won the Medal of Honor for his service during the Vietnam war. ``To plunge unilaterally into military action is a terrible and tragic mistake. It should not be done,'' the Nebraska Democrat said. He said it is wrong to view the Middle East crisis as a conflict between Iraq and the United States. ``If the president makes the mistake of getting Americans all fired up because of the treatment of American hostages, it then becomes an issue between (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein and the United States, which almost has to be treated with a military effort,'' Kerrey said. Kerrey made his comments to Hastings radio station KICS in a telephone interview.
DOC.HEAD: Poll: Voters Support Marijuana Ban By Nearly 2-1 Margin
DOC.TEXT: A statewide poll shows voters supporting the ballot measure to recriminalize marijuana by a nearly 2-1 margin. Measure 2 on Tuesday's ballot would make possession of small amounts of pot in private a misdemeanor punishable by up to 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine. State law for 15 years has allowed possession of less than 4 ounces of marijuana in private. The poll, commissioned by the Anchorage Daily News and Anchorage radio station KENI, showed 60 percent of those surveyed favored the measure and 31 percent were opposed. Nine percent were undecided. The survey has an error margin of plus or minus 5 percentage points. The random telephone survey of 530 registered voters who cast ballots in the August primary or in the 1988 general election was conducted Monday through Wednesday by Dittman Research Corp. of Alaska.
DOC.HEAD: New Registration Program Has Some Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The state's new voter registration-by-mail program is highly successful, but television ads promoting it have generated some controversy. A soap opera-style commercial features a couple in bed. ``Tim, wait,'' the woman says in a come-hither voice. ``Before we go any further, I have to ask. Are you ... registered to vote?'' The ad drew objections from Republican state Rep. Michael Liu, who is running for Congress. Lt. Gov. Ben Cayetano, the state's chief elections officer, defended the commercial as a humorous attempt to reach potential voters. Some 453,000 people are registered to vote in the general election, up 2 percent from 443,000 in 1988. Some 436,000 were registered for the primary, up 4 percent from 419,000 in 1988, Cayetano said.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Meets Dienstbier, Havel; Talk Expected On Sudeten Germans
DOC.TEXT: German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher met with his Czechoslovak counterpart Jiri Dienstbier on a new bilateral treaty to replace historic mutual animosity with cooperation. It was widely believed that Friday's talks centered mainly on claims of Sudeten Germans whose property was nationalized after their expulsion from Czechoslovakia at the end of World War II. But both ministers avoided reporters' questions on the issue. Dienstbier told reporters after the meeting that the treaty will expand a 17-year-old agreement that normalized relations between Czechoslovakia and then-West Germany. More than two million Germans were expelled from Czechoslovakia after 1945. Their property was seized by the state in retaliation for Nazi Germany's annexation of the Sudetenland in 1938 and its occupation of the whole country a year later. Genscher also met with the Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel and Premier Marian Calfa.

DOC.HEAD: `Exorcist' Actor Charged in Airline Disturbance
DOC.TEXT: Actor and playwright Jason Miller, nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of a priest in ``The Exorcist,'' faces several charges stemming from a disturbance aboard an airliner. Miller, 51, was arrested two weeks ago at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport along with traveling companion Ronald Dushney, 43, after a USAir flight from South Bend, Ind. Miller was charged with disorderly conduct, possession of a small amount of marijuana, public intoxication and terroristic threats. Allegheny County police said the men punched seats on plane and that officers found a bag of marijuana in Miller's luggage. Miller was released after posting $300 bond and faces a hearing Nov. 20. Miller, of Scranton, won a Pulitzer Prize for the play ``That Championship Season.''

DOC.HEAD: Thai Leader Visits Laos, Mekong Bridge to be Built Soon
DOC.TEXT: Construction on the first bridge across the Mekong River linking Thailand and Laos will start next year, the Thai government says. Commerce between the two countries is currently conducted mostly by boats crossing the river. Laos is among the poorest and most isolated countries in Asia. The new bridge, to be built with the help of Australia, will link the Thai province of Nong Khai and a point near the Laotian capital of Vientiane, the government in Bangkok said Friday. A press release from the prime minister's office said the bridge was one of several issues discussed during a one-day visit to Laos by Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan. Following the communist victory in Laos in 1975, relations between the two countries were generally poor and there were occasionally clashes along the border. Chatichai has pursued a policy of rapprochement in recent years and business ties have increased.

DOC.TEXT: John F. Kennedy Jr. can breathe a little easier. Kennedy, who twice failed the New York bar exam, has passed the Connecticut version, letting him practice law in the state. Kennedy, 29, a graduate of New York University Law School, took the Connecticut test during the summer. The results were announced Friday. He also took the New York bar for a third time this summer. If he failed again, he would lose his job as a prosecutor in Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau's office. Results of that test are to be announced next week. Kennedy, son of the late president, could not be reached for comment Friday at his office. An office spokeswoman said Morgenthau does not allow assistant district attorneys to speak to reporters. --- TRENTON, N.J. (AP) - Actor Tony Randall, accompanied by trilling opera singers and a hooded executioner symbolizing the death of culture in New Jersey, led a demonstration against eliminating funding for an opera school. Randall, best known as Felix Unger in the television series ``The Odd Couple,'' appeared Friday on behalf of Opera Music Theater International, based in Newark Symphony Hall. The school is directed by Jerome Hines, once a star of New York's Metropolitan Opera. It received nearly $4 million from the state in the past three years. Gov. Jim Florio, who took office this year, eliminated $1.6 million in funding. ``Support for the arts is not a government expenditure, strange as that may seem. It's a government investment,'' Randall said at the protest on the Statehouse steps. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - NBC's ``Hunter'' is losing another partner. Darlanne Fluegel, who co-stars as police officer Joanne Molenski in the television series, will bow out after only 13 episodes. Fluegel replaced Stephanie Kramer, who left the series last February after six seasons. Her last show will air in January, said Ennette Nusbaum, a spokeswoman for Stephen J. Cannell Productions, which makes the action series. Fluegel is leaving the show to pursue other roles, Nusbaum said Friday. Her replacement and how she will be written out of the show were not disclosed. The series stars Fred Dryer as detective Rick Hunter. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single name Ferron is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Canadian folksinger and songwriter Ferron says she toiled for years at blue-collar jobs - including one shoveling gravel - before getting the confidence she needed to become a performer. ``I'm just a regular Joe, who has worked, prayed, begged, crawled and celebrated,'' she said. The singer is on tour promoting her third album, ``Phantom Center.'' ---= PHOENIX (AP) - Barry M. Goldwater says having an airport terminal named for him ``is the greatest honor I've ever received.'' The fourth terminal at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, named for the longtime Republican senator from Arizona and 1964 GOP presidential candidate, was dedicated Friday. ``I'll keep on flying out of here until one day they'll have to pick me up in a box,'' Goldwater, 81, said at a dinner Thursday night at the terminal.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia Denounces Amnesty Report On Yemeni Tortures
DOC.TEXT: The government is objecting to findings by Amnesty International that Saudi security forces have tortured and mistreated hundreds of Yemeni guest workers because of the neighboring country's pro-Iraq position. ``We would have wished to see Amnesty International checking out the facts before directing charges to the kingdom of Saudi Arabia,'' said a government statement Friday attributed to a ``responsible government source'' and distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency. London-based Amnesty reported Thursday that Yemenis were being rounded up, expelled and ill-treated ``for no apparent reason other than their nationality or their suspected opposition to the Saudi Arabian government's position in the gulf crisis.'' The human rights group claimed to have interviewed Yemenis who had torture marks, including a man beaten so badly he had to be hospitalized. It called on King Fahd to hold an immediate public inquiry. About 750,000 out of some 2 million Yemeni workers in the kingdom have left since Riyadh announced Sept. 18 it was annulling their residence and work privileges. The decision was in apparent retaliation for Yemeni support of Iraq in the gulf crisis. Saudi Arabia initially offered Yemenis a month to find a Saudi sponsor, but the deadline has been extended, in line with the rules for all other expatriate workers. The Saudi statement said ``hundreds of thousands of Yemenis are pursuing their activities in the kingdom, supported by all Saudi care, after having adjusted their status.'' Those who left after the new ruling, ``have done so of their own free will and have taken with them all that they made of money and possessions,'' it said. The statement said Amnesty had probably contacted ``the more than 70,000 Yemenis who were expelled from Kuwait and Iraq and crossed through the kingdom to Yemen, with nothing for a cover on their bodies and who found all care with the Saudi authorities.'' ``Perhaps it is these that the Yemeni authorities, seeking to harm us, presented to Amnesty International,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Closed Down By Publisher Over Fears Of Moslem Protest
DOC.TEXT: The country's largest publisher has shut down its entertainment magazine, fearing new Moslem protests after the magazine ran a picture depicting prophet Mohammed, a company official said today. Islam prohibits any rendition of the prophet. The magazine ``Senang'' was ordered closed Friday by Kompas Gramedia chief executive Jacob Utama, who called it a blunder to run the picture. The picture depicts a young man meeting the prophet in a dream. A company official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Utama wanted to ``avert the wrath of the Moslem community,'' which makes up about 90 percent of the country's 180 million population. The government banned the company's weekly tabloid Monitor late last month after thousands of Moslems protested publication of a poll comparing Mohammed with other famous figures. Kompas Gramedia, which also controls the country's largest newspaper Kompas, is owned by a group of Catholic publishers.

DOC.HEAD: New Poll Shows Gantt Leading Helms
DOC.TEXT: A new poll showed Democrat Harvey Gantt narrowly leading Republican incumbent Jesse Helms in Tuesday's election for U.S. Senate. Among 703 likely voters surveyed in the Charlotte Observer-WSOC-TV poll released Friday, 47 percent supported Gantt and 41 percent favored Helms. The remainder were undecided. The margin of error was 3.7 percentage points. An Observer-WSOC-TV poll two weeks ago showed Gantt up 49 percent to 41 percent. The new survey was conducted from Sunday through Thursday by The Charlotte Observer's market research division. The survey is the latest of sometimes conflicting surveys. For example, a Mason-Dixon Poll released Thursday showed Gantt leading 48 percent to Helms' 44 percent. But a survey released Thursday by The News and Observer of Raleigh showed Helms ahead 44 percent to Gantt's 40 percent. Both candidates said Friday they aren't paying attention to the polls. Also Friday, a national leader of a Ku Klux Klan group, asked to explain his organization's ``endorsement'' of Gantt, made it clear it was intended as a slam against the black candidate. ``If they elect him, they'll find out we've got another crooked black politician,'' Imperial Wizard J.W. Farrands said in a telephone interview. Farrands heads the Invisible Empire of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, one of many klan groups. A state leader of the group had sent a letter to news organizations announcing its ``endorsement'' f Gantt on Wednesday. Gantt's campaign would not comment on Farrand's statements. Gantt, the first black mayor of Charlotte, has accused Helms of trying to make race an issue in the campaign through television advertisements that discuss hiring quotas for minorities. Helms has defended the spots as raising legitimate issues about hiring quotas and Gantt's background.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Guarantees for Israel Reported Set
DOC.TEXT: An American team plans to leave for Israel soon to finalize transfer of $400 million in guarantees to finance housing for a tide of Soviet Jews flowing into the country, officials say. The decision to send the team, disclosed Friday by Israeli Ambassador Zalman Shoval after a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker, ends a dispute that contributed to strained relations between the two countries. Americans have been calling on Israel to refrain from using the U.S. guarantees to build houses in the predominantly Arab, eastern part of Jerusalem, which was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast War. Shoval said Israel would not use U.S. guarantees to build homes in the eastern part of Jerusalem but would use its own money to build wherever it wanted. ``There are no two cities of Jerusalem, just as there are no two cities of Berlin,'' he said. Israel's Arab neighbors are incensed at the growing number of Jewish homes being built in what they regard as occupied territory. The Bush administration has questioned several times recently Israel's right to the eastern part of the city - an explosive issue that the Reagan administration had refrained from raising. The question arose this year partly as a result of the large influx of Soviet Jews under the newly liberalized emigration policies of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Plans Nuclear Talks With Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: Concern in Congress that Pakistan may be trying to get nuclear weapons has brought a promise from the Bush administration to take up the issue with that country's new government. ``We expect to engage the new Pakistani government early on in discussion of these issues,'' Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly said Friday. He told a House panel military aid to Pakistan has been suspended in compliance with a law requiring such a cutoff unless the administration can certify that the Asian nation does not possess nuclear weapons. The United States had planned $564 million in military aid for Pakistan in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Chairman Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., opened the hearing of the Asia-Pacific subcommittee with a warning that ``neither the administration nor Congress is prepared to turn a blind eye toward mounting evidence that Pakistan persists in its pursuit of nuclear weaponry.'' Unless the new government takes steps to prove that it does not have those arms, ``American law is quite clear, no further U.S. assistance can flow to Pakistan,'' Solarz added.
DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Government Erred on Nuclear Licensing
DOC.TEXT: A federal court says the federal regulators went too far in trying to streamline licensing of future atomic power plants. In its decision, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia handed a victory to anti-nuclear groups that said the plan would muzzle public opinion on licensing of plants. The three-judge panel was critical of a Nuclear Regulatory Commission plan to allow operators to get both a construction and operating permit in a single proceeding violated the law. The court said the ``one step'' plan would violate federal law. The NRC issued its new licensing regulations last year as part of an attempt to simplify the licensing process and reduce uncertainties and delays. The action immediately was challenged in court by the Nuclear Information and Resource Service and the Union of Concerned Scientists. ``It's disappointing,'' said NRC spokesman Joe Fouchard. ``We've attempted to craft a rule which provides for early decision making.'' The court did uphold some parts of the plan. But it said the commission must hold a second round of hearings, after construction is complete, before an operating permit can be issued.

DOC.HEAD: Havel's Civic Forum Shaken by Political Divisions
DOC.TEXT: Only 10 months after the Velvet Revolution ousted the Communists and swept Civic Forum to power, the movement founded by President Vaclav Havel is in crisis over the speed of reform. Cracks began to appear in the broad political movement earlier this month when Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, a radical free-market reformer, was elected Civic Forum chairman over Martin Palous. Palous was backed by the organization's Prague leadership and by Havel, who favors slower, gentler reform that will be less of a shock to the population. Klaus' victory Oct. 13 was seen as a dramatic shift to the right and it triggered an identity crisis in Civic Forum, founded on a civic rights platform and popularly associated with Havel's liberal, humanistic philosophy. On Thursday, Obroda, a group of left-wing intellectuals and Marxist reformers, quit Civic Forum to protest the forum executive council's decision to expel another group of non-communist leftists, the Left Alternative. The changes are reminiscent of the splintering of Poland's Solidarity, which was unified in its opposition to communist rule but since gaining power has divided into factions led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and the more conservative Lech Walesa. In a recent interview with the leading Lidove Noviny newspaper, Klaus suggested that Civic Forum's splintering might be inevitable. He said the idea of citizens' groups forming the basis for politics ``is as impracticable to me as the idea of a centrally planned economy.'' Obroda and Left Alternative, headed by former dissident Petr Uhl, issued a joint statement that called the expulsion ``illegitimate, undemocratic ... and an outrage.'' ``It's over, there is no way to go on like this,'' one of the executive council's 15 members said Thursday, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``When people excommunicate their political rivals without hearing the other side ... there is very little to talk about.'' More conservative forum members say the rightward shift is a natural political development as Czechoslovakia starts grappling with social and economic woes left by communism. ``After we have finally defeated the communists in free elections the question was no longer what we were against, but what we were for,'' said said Daniel Kroupa, a parliamentary deputy and leader of the forum's right-wing faction. Klaus wants radical reform in the inefficient economy, which most people say will bring higher prices and unemployment to the country's 15.5 million people. Havel favors a more careful course. Popular support for Civic Forum during the popular revolution of last November-December, and its subsequent triumph in June elections, swept many of the group's veteran dissidents into high political office. Leaders such as Havel, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Czech Premier Petr Pithart were too busy with state affairs for the most part to concern themselves with Civic Forum debates, and it drifted to the right. Klaus, although always considered a committed anti-communist, was never seen as a dissident. Conservative forum deputies have founded the Interparliamentary Club of the Democratic Right, grouping 42 of the movement's 116 deputies in the 300-seat bicameral parliament. Thirty-six mostly left-wing forum deputies formed the Interparliamentary Civic Society. In a race to lead the Civic Forum delegation in parliament, Kroupa won 57 votes, edging out leftist Petr Kucera with 46. Since neither secured the 59 votes needed to clinch the leadership, a compromise candidate is being sought. Civic Forum's smaller counterpart in the Slovak republic, Public Against Violence, has been under attack in recent months, but has had no major internal conflicts.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Contends Global Warming May Be Linked to Flatulent Cattle
DOC.TEXT: Inside the Interior Department, they refer to it as ``the cow pie case.'' And frankly, they think it stinks. But if the agency loses a case that a federal judge has ordered to trial, it soon may have to determine whether flatulent sheep, cattle and buffalo are contributing to global warming. The Washington-based Foundation on Economic Trends filed a lawsuit last year accusing the federal Agriculture, Interior and Energy departments of failing to measure how much flatulent livestock are contributing to global warming by pumping methane gas into the atmosphere. ``It is basically known as the cow pie case,'' said the Interior Department's top lawyer, Tom Sansonetti. Sansonetti is taking the fragrant fracas seriously, especially after losing an early round in court. He has assigned a lawyer to the case full-time. ``We filed a motion to dismiss ... and we lost. It's going to go to full trial on this issue,'' he told the Wyoming Stock Growers Association and Wyoming Wool Growers Association on Friday. ``I couldn't believe it.'' The foundation alleges that flatulent livestock could be producing up to 15 percent of atmospheric methane, believed by some scientists to be a contributing factor to global warming. Scientists believe global warming, also known as the greenhouse effect, occurs when the layer of carbon dioxide and other gases accumulating above the Earth prevents the atmosphere from cooling. Scientists say it can lead to potentially catastrophic climate changes that can cause polar ice melting, a rise in the world's oceans and drought conditions. If the foundation's lawsuit is successful, Sansonetti said the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management would have to determine how much methane is generated by livestock grazing on public lands. His office has until Nov. 15 to file an answer to the lawsuit arguing why such a study shouldn't be conducted. If a study is undertaken and it finds that the animals are indeed releasing too much methane, Sansonetti said farmers might be asked to ``produce less windy cattle.'' One way to do that, he said in an interview, would be to change the animals' feed. Another alternative would be to reduce the number of animals allowed to graze on public land.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Wins Mayoral Elections; Opposition Claims Fraud
DOC.TEXT: The governing party has won 36 of 38 races in northern Coahuila state mayoral elections, which opposition parties have challenged with claims of widespread fraud. The elections, which were held Sunday, touched off several protests this week. Governing party supporters temporarily blocked the international bridge between Ciudad Acuna and Del Rio, Texas, on Wednesday night. In the official results announced Friday, the Coahuila state's election commission said governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, had won in all cities except the state capital, Saltillo, and Ciudad Acuna. Only 25 percent of eligible voters cast ballots, it said. The conservative National Action Party was declared the winner in Saltillo. The leftist Cardenista Front of National Reconstruction was named the victor in Ciudad Acuna. The PRI previously held all 38 mayoralties. The elections were the first since the PRI announced political reform last month. Sunday's voting was considered a preview of elections later this month in Mexico state and 1991 mid-term congressional elections. Several opposition groups have challenged Sunday's election results in 14 municipalities because of what they claim was large-scale fraud. The PRI also claimed opposition fraud, challenging the results in the two cities where it lost. The state electoral tribunal has 15 days to decide whether the protests are valid. If it finds they are, the state congress decides whether to call new polls. Opposition parties claim that many registered voters were not allowed to cast ballots because their names had been erased from the voter rolls. They say some PRI members were listed more than once at different voting booths, allowing the party to conduct a ``carousel'' in which sympathizers voted in several polling places. They also claim the PRI bought votes in many cities with money or goods. The PRI made similar charges against the opposition. It has filed challenges to results in Saltillo and Ciudad Acuna, according to election officials. In a protest this week over the elections, members of the Democratic Revolutionary Party marched in Torreon and destroyed two cars. In another demonstration, about 100 members of the Authentic Party of the Mexican Revolution briefly occupied the municipal palace in Ramos Arizpe. The PRI has remained in power since itsfoundation in 1929 in part by suppressing or buying off the opposition, stuffing ballot boxes, and rigging election results. However, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has been pushing political reform as well as economic modernization. He took office in 1988 after winning little more than 50 percent of the vote, the smallest percentage in the party's history.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Faces Murder Trial in Liposuction Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bills cq, 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A doctor whose wife died as he performed liposuction on her in his office must stand trial on a murder charge, a judge ruled. Joe Bills Reynolds' wife, Sharon, 43, died during a four-hour operation Sept. 7, 1989. The liposuction left her with a two-foot-long wound and drained most of the blood from her body, medical witnesses testified during a preliminary hearing. The witnesses criticized Reynolds, 54, for performing the procedure outside a hospital and for allegedly using untrained office workers to deliver anesthesia and assist in the surgery. After seven days of testimony, Oklahoma County Judge Clinton Dennis on Friday ordered the case to trial. Reynolds has pleaded innocent. His lawyers allege he is being persecuted because he is unpopular with some doctors. ``People die every day in surgical procedures and they're never prosecuted. I think that fact speaks for itself,'' defense lawyer Garvin Isaacs has said. Reynolds, whose license has been suspended, has pleaded innocent to the murder charge. He remains free on a $25,000 bond.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov and Kasparov Draw in Game 10
DOC.TEXT: Champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov remained tied in the world chess championship after a draw in the 10th game. Kasparov offered the draw after his 18th move Friday and Karpov agreed, bringing the match score to 5-5. The game lasted three hours and 12 minutes, by far the shortest game in the match. ``Personally I think both players were happy with a little break after the last three games, which were really disastrous in that both players made blunders,'' said international master Alex Fishbein. Kasparov and Karpov each have a victory and have played eight draws. A victory is worth a point, a draw a half-point. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. The first 12 games are being played in New York, and the remainder will be in Lyons, France. The 11th game is scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Council Backs Two Controversial Grants
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts advisory council is recommending grants for two controversial stage performers who figured in the dispute over anti-obscenity rules Congress sought to impose on the agency. ``I will make my decision as quickly as possible,'' NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer said Friday after the vote to provide grants to two avant-garde New York theaters for performances by Karen Finley and Holly Hughes. The council's recommendation is advisory. The final decision rests with Frohnmayer. Grant applications submitted previously by Miss Finley and Miss Hughes as well as fellow performers John Fleck and Tim Miller of Los Angeles were rejected by Frohnmayer. He said their work would not ``enhance public understanding and appreciation of the arts.'' The four performers sued Frohnmayer and the endowment in federal court in Los Angeles. They charged their free-speech rights had been violated because funds were denied on political rather than artistic grounds. Frohnmayer was under pressure from conservative lawmakers to halt federal support for what they consider obscene and blasphemous artistic projects. Some critics have cited the NEA's previous grants to Miss Finley and Miss Hughes as evidence of a willingness to support objectionable works. Performance artists stage monologues and musical acts that frequently deal with feminism, racism, political issues and homosexual concerns, sometimes in sexually explicit terms. The new grant applications are for performances by Miss Finley at the Kitchen Theater and Miss Hughes at the Downtown Art Company, both of New York. They had been unanimously approved by an NEA ``peer panel'' of outside artists and arts managers. The council deferred action last August on five grant requests, including those from Finley and Hughes, citing a possible conflict of interest involving artistic collaborators who served on the peer panel. Later, a fresh panel was formed. It also approved the five grants. The amounts were not disclosed, but Kitchen Theater executive director Barbara Tsumagari said her request totaled $25,000. ``It's definitely not over until John Frohnmayer makes the final decision,'' Miss Finley said after the council vote. Before adjourning last weekend, Congress approved a $174 million NEA budget that scrapped an explicit obscenity ban, effective Oct. 1. The measure must be signed by President Bush before it becomes law. The ban was imposed a year ago at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and his allies who expressed outrage at endowment support for exhibitions of controversial works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. Last weekend, Congress voted to repeal the ban and instead to penalize NEA grant recipients whose works are later ruled obscene by the courts. The measure provides only that obscenity ``shall not be funded'' and that grant decisions must take into account ``general standards of decency'' and respect for the public beliefs and values. Council member Nina Brock, a former member of the Tennessee Arts Commission and a Chattanooga arts patron, abstained on the council's voice vote Friday. She earlier had questioned whether Miss Hughes' work met endowment standards for artistic excellence.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are Friday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Diplomats in Baghdad said four American hostages will probably be freed this weekend. --- President Bush will visit Egypt and Saudi Arabia during the Thanksgiving holidays and will meet with troops stationed in the Persian Gulf. Bush will consult with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the emir of Kuwait, living in exile in Saudi Arabia. --- The Iraqi Foreign Ministry on Friday called Western governments ``inhumane'' for urging hostage families to ignore Baghdad's invitation to visit Iraq for holiday reunions. --- Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left today for Baghdad to seek release of captives from his country, and three Irish parliamentarians traveled to Iraq on Friday to try to win the release of that nation's people. The Iraqi government has allowed reporters to visit some captives being used as so-called human shields at key military and industrial sites. --- Secretary of State James A. Baker III was to depart today for a trip that includes meetings with leaders of Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the ousted Kuwaiti government, Egypt, Turkey, Britain and France. --- A French Defense Ministry spokesman said disciplinary action was being taken against the three soldiers for their ``act of carelessness,'' after they were captured in Iraqi territory. A ministry communique said the soldiers were captured on a patrol Monday near the Saudi Arabia-Iraq border. The three were turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad later in the week. --- The government of Saudi Arabia is objecting to findings by Amnesty International that Saudi security forces tortured or mistreated hundreds of Yemeni guest workers because of the neighboring country's alleged pro-Iraqi position. The human rights group claimed to have interviewed Yemenis who had torture marks, including a man beaten so badly he had to be hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Requiem for a Bridge: Galloping Gertie's Collapse 50 Years Ago Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Fifty years ago, they ran away from ``Galloping Gertie'' when the Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapsed in the worst bridge failure in history. On Sunday, they'll mark the anniversary by running toward - and on - the suspension span's successor. On Nov. 7, 1940, the mile-long bridge linking Tacoma and the Kitsap Peninsula fell into Puget Sound. The 4-month-old bridge, which got its nickname from its instability in high winds, had twisted and buckled for an hour in a gale. Then its 2,800-foot center span crashed into the water 190 feet below. The only fatality was a cocker spaniel too frightened to leave the bridge. Tacoma wouldn't get a replacement span for another 10 years. But it was worth the wait, state officials say - the new one hasn't developed any serious problems. ``It's really in excellent shape,'' said Bob George, state bridge management engineer. The successor bridge will be the site of a 10-kilometer footrace, a three-mile walk and an antique car parade Sunday as Tacoma commemorates Galloping Gertie's collapse. The first Narrows Bridge was the third-largest suspension span in the world when it opened July 1, 1940. Almost immediately, it gained a reputation for swaying in the winds that channel through the passage that forms the entrance to southern Puget Sound. The bridge was designed by Leon Moiseiff, who also designed the Golden Gate and San Francisco Bay bridges. But George said the Narrows bridge ``was quite a departure from previous suspension bridge designs.'' For one thing, he said, it was narrow: just 33 feet and two lanes wide. It also had solid sides and a solid deck, which George said gave it the aerodynamic characteristics of kite. The bridge roadbed would move in a wave-like motion. Old films show cars disappearing in a wave trough and reappearing moments later as the trough turns into a crest. On the day the bridge fell, the late Leonard Coatsworth, a Tacoma News Tribune reporter, was driving across it with his daughter's dog, Tubby. In an article published later that day, he described how the swaying became so severe that he had to abandon his car. The frightened dog refused to follow as Coatsworth walked and crawled to the buckling bridge's east tower. Eyewitnesses described broken support cables cracking like whips and concrete bursting from the roadbed like popcorn. The last person off the bridge was Howard Clifford, then a photographer for the News Tribune who had been sent out with reporter Bert Brintnal to cover the catastrophe. In an article published Thursday by the newspaper's successor, The Morning News Tribune, Clifford told how he and Brintnal heard sounds ``like rifle shots'' as support cables snapped. They were standing on the bridge's eastern section when the center collapsed. ``Suddenly the center section of the bridge gave a mighty heave and peeled back as it fell into the waters below,'' Clifford wrote. ``Fearing that the east section might also fall, Bert and I turned and ran for the toll plaza.'' The $6 million failure was replaced by an $18 million, four-lane span that opened in October 1950. It was radically different: The roadbed rested on trusses that had been tested in wind tunnels. The bridge deck, 60-feet wide between the trusses, had gratings between the lanes to let air flow through. At each of the two towers and at the center of the span are hydraulic shock absorbers to dampen any movement. ``There's no way you're going to let a second one go down,'' George said. ``If anything, when this bridge was designed, I'm sure it was ultra, ultra conservative.'' Scuba divers, meanwhile, are trying to get Galloping Gertie's remains declared a federal and state historical landmark to protect it from salvagers who are taking pieces of it for scrap metal. ``Jacques Cousteau has even made dives at the Tacoma Narrows Bridge. It's probably the finest dive in the Northwest in terms of variety of sea life and clarity of water,'' diver Bob Mester said. Jake Thomas, the state's historical officer, said the sunken bridge is worthy of consideration and wouldn't be the first underwater site protected. To qualify, the structure must be of historical or archaeological significance - and at least 50 years old.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Walks Out of Parliament's Opening Session
With PM-Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her party walked out of the new Parliament today after her jailed husband was not allowed to attend the swearing-in ceremony. The right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance, which routed Ms. Bhutto in last month's election, took the oath without them to form Pakistan's fifth civilian government. Dozens of police wielding batons surrounded the National Assembly building and forced Bhutto supporters across a tree-lined boulevard. Ms. Bhutto initially rejected demands to boycott the opening session of the National Assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament. But she walked out after her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, did not show up for the ceremony. Interior Minister Zahid Safraz said adequate security arrangements could not be made to bring Zardari from jail in the southern port city of Karachi to the Pakistani capital. Zardari won a legislative seat representing the sprawling Karachi slum of Lyari in the Oct. 24 elections. He has been in jail since Oct. 10 on extortion charges. Earlier this week, a judge ordered that Zardari be allowed to take his parliamentary oath. Safraz said the availability of security personnel in Karachi was limited because of weeklong demonstrations against the desecration of a Moslem mosque by Hindu fundamentalists in neighboring India. The demonstrations have been peaceful and sparsely attended. Parliament Speaker Malik Miraj Khalid ordered the minister to bring Zardari to Islamabad for Sunday's legislative session. Zardari, 38, has been blamed for many of Ms. Bhutto's troubles since her government was ousted Aug. 6 on corruption charges. He regularly came under fire during her 20 months in power for allegedly demanding commissions on lucrative government contracts. Ms. Bhutto and Zardari have steadfastly denied any wrongdoing. Her populist Pakistan People's Party suffered a stunning defeat in last month's national elections, which brought the right-wing alliance to power. She has accused her opponents of massive vote fraud. The claims have not been substantiated. It appears that Nawaz Sharif, 41, will be the next prime minister. He was the alliance's unanimous choice for the post, which will be decided by secret ballot in the Assembly next week. Sharif's alliance swept the national elections, winning 105 seats in the 217-seat Assembly. He also claims the loyalty of another 40 seats controlled by independents and smaller parties. Ms. Bhutto's People's Party and three allied groups won only 45 seats.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Acquitted On Charge of Illegally Using Men's Restroom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Valorie is cq, 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A jury quickly acquitted a woman of illegally using a public men's room after she testified she couldn't wait in a long line for the ladies' room. Jurors deliberated only 23 minutes Friday before acquitting Denise Wells of illegally using the men's room during a July 7 concert at the Summit by country-western star George Strait. ``I'm relieved. I'm elated. The jurors told me, `You had us all the way,''' Ms. Wells, 33, said after the verdict. She laughed and hugged her lawyer, Valorie Wells Davenport, who is also her sister, as the verdict was read. Ms. Wells was ticketed and ordered to leave the concert, for which she had paid $125 for a ticket, after a security guard saw her leave a stall in the men's room. She faced a $200 fine if convicted of a city ordinance that bars members of one sex from using a public restroom designed for members of the opposite sex in a manner calculated to cause a disturbance. ``There was no proof or evidence that she entered in a manner calculated to cause a disturbance,'' jury forewoman Frieda Felton said. During a two-day trial, the defense also raised allegations that public places do not provide adequate restroom facilities for women, who generally take longer to go to the bathroom than men. Ms. Wells testified Friday that she used the men's room in desperation because the ladies'-room line was too long. ``I felt I was in a situation where I had to be in a restroom,'' Ms. Wells testified. ``I took the only option I felt was available.'' She said she covered her eyes and apologized to the men already in the restroom when she entered. In a videotaped deposition played in court, one of the men testified that it was clear Ms. Wells wasn't trying to create a distubance and that he sympathized with her. Air Force Lt. David Keller said that just before Ms. Wells entered, he told another man in the restroom, ``If I were a woman, I'd just go in here. Nobody should have to stand in that line.''

DOC.HEAD: Global Accord Reached to Clean Up World's Oceans
DOC.TEXT: In a major bid to clean up the world's oceans, delegates from the United States and 42 other nations have agreed to bar dumping industrial waste at sea within five years. Environmental groups praised the actions taken by delegates at the five-day meeting of the London Dumping Convention, which ended Friday. ``It is not an exaggeration to say that this is an historic step in cleaning up the sea,'' said Remi Parmentier of the environmental group Greenpeace. On Thursday, the delegates adopted by consensus a resolution that calls for phasing out industrial waste dumping at sea by 1995. It is legally binding on all 64 nations that have signed the 20-year-old London Dumping Convention. They include the United States, Britain, Germany, France, the Soviet Union, Japan and most other industrialized nations. The United States, which in 1988 passed a law halting ocean dumping of industrial waste, had originally opposed the international ban, saying more study was needed. ``But they realized there was such strong sentiment against dumping that it was pointless to obstruct it and they just gave up,'' Parmentier said. The resolution was sponsored by Denmark, Iceland, Finland, Norway, Sweden, Spain and Brazil. Under the measure, a survey will be conducted to identify areas suffering the worst effects of waste dumping. Member countries will be expected to prosecute their own flagships found violating the ban. The resolution calls for dumping to be stopped without increasing pollution in other parts of the environment. The measure urges nations to encourage and promote cleaner industrial processes, recycling, the treatment of waste on land and more research and development on alternative and environmentally sound means of waste disposal. Delegates also recommended creation of a global mechanism for controlling land-based pollution of the sea. About 80 percent of all ocean pollution is generated on land; 10 percent comes from industrial waste disposed of by ships at sea, and the rest is thrown or discharged from vessels in routine operations. Delegates also agreed that the dumping convention should be applied to the burial of radioactive waste under the sea floor. The resolution, though not binding, was a setback for plans for sea-bed disposal of high-level nuclear waste. The United States, Britain, France and Soviet Union - all with active nuclear programs - voted against the resolution but indicated they would voluntarily comply. Japan, Belgium, Switzerland and Greece abstained from voting. ``This vote sends a strong message to the world that the sea disposal of radioactive waste is not acceptable,'' Parmentier said. Disposing of the lethal waste is a major headache for governments and the nuclear industry. Local groups often have blocked construction of land-based nuclear dumps. ``We've all got radioactive waste that has to be disposed of, and it either goes to the sea or to the land,'' said a British delegate, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Wherever you go, someone will be very annoyed. But you can't wish it away.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The most important thing is the inviolability of Moldavia's borders and its territorial integrity.'' - Mikhail Gorbachev, urging restraint after Moldavian troops shot Russians and Ukrainians in ethnic strife that could jeopardize the Soviet president's efforts to hold the nation together. --- ``I will make my decision as quickly as possible.'' - John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, after the NEA's advisory council recommended grants for two stage performers who figured in the dispute over anti-obscenity rules sought by Congress. --- ``It is basically known as the cow pie case.'' - Tom Sansonetti, the Interior Department's top lawyer, referring to a lawsuit which may force the department to determine whether flatulent sheep, cattle and buffalo are contributing to global warming.

DOC.HEAD: Exiled Kuwaiti Official Warns Against Iraqi Use of Letterhead, Documents
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An exiled Kuwaiti official says the government-in-exile has alerted the Arab League and the United Nations that Iraq is using Kuwaiti letterhead and altering documents it seized in the invasion. A document purporting to show that the CIA and Kuwait conspired to damage Iraq's economy is a fake and was stamped with a seal taken by the invading Iraqis, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed, exiled Kuwaiti deputy premier and foreign minister, said Friday. The exiled Kuwaiti Foreign Ministry issued the warning about bogus documents ``despite the naive contents with which the Iraqi regime has been filling them,'' al-Ahmed said in a statement released by the Kuwait News Agency. Iraq has claimed that its agents in occupied-Kuwait seized a secret document that showed the CIA and Kuwaiti intelligence were plotting against Iraq prior to the Aug. 2 invasion. CIA spokesman Peter Earnest said the document and its contents were ``total fabrications and without foundation.''

DOC.HEAD: Ivana Filing for Divorce from Donald
DOC.TEXT: After nine months of gossip about the war between the Trumps, Ivana is filing for divorce from developer Donald. It wasn't clear, however, whether she'll settle for their postnuptial financial agreement, worth $22 million, or keep seeking half of her husband's now-faltering empire. The Trumps announced Friday in statements that she is seeking the divorce. They separated in February amid a flurry of publicity over Donald Trump's relationship with model-actress Marla Maples. Their marital troubles repeatedly made the front pages of the city's tabloid newspapers. In March, Mrs. Trump's lawyers filed a lawsuit challenging the validity of a postnuptial agreement that granted her $10 million cash and the Trumps' $12 million Connecticut estate in the event of divorce. At the time, Michael Kennedy, a lawyer for Mrs. Trump, said the $22 million represented less than 1 percent of then-billionaire Donald's assets. He said Mrs. Trump deserved half of her husband's empire. But Trump since has come under severe pressure from bondholders and other lenders and the worth of the former billionaire now is subject to question. The postnuptial agreement Mrs. Trump signed has become more attractive, the developer's lawyer, Jay Goldberg, suggested. ``In the first lawsuit she claimed the agreement ought to be set aside,'' Goldberg said. ``Once the depositions were taken, she realizes now the frivolousness of her position. Now she seeks a divorce where she can get the benefit of the agreement.'' Goldberg said Mrs. Trump's lawsuit seeking to invalidate the agreement was still pending and he did not know what would happen to it. Kennedy's secretary said Friday he would not speak to reporters. The Trumps married 13 years ago and have three children.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blast At Police Residence Injures Two Youths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix to a writethru that UPDATES with two victims being youths, other details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A package bomb exploded early today in the doorway of a police residence, injuring two youths, one seriously, police said. The 22 pounds of explosives went off shortly after 2 a.m. in a five-story apartment building housing national policemen and their families in this northern Basque city, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. No group claimed responsibility. But police suspected the blast was the work of the Basque separatist organization ETA, the spokesman said. The 18-year-old son of a policemen fell into the doorway area of the residence when his bedroom floor collapsed, and he suffered serious head injuries, the spokesman said. He was taken to a nearby hospital, the spokesman said. He said flying glass injured an 11-year-old girl, but her cuts were slight and were treated by emergency workers on the scene. The blast seriously damaged apartments on the first and second floors and shattered windows of nearby buildings and cars, the spokesman said. ETA seeks independence from Spain for the three-province northern Basque region and has claimed numerous similar attacks. The acronym stands for homeland and liberty in the Basque language. The group has taken responsibility for the killing of more than 600 people since beginning its violent campaign for independence in 1968. So far this year, ETA has claimed 15 killings.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Told Keating Knew Lincoln Savings Stood to Lose $2 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr. sold risky junk bonds for his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association even after he told a federal regulator the thrift stood to lose $2 billion, the regulator told a grand jury. ``If this institution is taken over, you guys will be faced with a $2 billion loss,'' the official, Alex Barabolak, quoted Keating as telling him in October 1988, according to transcripts of grand jury testimony released Friday. Barabolak is an examiner with the federal Office of Thrift Supervision and a former examiner with the federal Home Loan Bank Board. Prosecutors have charged that Keating knew Lincoln couldn't back the uninsured bonds but misled the public into buying the bonds from Lincoln and its parent, American Continental Corp. Keating has insisted he didn't know Lincoln was in trouble until American Continental filed for bankruptcy in April 1989. Lincoln was taken over by regulators the next day. It will cost taxpayers an estimated $2 billion to bail out the thrift. ``We think we will demonstrate that we didn't violate any laws,'' said Keating's attorney, Stephen C. Neal. ``And there's nothing in the transcripts that changes my belief.'' A 42-count indictment accuses Keating and three associates of securities fraud in the junk bond sales. Keating, 66, pleaded innocent and is free on $300,000 bail after spending a month in jail in Los Angeles. His associates also pleaded innocent and posted bail. Keating is charged with ordering employees to steer depositors away from insured certificates of deposit in favor of the uninsured junk bonds. The proceeds were used to fund real estate ventures. All told, 17,458 investors lost more than $250 million, prosecutors said. The indictment listed only 20 victims who lost $1.1 million, as prosecutors said they wanted a concise case. A judge unsealed 45 volumes of grand jury testimony Friday at the request of the news media. The transcripts showed that Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., one of the so-called ``Keating Five'' - five U.S. senators who accepted $1.3 million in political contributions from Keating - avoided testifying before the grand jury. He pleaded a busy schedule. Cranston maintains he was unaware of the severity of Lincoln's problems at the time he spoke to thrift regulators on Keating's behalf. He says he was merely trying to cut red tape for a substantial California employer. The Senate Ethics Committee is investigating whether the five senators improperly intervened with regulators on the Arizona developer's behalf. In other testimony, an 83-year-old widow described how she was lured into plunging her life savings into the bonds. Adaliza Whinfield said she lost $50,000 on bonds purchased at the Lincoln branch in Hemet, Calif., a retirement community in the desert 100 miles east of Los Angeles. Mrs. Whinfield said an investment counselor named Robert Pascual told her the bonds ``were as safe as the United States of America.''
