DOC.HEAD: Africans Set Conditions For Ending Sports Boycott
DOC.TEXT: African Olympic organizers, in their first meeting with South African sports officials, today refused to drop their sports boycott against South Africa despite the white-led Pretoria government's racial reforms. But Africa's main Olympic policy-making body also said at the beginning of the two-day meeting that it looks forward to readmission of South African sportsmen to international events ``in the fairly near future.'' Zimbabwean officials have said the South Africans will be told specifically during the meeting what they must do to end the boycott in time for the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta. ``We shall not give up until South African leaders accept that in sport, all men are equal whatever the color of their skin,'' Jean Claude Ganga of the Congo, president of the Association of National Olympic Committees of Africa, said at the opening session. South Africa has done away with part of its apartheid system of racial separation in the past year. But the boycott imposed by the International Olympic Committee in 1970 will not be lifted until apartheid is dismantled entirely and South Africa merges white and black sports groups into one national Olympic committee, Ganga said. The meeting marked the first time South African sports officials conferred face-to-face with their black African counterparts to discuss what Ganga called South Africa's return ``to that most peaceful of battlegrounds, the sports ground.'' About 40 South African sports organizers attended the meeting to lobby for an end to the international sports boycott imposed by the International Olympic Committee in 1970. The South Africans argue that reforms introduced by President F. W. De Klerk have improved their country's image enough to clear the way for a phased lifting of the boycott. African Olympic officials, however, say the dismantling of apartheid and steps toward a negotiated settlement between the white-dominated government and the voteless black majority must make more progress before the ban can be eased. The South African delegates represent all major sports in that country. They include Danie Craven, longtime president of the South African Rugby Board, heads of the white-dominated National Cricket Union and leaders of the mainly black Olympic Sports Committee. Despite bans in the past, some South African golfers, tennis competitors and other individual players have taken part in international events. There have also been unofficial and widely condemned tours to South Africa, particularly by cricket and rugby teams.

DOC.HEAD: Manhunt Continues In Deaths Of Four Small Children
DOC.TEXT: Authorities with tracking dogs combed woods today searching for a man accused in the stabbing deaths of four children ages 2 to 5. Two other children and the man's sister were wounded. Neighbors said Henry Curtis Jackson Jr., 26, went on the rampage Thursday night because his sister wouldn't give him money for drugs. Deputies and Mississippi Highway Patrol officers used dogs and an airplane and helicopter Friday to search for Jackson in woods. A ground search continued overnight. ``All of us are getting tired, Webster County Sheriff Bill Middleton said late Friday. ``We're just trying to wait him out.'' Jackson crashed through a bedroom door at the Greenwood home of his mother, Martha Jackson, and stabbed to death four of his young nieces and nephews, police said. Two other nieces and his sister, 23-year-old Regina Fay Jackson, were wounded before Jackson fled in a car his mother had loaned him, authorities said. Roadblocks were set up Friday night in Webster County, where the night before Jackson ran a stop sign and wrecked the car about 65 miles east of Greenwood. Leflore County Coroner James Hankins said he found the victims on the floor and ``all had been stabbed in the neck with a sharp instrument.'' Hankins identified the victims as Andrew Jackson, 2, Antonio Jackson, 3, Shumetricia Jackson, 2, and Dominique Jackson, 5. The girls were daughters of Regina Jackson. Authorities said Curtis Jackson was the uncle of all of the children. Neighbors said the stabbings occurred after Jackson's sister refused to give her brother money for drugs. Jackson's mother was at a church service at the time, a Leflore County deputy said. ``He came in there and asked Regina (Jackson) for some money. Regina said she didn't have any money, and he went to slashing,'' said Anthony Mallett, a 16-year-old who lives two doors down from the Jackson home. ``He just clicked and started stabbing,'' said Angelo Jeems, 24, a cousin of the Jackson family who lives across the street from the red-brick house. Middleton said Jackson was wanted on four counts of murder and three counts of attempted murder. Regina Jackson, who had multiple stab wounds, was in stable condition, said Tricia Chick, spokeswoman at Greenwood Leflore Hospital. She said Sarah Denise Jackson, 11, was listed in serious but stable condition with stab wounds. Andrea Alice Jackson, 1, was first treated at the hospital then transferred to the University Medical Center in Jackson, where spokeswoman Barbara Austin said Friday night she was in critical but stable condition after surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Urges Restraint After Moldavian Troops Fight Russians, Ukrainians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with mourning declared in eastern region and separatists' meeting to consider economic boycott of Moldavian capital. Pickup 5th graf `But Deputy...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KHI1 of Nov. 2
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev is urging restraint after Moldavian troops shot Russians and Ukrainians in ethnic strife that could jeopardize the Soviet president's efforts to hold the nation together. Officials in Moldavia said at least three people were killed and nine wounded in one clash Friday east of Kishinev, capital of the southwestern Soviet republic. Moldavian authorities declared states of emergency in three cities in the east, where separatists have declared their own republic. Separatists declared a state of mourning and flags there were flying half-mast, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. The separatist authorities also met to consider an economic boycott of Kishinev, such as cutting off electricity supplies and railway traffic, Tass said. The violence Friday came after Russian and Ukrainian separatists seized a government building in Dubossary, set up roadblocks and announced elections for an independent parliament, according to legislators in Kishinev. The parliament in Moldavia, a republic of 4.3 million people bordering Romania, announced formation of a new national guard to try to re-establish order in the area east of the Dniester River. But Deputy Mayor Alexander Parajan of Dubossary said the Dniester separatists ``demand the introduction of Soviet Interior Ministry troops, instead of Kishinev militia or volunteer units,'' Tass reported. Pyotr Shornikov, a member of the Moldavian parliament, said states of emergency were declared in the cities of Dubossary, Tiraspol and Bendery. President Gorbachev met with the Moldavian president in Moscow Friday during a conference of 15 republic leaders, and called for restraint. ``The most important thing is the inviolability of Moldavia's borders and its territorial integrity,'' Gorbachev said in an interview on the nightly newscast ``Vremya.'' ``We should struggle against separatists of all kinds.'' Gorbachev, trying to carry out political and economic reform, is beset by restive republics demanding greater autonomy or even independence. All but one of the 15 republics have declared some form of sovereignty. Moldavia declared sovereignty last June and is trying to separate from the Soviet Union. But it faces its own crisis produced by two internal separatist movements. The Gagauz, another minority composed of Turkish Christians, declared sovereignty last week in southern Moldavia and the legislature declared a state of emergency in the Gagauz area. Both separatist groups complain that Moldavians discriminate against minorities. The unrest began more than a year ago after the Moldavian parliament declared Moldavian the republic's national language. Non-Moldavians feared discrimination and loss of their own culture as Moldavian nationalism grew. Yuri Roshka, a Moldavian People's Front leader who supports Moldavian independence, alleged the separatist movements were being directed by the Kremlin to try to discredit and stop the republic's independence drive. He declared, ``The Soviet empire has always used the tactic `divide and conquer,' and that's what they're trying to do here.'' Dubossary, a town containing more than 20,000 people, lies in a heavily Slavic area northeast of Kishinev along the Dniester River. More than 200,000 Russian and Ukrainian speakers live in the area. The Moldavian Interior Ministry said the fighting took place about 5 p.m. Friday at the west end of a bridge over the river that had been blocked by Russian and Ukrainian volunteers. From 100 to 200 Russian and Ukrainian volunteers erected a road block on the bridge and other roads leading to their self-declared Dniester republic after hearing rumors that Moldavians were headed there to try to stop the independence movement, it reported. The ministry's Lt. Col. Yevgeny V. Zaporozov said 100 to 200 ministry troops fired after separatists hurled stones, sticks and other missiles from behind a barricade on the bridge. Zaporozov said hospital officials in Dubossary told him gunfire killed three people and wounded nine. The news agency Tass reported earlier that six people were killed in fighting between Dubossary and Lunga village, but gave no details. The discrepancy was not immediately clarified. Zaporozov said all the casualties were Russian or Ukrainian volunteers. The approximately 400 Interior Ministry troops sent from Kishinev also recaptured the government building in Dubossary, parliamentary officials said. Russians and Ukrainians from the area had helped defend the Gagauz from Moldavian nationalist volunteer who tried to stop the Gagauz secession last week. The Kremlin sent up to 800 Interior Ministry troops to keep order in the Gagauz areas.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Meets With Both Sides in Newspaper Strike
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with both sides at the Daily News in an effort to resolve a bitter newspaper strike, while management fought to get the paper to readers. Daily News publisher James Hoge said the paper has resorted to giving away 200,000 copies a day because the strike has disrupted its distribution system. Daily News delivery trucks are being dispatched to various areas of New York each day to offer free ``samplings'' of the paper, today's New York Times quoted Hoge as saying. Many newsstand operators throughout the city have refused to sell the newspaper, saying they have been threatened with violence or fear they will be. Replacement delivery drivers and their trucks have been attacked and bundles of papers have disappeared from distribution points since the strike began Oct. 25. Management officials said 1.06 million copies of Thursday's and Friday's newspaper were printed, but it wasn't immediately clear how many were sold. A source at a rival newspaper, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said its tracking of the Daily News' circulation showed that the Daily News may have sold 285,000 to 295,000 papers Friday. Another industry source, also speaking anonymously, said the total could be 400,000 to 500,000. Jackson, an unsuccessful presidential candidate in 1984 and 1988, met with Hoge on Friday before addressing a union rally outside the Daily News' headquarters. The civil rights leader said the meeting produced a ``very meaningful dialogue,'' but he did not elaborate. He told about 3,500 people at the rally that job security and worker dignity are at stake. ``We choose negotiation over confrontation, but dignity and job security above all,'' he said. Daily News spokeswoman Lisa Robinson declined to comment on the possibility of Jackson bringing the two sides together to resolve the strike. Lawyer Theodore Kheel, an adviser to the newspaper's nine striking unions, said labor was interested in having Jackson mediate an issue common to all of the unions - the right of strikers to return to their jobs. The Daily News has replaced some strikers who wouldn't cross picket lines. The News was struck by eight of its ten unions on Oct. 25, and The Newspaper Guild joined the strike the next day. The unions charge unfair labor practices. They have negotiated fruitlessly since January over contracts that expired in March.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Discuss Terms of Conventional Arms Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with treaty signed; Pickup 5th, `Soviet Foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: Officials of six Warsaw Pact countries signed an agreement today dividing up tanks, artillery, aircraft and other conventional weapons. The accord removes the last serious obstacle to the Nov. 19 signing of a conventional arms treaty by the U.S., Canada and all European nations except Albania in Paris on Nov. 19. President Bush had said his presence was contingent on the conventional weapons treaty being ready for signing. The meeting also comes at a time that the future of the Soviet-led bloc is in question, as members strengthen ties with the West. The signing of the agreement was delayed by almost four hours as delegations continued to work out what Hungarian foreign ministry spokesman Janos Herman called ``technical questions.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze did not come to Budapest because of ``internal engagements,'' Herman said. He did not elaborate, but Shevardnadze could have been forced to stay in Moscow because of ethnic violence that erupted in Soviet Moldavia along the Romanian border. The Soviet Union was represented by Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky. The foreign ministers of Bulgaria, Hungary, Poland and Romania were present. Czechoslovakia was represented by Deputy Foreign Minister Robert Harenciar. Warsaw Pact experts agreed last weekend in Prague on how to divide the 20,000 tanks and other conventional weapons they may keep under the agreement between East and West. The NATO alliance will be allowed to keep similar levels of weapons, but will have to destroy many fewer than the Warsaw Pact members. Czechoslovak officials said after last week's meeting that the Soviets will keep 13,150 tanks, 150 fewer than they had proposed to keep. A Hungarian official recently revealed that the ``military aspect'' of the Warsaw Pact would be suspended in December, and the pact would be dissolved as a military alliance next year, continuing only as a political body. Hungary has already served notice that it will leave the military part of the Pact next year even if it is not dissolved by then. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel said recently the pact would be transformed into a body with a ``consultative political function.'' The Warsaw Pact was reduced to six members after East Germany left the alliance prior to German unification last month.

DOC.HEAD: Photographer Eliot Porter Dies, Known for Sierra Club Books
DOC.TEXT: Color photography pioneer Eliot Porter, best known for his large-format books published by the Sierra Club, has died at age 88. Porter died Friday at St. Vincent Hospital of cardiac arrest. He had been hospitalized since Oct. 27 for treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. Porter was born Dec. 6, 1901, in Winnetka, Ill., and had lived in Tesuque, N.M., since the mid-1940s. He earned a medical degree from Harvard and conducted bacterial research there before turning his interest in photography into a career. ``I don't think that he saw any difference between art and science,'' said Jim Bones, who was Porter's assistant in the 1970s. ``If you look at history, the great artists were also great scientists, like (Leonardo) da Vinci, for example,'' Bones said. Porter was first recognized for his photographs of birds, and perhaps bestknown for ``Birds of North America - A Personal Selection.'' Two books featuring his work, ``Mexican Celebration'' and ``Nature's Chaos,'' were released last week, said David Scheinbaum, owner of the Scheinbaum & Russek Gallery of Photography in Santa Fe. ``He is, beyond a doubt, the father of color photography as an art form,'' Scheinbaum said. ``There is a whole generation of young photographers who are following in his footsteps.'' Porter, whose work was exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, donated hundreds of prints to the University of New Mexico and the Fine Arts Museum in Santa Fe, said Beaumont Newhall, a photography historian and former UNM professor. Porter took his last photograph in 1986, the same year he was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease. He is survived by his wife Aline and five sons.

DOC.HEAD: Omani Monarch Gives Huge Handout on to Mark His 50th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Many of Oman's 65,000 civil servants cheered, clapped their hands and stamped their feet Saturday as cash handouts were announced to celebrate Sultan Qaboos's 50th birthday and his 20 years on the throne. Government workers would receive bonuses of up to three times their monthly salaries, Civil Service Minister Abdul-Nabi Macki said. Larger payments were announced in the state press for members of the security forces and defense personnel including foreign contract officers and men in addition to Omani nationals. Government economists did not disclose the total amount of the disbursement. Its Central Bank president said Oman's financial position was ``good'' following the rise in oil prices prompted by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The official, Abdul-Wahab al-Khayata, said the handout would not have an inflationary effect on gulf nation's economy. The government announced plans last month to go ahead with its 20th National Day celebrations Nov. 18, despite the crisis in the northern gulf. British-educated Sultan Qaboos overthrew his father Sultan Seed in 1970 in a bloodless coup ending more than a hundred years of isolation and stagnation. Qaboos abolished his father's restrictions on the wearing of sunglasses or owning of transistor radios. Qaboos put down a 10-year communist-inspired rebellion in southern Dhofar province in 1975 and launched an extensive social and economic development program. The nation of 1.5 million lies in the southeastern region of the Arabian Peninsula.

DOC.HEAD: More than 100 Dolphins Forced Ashore by Fishermen in Southern Japan
LaserPhoto TOK12
DOC.TEXT: Fishermen drove hundreds of dolphins toward shore on an island in southern Japan on Saturday, causing the deaths of more than 100, officials said. Fishermen discovered thousands of dolphins swimming Friday night in waters off Miiraku on Fukuejima island, 630 miles southwest of Tokyo, an official of the Miiraku Fisheries Cooperative said. He said dozens of fishermen drove the dolphins toward the sandy beach using ropes in hopes of killing some for food. But more than expected were trapped by the receding tide and were beached, he said. At least 100 died on the beach but another 200 returned to open waters, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Television showed dozens of dolphin bodies on the beach, some thrashing their tails, with dozens more swimming in nearby shallow waters. The official said fishermen and local people had taken most of the dead dolphins home to eat. ``Many people here like to eat dolphin meat,'' he said. Some owners of shops selling fish offered from 15 to 23 cents for each dolphin, he said. The fishery cooperative official said catching and eating dolphins should be ``no problem'' because there is no law prohibiting the practice. He said a much smaller number of dolphins were killed by the villagers last year. Dolphins are used as a source of protein by the local people because fish and meat is expensive in the isolated community, Kyodo News Service reported. Animal protection groups overseas have criticized the Japanese custom as cruel and barbarian. ``We know it is a controversial issue, but for fishermen here, dolphins are enemies because dolphins eat squid and other small fish,'' the official said. In February 1978, when fishermen in Iki, another fishing town in the area, killed about 1,000 dolphins caught off the island, protesters poured into the town.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit-Reduction Bill To Cost Average Taxpayer $321 A Year
DOC.TEXT: The deficit-reduction bill awaiting President Bush's signature will cost the average family of four $321 a year, with additional taxes spread close to evenly among the states, a new analysis shows. The average increase will range from $151 per family in West Virginia to $578 in Connecticut, according to computations by Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-financed research group. The changes will take an average 0.6 percent of family income on a national basis, the report said. The bite on family income will be within one-tenth of a percentage point of the national average in every state except Connecticut (0.8 percent) and West Virginia (0.4 percent). ``Generally, states with the highest incomes will face slightly higher-than-average ... tax hikes as a share of income, while those with the lowest average incomes will pay the least in additional taxes,'' the report said. ``This reflects the fact that, overall, the tax hikes are somewhat progressive,'' meaning they fall most heavily on those most able to pay, the organization said. On a national basis, the median tax increase will be $183, meaning that half the four-member families will see tax increases of less than $183 and half will see increases of more. The highest median increase, $250, will be in Alaska; the lowest, $152, in Pennsylvania. The median increase differs from the average increase, which is calculated by dividing all new taxes by all taxpaying families. The bill, which would cut the deficit by nearly $500 billion over the next five years, includes $137 billion in tax increases. These include higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcoholic beverages, airline tickets, telephone service and expensive cars and other ``luxuries.'' In addition, the plan will raise Medicare payroll taxes on people whose wages exceed $51,300 and income taxes on those with incomes generally above the $100,000-a-year range. Meanwhile, the organization representing state lawmakers said the deficit-reduction plan will cost the states $16.9 billion over the next five years. ``Once again, congressional and administration budget negotiators have taken the easy way out by exporting difficult decisions to the states,'' the National Conference of State Legislatures said in a statement. ``Many states face severe recessionary and no-growth economic conditions,'' said the statement from Lee Daniels, minority leader of the Illinois House of Representatives, and John Martin, speaker of the Maine House of Representatives. ``Knowing this, Washington now decides to invade state revenue bases and at the same time tell states they need to find billions of additional dollars.'' The biggest portion of the $16.9 billion - $10.1 billion - will come from provisions mandating Social Security coverage for all state and local government employees and raising the amount of wages that are subject to the Medicare tax. Employers, including governments, must match employee taxes for Social Security and Medicare. Other costs will include $3.6 billion in lost state revenue because of the higher taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcoholic beverages, and $3.2 billion that the states will have to spend to meet federal regulations for Medicare and Medicaid services.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Poisoned By Pesticides
DOC.TEXT: About 27,000 people are poisoned by pesticides each year in one Chinese province, 10 percent of them fatally, an official report said Saturday. The Legal Daily attributed the high incidence of poisonings in east China's Jiangsu province to the growing use of pesticides over the past decade without adequate safety instructions. No nationwide figures were given. Jiangsu, one of China's 31 provinces and administrative regions, has a population of 64.4 million. About 52 percent of the poisonings resulted from accidents while applying pesticides, the report said. It classed the rest as ``accidents not occurring during production,'' including deliberate drinking of pesticides to commit suicide. It said non-production accidents were increasing steadily and hit a high of 17,000 cases last year, including 1,905 suicides. ``The great majority of those killed by pesticides are young, strong workers and the main supporters of their family,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: California Town Distributes Emergency Radios
DOC.TEXT: Officials fine-tuning Atherton's disaster plans have a new message in the event of an earthquake or other natural disaster: Just touch that dial. The wealthy suburb 20 miles south of San Francisco is giving each household a tiny radio already tuned to a local station that will broadcast emergency information. Static over information distribution during last year's earthquake prompted the program. ``Our main problem during last year's earthquake was dissemination of information to the public,'' said Police Chief Kip Rolle. ``We needed to tell people that everything was OK.'' After the Oct. 17, 1989, quake, power and telephone service was disrupted, and most media attention was focused on larger cities and areas that suffered substantial damage, officials said. But next time disaster strikes, the town's 8,000 residents can use their new radios to listen to KCEA, a non-profit FM station at Menlo Atherton High School. The station, which has emergency generators, will broadcast local emergency information from the town's disaster command post. Officials decided to pre-set the radios so people wouldn't have to remember KCEA's dial setting, 89.1, said Councilwoman Nan Chapman. The City Council allocated $25,000 for the radios, which police are distributing this month. The council hopes to be reimbursed by donations.

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad Hotel Is `Great Hostage Bazaar'
With AM-Gulf-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the 11th floor disco of Baghdad's Mansour Melia Hotel, overlooking the palm-fringed Tigris River, two American and British diplomats sip beer and Cokes as they wait to meet Saddam Hussein's ``guests.'' Under the watchful eyes of Iraqi intelligence agents, a line of foreign men, some emaciated and sick, sit one by one at the tables. Pleasantries are exchanged. The diplomats offer chocolates and hand over letters from some of the men's families. The chocolates are consumed quickly and then the diplomats pass on which names they have submitted to the Iraqi government for release on grounds of age or poor health, which hostages they believe are to be used as Saddam Hussein's human shields. Sometimes the hostages themselves know they've been selected by the Iraqis to be sent to strategic locations throughout Iraq to deter any U.S.-led air attacks on those targets. There is agony in their eyes. But smiles of relief flutter fleetingly on the faces of those who have not been chosen and have a faint chance of being freed. According to information gathered by Western diplomats and other sources, there were nearly 600 Americans, Britons, Japanese or Germans held at various strategic locations. About 300 Frenchmen held as human shields were allowed to leave Iraq last week. The French release was an apparent Iraqi effort to encourage France to pressure Washington and its allies to find a peaceful settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis prompted by the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The luxurious 320-room Mansour Melia in Baghdad's Salhiya district was built by a Spanish company specially to accommodate heads of state slated to attend the 1982 summit of the non-aligned movement. But Iraq was then at war with Iran and the summit was eventually held in New Delhi after Tehran objected to the Baghdad venue. The hotel has now become the ``great hostage bazaar'' for Saddam's government, diplomats say. They also call it the ``hostage palace.'' The logic behind the human shield operation is starkly simple - the hostages die if the multinational force in the gulf launches air strikes on Iraq. ``The place is shockingly depressing'' said American diplomat Stephen Thibeault, who is allowed to visit the Mansour twice a day to see U.S. hostages. ``It's a hostage manufacturing unit. ``The day some of the hostages are released and allowed to go home, the rooms are immediately restocked'' with others among the hundreds of foreigners held in Baghdad, he said. Most of the American hostages held at strategic sites passed through the hotel. When Britain's former prime minister, Edward Heath, left for home Oct.24 with 33 Britons whose freedom he had negotiated, 26 other Britons were brought to the hotel within hours for shipping out to strategic sites. Those at the hotel waiting to be utilized as human shields are not allowed to leave the building or make telephone calls. But they can swim in the hotel pool watched by Iraqi guards. ``They can eat from the hostage buffet that's laid out twice a day,'' said another Western diplomat on condition that neither he nor his nationality were mentioned. ``In simple terms, this place is nothing but a prison with the facilities of a hotel,'' he added. The Mansour Melia was chosen as a hostage center by the Iraqis because it is situated between several important government buildings and security is tight. At night, lights around the hotel are kept on, making it a sitting duck target in any air raid. ``The idea is again simple, you'll kill your own men if you attack,'' the diplomat said. ``Even a greenhorn pilot could pick the hotel as a nice target.'' After the invasion of Kuwait, Iraq banned foreigners from leaving the country, instructing them to report to the police. Iraqis harboring foreigners were warned they could be hanged if they were caught. The government then selected Americans, Britons, Germans, Japanese and Frenchmen as human shields. Hundreds of other foreigners, including an estimated 300 Americans, are in hiding in Kuwait. They are constantly being caught in ones and twos. Saddam has told the hostages that they're being held because ``barring a person from seeing his homeland for a limited period of time is better for him and for humanity as a whole than denying thousands of people life itself'' in Iraqa. Saddam also told his ``guests'' that they will be freed ``when the clouds roll by and the sky becomes clear again.'' But there are no signs that the sky over the gulf is clearing.

DOC.HEAD: Sailor Running Marathon On Ship in Gulf; Father, Wife Race At Home
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While Lt. Guy Zanti's wife and father run a marathon Sunday in Washington, the naval officer intended to match their efforts on a battleship in the Persian Gulf. Zanti became interested in marathon running in April when he watched his 53-year-old father run his first marathon in California. Zanti told his father even if he couldn't make it to Sunday's Marine Corps Marathon, he would still run the 26.2 miles. ``He had been based in the Mediterranean, so he planned on training on land and the ship, and then running the marathon on land,'' said his father, Frank Zanti Sr. ``When this crisis came up, he was deployed to the gulf. But he didn't stop his training and he's going to run on the ship.'' The USS Wisconsin, an Iowa class battleship, is 887 feet long, about one-sixth of a mile. But even at that, the 29-year-old Zanti will have to make about 75 laps. The younger Zanti has already run 24 miles and 22 miles on the ship during training, said his father, a tool-and-die maker who lives in suburban Catonsville. ``You can imagine what it's like. It's a battleship, but that has to be a boring run,'' said Zanti's sister, Karen Burkett. ``And a hard run, because you're running on metal, not asphalt or grass.'' Zanti's wife, Lt. Kathleen Zanti-Murray, 27, who met her husband at the U.S. Naval Academy and is based in Norfolk, Va., will also run with her father-in-law. Zanti said his son, who wrestled for the Navy, started training in April after traveling to California to watch him run in a marathon in Big Sur. ``While we were out there, my son met me at the 20-mile marker and we ran the rest of the race together,'' Zanti said. ``Guy really was impressed by the atmosphere, the runners and the whole scene. He's quite an athlete and he just felt like he could do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Deny Reports Leader Still Alive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th pvs, `Officials at...' to UPDATE with comment from U.S. officials; Pickup 7th, `The insurgents...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebels seeking to overthrow the Rwandan government denied reports in Ugandan newspapers today that their leader is alive and being treated for battlefield injuries in the United States. A statement from the Rwandan Patriotic Front said rebel leader Fred Rwigyema died after stepping on a mine Oct. 2, the second day of the invasion. Rebel representatives in Brussels said on condition of anonymity that the news of Rwigyema's death was kept secret for fear of lowering the morale of the guerrillas. But Ugandan newspapers reported today that Rwigyema was seriously wounded during a helicopter attack on rebel forces and was taken to the United States. The newspapers, quoting Rwandan army commander Lt. Col. Deogratius Ndabimana, did not describe Rwigyema's injuries or say when or where he was injured. The reports in the Star and Munno newspapers also did not say who evacuated Rwigyema, a former Ugandan deputy army commander, or where he was taken in the United States. Officials at the U.S. Embassy in Kampala, Uganda, could not be reached for comment. In Washington, U.S. officials said they could not confirm whether Rwigyema was dead or alive, but pointed out he had not been heard from since the beginning of the invasion. They also denied, on condition of anonymity, that Rwigyema had been brought to the United States for treatment. The insurgents said Rwigyema was killed in the northeastern region around Kagitumba near the Ugandan border. The rebels have a base camp in the area. The front also announced two other rebel leaders were killed by a land mine on Oct. 23. The statement did not say who was currently leading the insurgents. The rebels said they still controlled the Kagera National Park in the north, which makes up about 15 percent of Rwanda's territory, despite government claims it had driven the insurgents out. The front said it was ready to talk with the government about the future of Rwanda, a former Belgian protectorate. But the rebels warned they could still launch attacks. Last week, the Belgian government said it had negotiated a cease-fire between the government troops and the rebels, but the truce has yet to become effective. Belgium and France sent paratroopers to Rwanda to protect their nationals after the insurgency began. Belgium's last paratroopers returned Saturday. Rwigyema, who was 34, fled Rwanda as a child during the repression of the Tutsi tribe. He returned to Rwanda on Oct. 1, leading a group of mostly Tutsi refugees and deserters from Uganda's army seeking to depose the government.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Tough Anti-Tax and School Choice Issues Trailing
DOC.TEXT: The tax revolt and the environmental movement may be headed for jolts at the polls Tuesday. And anger at government could lead voters in two states to limit politicians' terms. Polls conducted in the final days of this year's campaign show roughly 2-1 support for ballot proposals in California and Colorado aimed at limiting terms of state legislators. Colorado's proposed amendment extends even to U.S. senators and congressmen. But the tide may be turning against ``Big Green,'' a sweeping environmental issue in California, as well as many of the anti-tax, anti-spending measures facing voters in about a dozen states. In several cases, that's a switch from earlier poll results showing many such measures seemingly coasting toward approval. In all, voters in 43 states and the District of Columbia will decide 236 ballot questions, according to the Free Congress Foundation, a conservative Washington-based research group that tracks propositions. Sixty-seven are citizen initiatives - the most since 1914, when a record 90 appeared on state ballots. Twenty-six states, mostly in the West, allow citizens to put initiatives on the ballot. The changing fortunes of ballot races in several states have followed heavy campaigning by teachers unions, local government officials and other affected interest groups and individuals. Their efforts appear to be paying off in Massachusetts, Oregon and Nebraska, where early support for stringent anti-tax, anti-spending issues seems to be waning. Analysts had interpreted the heavy volume of ballot measures as a sign of voter anger at politics-as-usual. But as Election Day approaches, confusion prevails as voters try to sort out the consequences of the many ballot issues that promise sweeping solutions to complex problems. Nowhere is that truer than in California, where earlier wide support for the highly complicated environmental proposition known as ``Big Green'' has dwindled, according to polls. The proposal is just one of 28 questions on California's ballot. The outlook in key contests: - A tight race is apparently shaping up over California's Proposition 128, which would impose severe limits or bans on pesticides, offshore oil drilling, and chemicals and emissions that harm the ozone layer. Environmental advocates still hope passage would give their cause a boost, but a poll on Friday found ``Big Green'' trailing slightly. - Among other environmental contests, Missourians appear evenly split on a ``Natural Streams'' proposal aimed at protecting Ozark waterways. - In Massachusetts, a proposed $2 billion state tax rollback is facing an uphill battle. A poll for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV found 59 percent opposed to the rollback. Opponents of what would be the largest voter-initiated state tax cut in history argue it would bankrupt poor school districts, seriously damage others and lead to tens of thousands of state layoffs. - A Montana initiative, which would junk the state's existing tax system and replace it with a novel 1 percent ``trade charge'' on all sorts of transactions, is trailing by a wide margin in opinion polls. - Polls suggest a majority of Utah voters may be heeding warnings of state college and school officials that a proposed repeal of the state sales tax on most food would be a disaster for education financing. - In Nebraska, the so-called ``2 Percent Solution,'' a proposition that would limit annual growth in state and local spending to 2 percent, is likewise in trouble. An Oct. 24-26 poll published in the Omaha World-Herald found 57 percent of those surveyed opposed to the limit. Nebraskans also seem to be turning against a proposal to scrap a recently enacted school finance reform law that takes the burden from property tax by increasing state income and sales taxes. - In a contest being watched by the Bush administration and education reformers, Oregon voters will decide on a far-reaching school ``choice'' measure that would grant parents a $2,500 tax credit to send their kids to any school, even church-related, or to teach them at home. Recent polls show the plan trailing. - A survey released Wednesday indicated Oregon voters narrowly favored two other tough measures: one phasing in a 1.5 percent property tax limit, and a second that would shut down the state's only nuclear power plant. - In Nevada, 52 percent of those surveyed in an Oct. 21 poll supported a ballot issue aimed at making it harder to change the state's liberal abortion law. In Oregon, a proposed ban on abortions except in cases of rape and incest appears headed for defeated, while a measure requiring parental notification for abortions performed on minors may pass. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Lee Mitgang has followed ballot issues since 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Prepares for Islamic Law
DOC.TEXT: The right-wing coalition that ousted Prime Minister Benzair Bhutto is ready to revive the spread of Islamic law, and everthing from social mores to civil liberties may be affected. Islam has long been the center of cultural conflict between the Westernized urban elite and Islamic clerics who wield enormous influence over the impoverished, conservative countryside where most of Pakistan's 110 million people live. The last military dictator, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, championed Islamic law. During her 20 months in power, however, Mrs. Bhutto was able to stave off attempts by religious fundamentalists to assert their influence over government and society. With her dismissal from office and subsequent defeat in last month's parliamentary elections, the governing Islamic Democratic Alliance is in a position to bring back strict Islamic principles and has pledged to do so. It has a parliamentary majority and probably will be able to draw on small parties for the two-thirds majority needed to pass a bill imposing Islamic law. ``In Islam, the state and religion cannot be separated,'' said Zia's eldest son, Ijaz ul-Haq, who won a Parliament seat by promising to carry on his father's Islamic dream. During his 11-year rule, Gen. Zia made the ``Islamization'' of Pakistani society a pillar of his policy. He was killed in a plane crash in August 1988, and Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party won elections held three months later. Her dismissal Aug. 6 charges of corruption and mismanagement renewed the debate of whether Pakistan should be a secular democracy or governed by the laws of the Koran, the Moslem holy book, as interpreted by Islamic scholars. Islamic law is interpreted with varying stringency from one Moslem nation to another. Gen. Zia's laws included a ban on consumption of alcohol, flogging and stoning as punishments for such crimes as drinking and adultery, and a 2.5 percent tax on the rich to help the poor. They remain in effect, but punishment by flogging is rare and there have been no stonings. Defining the relationship between Islam and the country's legal system has been a central question since 1947, when Pakistan was created as a homeland for Moslems in the partition of the Indian subcontinent. Many Islamic principles were enshrined in law before Zia seized power in a a 1977 military coup. He sought to expand these dramatically, giving courts constitutional power to determine whether laws conformed to the Koran and the traditions of the prophet Mohammed. When Gen. Zia dismissed Parliament in May 1988, he cited corruption, laxity and failure to promote Islamic law. He issued a presidential order that decreed the legal code of Islam to be the supreme law of Pakistan and expanded court powers to review laws for conformity with the Koran. Although special courts now review laws for compliance with Islamic tradition, final appeals still go to civil high courts rather than to legal bodies of religious scholars, as in some Moslem states. That could change with the new government, both critics and supporters say. ``The (bill) will have smooth passage,'' said Zia's son, a 38-year-old U.S.-educated banker. ``That is what Islam is.'' Opponents contend the Islamic biIl would promote sectarianism, pave the way for a militant and repressive theocracy, confine women to their homes and ostracize them, and bring the media and educational system under clerical control. Many groups, particularly the middle class, lawyers and educated women, believe Pakistan should not turn its back on Western educational and legal traditions inherited from the British colonial era. Ms. Bhutto has tried to cloak herself in Islamic traditions, but also has spoken out strongly against Zia's brand of Islamization. ``The name is Islam was used to practice oppression,'' she said. ``Basic human rights were jeopardized under the new laws enacted as Islamic laws.'' Earlier this year, she infuriated the clerics by saying she opposed cutting off a hand as punishment for theft. They called her an unbeliever and warned that anyone who said such things could be sentenced to death by religious leaders. Last week, the leading Islamic court ruled that punishment for defiling Mohammed's name or teachings must be death.

DOC.HEAD: Young Saddam Hussain Taking Some Ribbing
With AM-Gulf-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Meet Saddam Hussain. He plays baseball, likes cheese pizza and watches wrestling on television. But this Saddam is a 9-year-old fourth-grader at Pearl Upper Elementary School in this community near Jackson. Friends say he's an all-around nice kid. A Pakistan native, Saddam said he is unfazed by sharing a name with the man President Bush branded ``the butcher of Baghdad.'' ``When I was little, my parents used to tell me all about Saddam,'' he said. ``I know he's not a nice person.'' ``He is handling it all very well,'' teacher Patsy Rogers said of the occasional ribbing Saddam takes about his name. ``He has a sense of humor.'' Saddam said he quickly got used to double takes and quizzical looks from teachers when school started a few weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. ``They don't notice my name that much now,'' he said. ``Our music teacher said that if the Saddam Hussein over there was as sweet as the Saddam Hussain over here, we wouldn't have any problems,'' said Paige Welborn, one of Saddam's classmates. ``I think she's right.'' Saddam is quick to point out a key difference between his name and the Iraqi leader's: ``He spells his (last) name with an `E,''' Saddam said. ``I spell mine with an `A.''' Saddam got his name for two reasons: His older brother is named Hasham, and the rhyming names sounded good for a pair of brothers, his father, Manzoor Hussain, said, adding: ``In New York, where I was working, I had an Iranian friend. I would tell him, `I'm going to have a son, and I'm going to name him Saddam.''' He said he was only teasing his Iranian friend. At that time in 1980, Iran and Iraq were at war. ``After we had a son, I thought, `Why not name him Saddam? It's a good name,''' said Hussain, a veterinarian for the U.S. Agriculture Department in Jackson. Most of Saddam's peers at Pearl Upper Elementary understand a bit about events developing in the Persian Gulf, Rogers said. A few classmates have greeted him with military salutes. ``I just ignore them,'' Saddam said, shrugging. ``I don't like it when people make fun of him,'' said Scott Rowan, one of Saddam's best friends. ``I take up for him.'' Rogers smiles when talking about Saddam's part in a class project. ``They wrote letters to the servicemen in the Middle East,'' she said. ``You're going to love what Saddam put on his card. He wrote, `I'm not who you think I am.'''

DOC.HEAD: Taxi Firms Settle Bias Suit for $300,000, Agree to Monitor Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Three taxicab companies in the nation's capital have agreed to pay over $300,000 to settle a racial discrimination lawsuit. In a consent decree, the companies agreed to improve service, but did not admit to the alleged violations. The decree was signed in federal court on Friday. Six people and one company filed suit against the companies alleging that cabs in the District of Columbia failed to pick up black patrons and refused them service to predominantly black neighborhoods of the city. The suit was the first to address racial discrimination in the district's taxicab industry and makes the companies liable for actions by individual drivers. Under the agreement, American Cab, National Cab and Empire Cab said they would formally address complaints by passengers that claim they were refused service on the basis of race. All complaints would be recorded and investigated by a committee assigned by each company, court papers said. If the committee finds service was denied, wholly or partially based on race or the location of a rider's destination, actions will be taken against the driver. Officials said upon the first confirmed incident, the companies agreed to revoke the driver's right to use the company's colors and accompanying benefits for seven days. Taxicab driving privileges would be suspended for 12 days for a second incident and the driver would be permanently terminated upon the third incident.

DOC.HEAD: Soliders Clash With Crowds Protesting Jail Death in Gaza
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Arab reports saying 113 wounded, clashes spreading; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians enraged by the death of a prison inmate clashed today with soliders using tear gas and gravel-throwing machines. One protester was killed and dozens were injured, Arab and army reports said. Curfews were imposed on four villages and refugee camps in the occupied Gaza strip in an effort to quell the unrest, according to a statement from the army, which reported at least 43 injuries among the protesters. Arab reports put the number of wounded in the Gaza Strip at 113, including a 4-year-old boy who was struck in the head by gravel. The army said it was checking other reports. The clashes underscored a rise in Arab-Israeli tensions since the Oct. 8 Temple Mount killings of 20 Arabs and subsequent stabbing deaths of three Israelis in Jerusalem. The violence began early today after word that Attiyah Abdel Atti Zanin, 36, of Beit Hanoun village died in his jail cell in Gaza City. Authorities told Zanin's family he hanged himself with a rope made from blankets. Zanin was detained 13 days ago for questioning about links to the mainstream Fatah wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Prison Services spokeswoman Shulamit Meiri said Zanin's body was found late Friday. It was believed he committed suicide because he was alone in the cell and there were no signs of violence, she said. But rumors spread quickly through the village of 11,000 that Israeli soldiers killed Zanin, who had been jailed three times by Israeli authorities. Youths took to the streets and began throwing stones at troops, Arab reports said. The riots spread to at least three sections of nearby Gaza City and the refugee camps of Shati, Nozeirat and Jebalya. Troops opened fire, killing Mohammed Izzat Abdullah el Bassiouny, 36, who sustained a bullet wound in the head, the reports said. The army said Bassiouny was 29. Bassiouny was the 771st Palestinian to be killed by Israelis in the 34-month-old uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are home to 1.7 million Palestinians and some 70,000 Jewish settlers. Another 293 Arabs have been killed by fellow Palestinians as alleged collaborators with Israel, and Arabs have killed 51 Israelis and foreigners. Riots spread from Beit Hanoun to six other neighborhoods and refugee camps in the vicinity of nearby Gaza City, the reports said. Witnesses said soldiers sprayed tear gas out of helicopters and used gravel-throwing machines in some spots to contain the violence.

MOTHERHOOD AND MARCHING ORDERS:
DOC.TEXT: ``I called Mom to ask how the kids are doing,'' Capt. Sheila Michelli writes after rejoining her Army unit for military exercises. ``It's a relief to know that they miss me less than I miss them.'' An Army logistics officer at Fort Lee, Va., Sheila is a woman who knows how to take control and get things done. But saying goodbye to 6-week-old Connor is a tough order. He is the Michelli's second son - the last child the couple plan. ``The most wrenching part about returning to work is giving up breast-feeding,'' she writes at 5:53 p.m., after dropping the kids off with her parents and heading for nine days of crisis combat preparedness training. ``Connor I'll see in 11 days, but I'm done breast-feeding for good,'' she writes. ``It's so final.'' Still, letting go of her newborn is easier the second time around. Sheila, 27, has finally decided to commit to a career with the Army, where she believes working mothers have it pretty good. She received 28 days' paid maternity leave with her first child and 42 days with Connor. Less than half of U.S. working women have access to such maternity benefits, according to the Census Bureau. Shortly after returning to work last spring, Sheila was placed in command of a 300-member unit. The Persian Gulf crisis has since put pressure on the entire military, though the Michellis have not been directly affected. Sheila is proud of herself, but the work is demanding. And her husband, Tom, is a semi-workaholic who works as a computer programmer for Virginia's National Guard. Because both are so committed to their careers, tensions arise. Sometimes the couple ends up locking horns. But Sheila knows she can count on Tom to help warm a bottle, wash a load of diapers or be there when it's time to drive the babysitter home. ``It takes a lot of coordination and teamwork,'' says Sheila. ``We argue ... but he supports me.'' And that, all the mothers agreed, is key. ---
DOC.HEAD: BROADCASTING AND BREAST-FEEDING:
DOC.TEXT: ``The first day back at work was nothing short of traumatic,'' Pam Salazar writes after going back to her job reporting for television station WKEF in Dayton, Ohio. ``The thought of leaving my baby brought me to tears.'' Although willing to cut back on hours at the office and forgo her morning anchor position, Pam wasn't prepared to quit broadcasting altogether. ``I guess I thought somehow the situation would magically work itself out,'' she writes, after finding out how it feels to be caught between news deadlines and her 5-month-old daughter, Chase. There are no magic wands when it comes to racing the clock. Pam may roar home to relieve the babysitter after a late-breaking news story or reel into work after prolonged morning good-byes. But breast-feeding is another story. Mother Nature won't be rushed. ``I was extremely nervous,'' Pam, 28, wrote after her first disastrous attempt at expressing milk in an office bathroom. ``Would I be able to master the art ... would I manage to pump enough (milk) to feed my baby?'' It was only after several attempts and with a lot of coaching by telephone from her husband, Kyle Hickok, that Pam was able to get the gadget to draw milk. The new mother felt like she was hogging the bathroom and, perhaps, embarrassing her colleagues and herself. ``But my co-workers are very supportive of my breast-feeding,'' she writes. ``The news director bends over backwards to accommodate Mother Nature's schedule, allowing me to only go out on short stories so that I don't miss a pumping session.'' The majority of employers are not as supportive. Of 6 million U.S. companies, only a slimminority offer subsidies, referrals or on-site day care for working mothers. Some working mothers read a message in the writing on the wall: They feel they are not valued members of the labor force. Down at the TV station, Pam found the kind of support many women crave - and still there were tensions. ``Nursing is something I felt very strongly about, but I had my doubts about how professional it would be,'' she reflects. ``I'm pulled both ways ... feeling guilty that I'm not doing either of (my jobs) very well.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: SHARING THE LOAD:
DOC.TEXT: ``My name is Vicki Sugarman and my game is the `Mommy Track,' '' the new mother writes. ``I would be very upset if we were just a token, '' writes Janet Aikens, who with Vicki shares a job managing promotions at Reebok International Ltd. in Stoughton, Mass. Vicki and Janet each work three days a week, overlapping on Wednesdays. The co-workers hit on the increasingly popular alternative to full-time work and motherhood after each became pregnant around the same time last year. Job-sharing has required some adjustments to ensure both women are working on projects suited to their skills. All concerned eventually decided it would be easier for Janet and Vicki to split their hours but work independently. ``I now have the best of both worlds!'' writes Vicki, 31. ``I can maintain my professional status and still be with my daughter four days a week.'' But read between the lines. It wasn't quite that simple. The night before her first day back, Vicki lay in bed staring at the clock and wondering how being both a mother and a manager would work out. ``It is 3 a.m. in the morning and I am still wide awake just wondering: Will the baby think that I have deserted her? Will the nanny take good care of her? What will it be like to be back in the office? Have I forgotten everything I've ever learned? When will I ever fall asleep?'' Janet, too, has known fitful nights. Before the birth of her son, she was working 10 hours a day and traveling at least a week out of every month. Her husband, Andy, was matching her hour-for-hour at his job as an engineer for Raytheon Co. ``I was determined not to let my pregnancy change anything, so I continued to work, work, work ...'' Janet, 30, wrote after her first day back. ``I wanted to be promoted to associate brand manager by year's end, as scheduled.'' But things changed. Priorities shifted. ``The decision not to return to my career full time was a very difficult one for me. I had worked hard and long to get where I was ... (but) there was Skyler,'' Janet writes. ``I can get my career back on track, but I can never recapture Skyler's childhood.''
