DOC.HEAD: Pooch Palace is Doggone Nice
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans are feeling the pinch of an economic slowdown, but Popeye and Dana Gentry are living high in a custom-built, two-story gray and white cottage with a shingled roof and sundeck. Popeye and Dana are a pair of 2-year-old Great Danes. Their new 8-foot square home is a step up from their old, smaller living quarters. Although the stairs in the new unit presented a challenge at first, the dogs have adapted. Patrick Gentry, their owner and the builder of the house, said he plans several improvements. ``I'm going to fix it up a little bit better when I get some more time,'' he said. The planned additions include a bay window and insulation for the winter. The dogs like to hang out on the deck, standing on their hind legs to keep a lookout for cars coming up the long, gravel driveway, Gentry said. He said he got bored with the old building and wanted to build something unique. His neighbors are divided on the house, he said. ``A lot of them like it, and a lot of them think I'm crazy,'' he said. ``But I don't care. My dogs seem to like it.''

DOC.HEAD: Captured French Soldiers Freed But Face Discipline
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with plane landing in Amman, Jordan; Pickup 3rd, `The official...'
DOC.TEXT: Three French soldiers captured by Iraqi troops and freed today will probably be punished for apparently straying over the Saudi Arabian border into Iraq, a French general said. The soldiers arrived in Amman, Jordan aboard an Iraqi Airways jet, along with four freed American hostages. A Defense Ministry spokesman said the soldiers would be flown to Paris on Sunday. The official Saudi Press Agency cited the Joint Forces Command for multinational forces in the Persian Gulf as confirming that the French patrol had accidently crossed into Iraq on Monday. The Iraqi troops ``quickly'' took the three to Baghdad and turned them over to the French Embassy, which is negotiating their departure from Iraq, French authorities said. They declined to say when the soldiers were released. ``This wasn't a willful act by our soldiers but probably an error in appreciating particularly difficult terrain where reference points practically don't exist,'' Brig. Gen. Raymond Germanos of the Defense Ministry said in an inteview on France-Inter radio. The soldiers will almost assuredly be punished on completion of a military investigation into the incident, Germanos said. ``In the military profession, all faults are punished, and this fault could have had the most serious consequences,'' He said. Germanos ruled out the possibility that the patrol could have misunderstood standing orders, which explicitly prohibit patrols from straying too close to the Iraqi border. But there were conflicting reports about whether the soliders were taken by Iraqi troops in Iraq or in Saudi Arabia. The Defense Ministry said in a communique late Friday that the soldiers were captured in the region of Hafar el Batin in northeastern Saudi Arabia, but did not make clear whether the incident occurred on Iraqi or Saudi territory. Later at a news conference, Germanos said the investigation would clarify the soldiers' exact location when captured. He said he did not know what unit they were from. A Defense Ministry source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: ``They committed an error of exceeding their mission. There's a lot of movement around the border right now and we don't know exactly what happened. The commander who has opened the investigation believes they are responsible.'' Other military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the trio was composed of one officer and two non-commissioned officers in an all-terrain vehicle. The French soldiers were surprised by the Iraqi troops but committed no ``hostile act,'' the French Foreign Ministry said. The communique did not say how big the Iraqi patrol was. There are about 5,500 French soldiers, including paratroopers and Foreign Legionaires, stationed in Saudi Arabia. Defense sources said earlier Friday that France might reinforce its ground troops in Saudi Arabia with artillery and 500 more soldiers. France has about 13,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen in the region to defend Saudi Arabia and enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The multinational force of U.S. and other troops in Saudi Arabia totals about 300,000, facing an estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. The Baghdad government seized Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Threatens India's Concept of Secular Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with latest violence, death toll above 300. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Singh might...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AYO1
DOC.TEXT: Riots that exploded around a rundown little mosque in Ayodhya last week threaten the concept of secular government on which religiously diverse India prides itself. More than 300 people have been killed. The strife comes at a time when Indian politicians, lacking clear-cut ideologies, are defining their vote blocs by religion. Police with shoot-on-sight orders patrolled five northern Indian towns Saturday after renewed Hindu-Moslem clashes claimed 13 more lives, the Press Trust of India said. Police also said more victims were discovered from clashes Friday, bringing the overall death total to at least 305. The issue has shaken Prime Minister V.P. Singh's centrist government, which gained power 11 months ago. It is in trouble because it lost the support of the Bharatiya Janata Party, a right-wing Hindu group. Singh faces a confidence vote Wednesday. Singh might soon be deposed or relegated to a caretaker role, which would leave India limping toward new elections four years ahead of schedule. Both the riots and government crisis were precipitated by the efforts of Hindu fundamentalists to build a temple where they believe the god Rama was born, which happens to be under the Ayodhya mosque. The Bharatiya Janata fervently espoused the temple project. Emboldened by its make-or-break position in the government, the party claims to speak for India's Hindu majority. Its rhetoric, however, often resembles that of an embattled minority - especially after Singh, a Hindu, tried to halt the temple project while the courts sorted out conflicting Hindu-Moslem claims to the site. Moslemsare only 12 percent of India's 880 million people and tend to keep a low profile, especially when it comes to confrontation with the Hindu majority of 82 percent. Despite this, they went to court in an effort to save the 460-year-old Ayodhya mosque, fearing that if it went, others would follow. The Moslem suit provoked a tempestuous reaction. ``They want to swallow the whole of India,'' said Vijay Kumar Malhotra, secretary of the Bharatiya Janata and a parliamentarian. ``They have the government siding with them. The Indian home minister is a Moslem. In India, to be a Hindu has become a crime.'' A year ago, Indians were anxious for change and weary of allegations of corruption against Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. They splintered their vote; nobody won, everyone lost. Gandhi's Congress Party got 37 percent of the 522 Parliament seats, Singh's National Front coalition got 27 percent and the Bharatiya Janata bounced from near-obscurity to 17 percent. Singh teamed with the Bharatiya Janata and the Communists to forge a majority. There was little discernible difference in the platforms of democratic socialism presented by the Congress Party and National Front, and the Communists stood only slightly to the left. Even the Bharatiya Janata's written manifesto was similar to those of the Congress and the National Front, but its oratory appealed to a nationalism that increasingly tended toward Hindu fundamentalism. Because Singh's coalition was considered shaky from the start, everyone started anticipating new elections and staking out constituencies. The Moslems minority can be pivotal in close elections. The Congress Party and National Front compete for the Moslem vote and need to win Hindus back from the Bharatiya Janata. ``More and more riots are becoming political statements,'' said Ashis Nandy, a political analyst with the Center for the Study of Developing Societies, an independent think tank. Many analysts say religious blocs have become more important in the absence of ideological constituencies. Almost any issue, such as Ayodhya, that entices or placates one group alienates or threatens another. ``Religion is being used as a political tool,'' said Rev. Arokia Doss, a Jesuit theologian who studies the interaction of India's different faiths. M.J. Akbar, Congress Party spokesman, singled out the Bharatiya Janata Party for blame in the Ayodhya violence, but added: ``You can get freedom by winning a war of independence. A nation can be formed by a revolution, but the state only stabilizes after its civil war.'' Akbar, a Moslem who has written extensively on India's internal frictions, would not characterize India's current situation as civil war, but ``a process of confrontation in order to achieve political power.'' Although riots and rebellions are frequent in India, it also has a rich history of nonviolent protest and religious tolerance. It broke free of British colonial rule in 1947 through peaceful protests and strikes led by Mohandas K. Gandhi, revered as the Mahatma, or ``Great Soul.'' On the verge of that independence, however, it broke apart on religious lines and was partitioned into India, predominately Hindu, and Pakistan, overwhelmingly Moslem. There was a bloody transmigration in which 1 million people died, but nearly as many Moslems remain in India as now live in Pakistan. Memories of those violent days continue to stir Hindu-Moslem antagonism, but Nandy found one legacy of hope. ``Even after a million killed, we could go back to a normal life,'' he said. ``It left its scars, but one could go back to civilized living. But that's the optimistic view.'' The pessimistic view? ``Each party will continue to play its own games.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying Americans, French Soldiers Lands in Amman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to CORRECT Spelling of hostage name, hometown; Pickup 5th, `Trinh, who...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways flight carrying four sick American hostages freed by the Iraqi government and three French soldiers captured this week by Iraqi troops arrived today in Amman, Jordan. Also on the flight from Baghdad was a two-man delegation from the U.S. peace group, Fellowship of Reconciliation, which negotiated the release of the four Americans. French and U.S. Embassy officials meeting the plane said the Americans and the soldiers would be flown home Sunday morning. In Baghdad, the four Americans were identified as Dr. Abdul Kanji, 50, an Indian-born American from Glencoe, Ill.; Raymond Gales, a diplomat from the besieged embassy in Kuwait; Michael Barner, 49, of Woodsworth, La.; and Randall Trinh, 49, of Hacienda Heights, Calif.. Trinh had been held at an unknown strategic site in Iraq. Iraq's Information Ministry had said Friday the four were being released because they were ``elderly and sick,'' although it was not immediately clear what ailments they suffered. The French soldiers were turned over to the French Embassy after their capture Monday. They had arrived at the Baghdad airport today accompanied by the French charge d'affaires, Andre Janier, who did not allow them to speak to reporters. Janier said Iraq let the soliders leave because ``French nationals anyway are allowed to leave Iraq.'' Saddam freed all French citizens last week. But thousands of Westerners are still being held, many at strategic locations to deter possible attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces in the region. Amid charges that Iraq is mistreating hostages, the Baghdad government on Friday allowed reporters to visit some captives being used as human shields at key sites. Humanitarian groups and officials from some countries are working for the release of the captives, held since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left today for Baghdad with that mission, and three Irish parliamentarians traveled to Iraq on Friday to try to win the release of their countrymen. Although Nakasone's trip is private, it has the Tokyo government's backing. His chartered Boeing 747 carried 6 tons of food, clothing, medicine, books, letters and personal effects for Japanese hostages. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was to depart today for a trip that includes meetings with leaders of Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the ousted Kuwaiti government, Egypt, Turkey, Britain and France. Baker also is to meet next week with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen. The Chinese Foreign Ministry announced today that Qian would visit Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Egypt next week to discuss the gulf crisis. President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived in Cairo, according to a source close to Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak. Mitterrand will meet with Mubarak Sunday on the gulf crisis, the source said on condition of anonymity. Paris indicated the three French soldiers captured by Iraq may have blundered. A French Defense Ministry spokesman said disciplinary action was being taken against the men for their ``act of carelessness,'' indicating the patrol was captured on Iraqi territory. A ministry communique said the soldiers were captured on a patrol Monday near the Saudi-Iraqi border northwest of Hafar el Batin, a city in northeastern Saudi Arabia about 50 miles from the border. The three were turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad later in the week. France has contributed about 13,000 soldiers to the 300,000-strong multinational force deployed after Iraqa invaded Kuwait. Saddam's troops then rounded up Westerners, who are being held in Kuwait and Iraq. Western governments have accused Iraq of trying to crack international opposition to its occupation of Kuwait by selectively releasing hostages. There are about 1,000 American captives still in Iraq and Kuwait. On Friday, reporters were taken to a strategic site about 60 miles north of Baghdad and interviewed 10 foreigners - American, Japanese and British - as Iraqi officials stood nearby. The captives denied reports they were being underfed or mistreated by their guards. They said they received messages from their families over the BBC and the Voice of America radio. One American, Charles Keegan, 56, an investment strategist, said: ``The food is decent. I eat well and I'm treated well.'' His hometown was not available. In recent days, there has been an escalation of claims in the West that the foreigners are being mistreated. Iraqi officials have denied the charges. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that with the onset of cooler weather in the gulf, U.S. officials had been trying unsuccessfully for Iraqi cooperation in supplying clothing and blankets to American hostages. The deputy director of the American Red Cross said the organization is arranging to provide postal services to the captives.

DOC.HEAD: Two British Satellite Networks To Merge
DOC.TEXT: After months of battling, Britain's two satellite television networks have announced they would merge, pooling their flagging resources and ending a bitter ratings war. The four-channel Sky Television will merge with British Satellite Broadcasting's five channels to form a new five-channel network called British Sky Broadcasting, Sky announced Friday. ``The merger brings to an end a satellite war with both sides claiming there can no longer be a loser in the television space race,'' Sky World News said in a bulletin. Sky said the battle had been expensive and acrimonious, with each network bidding against the other for feature films and sport, the staples of satellite menus. Sky and British Satellite will merge with a combined investment of $2.43 billion, it said. Media magnate Rupert Murdoch's company, News International PLC, which owns Sky, and British Satellite's major shareholders will each hold 50 percent of the new company, Sky said. Sky was launched in February 1989. British Satellite, after a delayed start, has been broadcasting for just six months. Both have been hit by soaring costs, dwindling advertising revenues and declining British television audiences. News International disclosed recently that Sky has been losing $3.9 million a week. But the Australian-born Murdoch, now a U.S. citizen, said the company would earn a profit next year. According to Continental Research, a media research company, the number of British homes receiving satellite television exceeded 1 million for the first time at the end of August. Sky says there are just over 1 million of its circular receiving dishes in use. Homes that tap into Sky channels through the cable network bring the figure to 1.6 million, a potential audience of 5.5 million, a Sky spokeswoman said. British Satellite subscribers receive programs via distinctive square dishes, dubbed ``squarials.'' There are an estimated 100,000 of these in use. Britain has a total population of 57 million people. Chris McLaughlin, British Satellite's corporate affairs manager, said Friday the five combined channels will include two movie channels, available on subscription only. Sky's Astra satellite, in orbit above central Africa, will provide the primary system but there will be ``a lengthy transitional period during which arrangements will be made to protect existing subscribers,'' McLaughlin said. News International had no immediate comment on the merger. Until the launch of Sky, British TV consisted of four land-based channels: Independent Television and Channel 4, which are both funded by advertising, and the British Broadcasting Corp.'s BBC1 and BBC2, funded by an annual fee paid by TV viewers.

DOC.HEAD: Prospect of City Kids in Suburbs Raises Fears
LaserPhoto KX1
DOC.TEXT: Brenda McCoy's two children had never gone to school with blacks before. But when their rural district began accepting students bused from inner-city neighborhoods, they made some fast friends. ``Once you let the kids work it out by themselves, one on one, there's no problem,'' their mother said. Doris Brunson doesn't see it that way. Her suburban district has refused Kansas City children, despite pleas from judges and educators trying to desegregate schools. A recent Supreme Court ruling may finally force the district's hand, and that has her worried. ``It has nothing to do with race,'' the mother of two from Independence said. The inner-city students could bring drugs, and they could slow down her childrens' progress, she said. ``We don't want any more problems than we already have.'' To Pat Shanks, it's a matter of fairness. She and her husband moved to the suburb of North Kansas City when they decided to have a family. ``We live here and pay our taxes here. Some of us have to work two jobs to live in these neighborhoods. The kids who live here should go to these schools,'' she said. In the 13-year history of Kansas City's desegregation case, no issue has created as much court wrangling, and as few results, as proposals to send inner-city students to predominantly white suburban schools. So far, only 10 students have made the move - the 10 that came this fall to Mrs. McCoy's tiny district in rural Missouri City. A ruling last Monday by the U.S. Supreme Court increases the likelihood that more children could be bused out of the city soon. No figure has ever been set for the number of minority students to be sent to the suburbs. In 1978, a federal judge ruled that five suburban districts on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area were not guilty of discrimination and six years later found the same way for 11 districts in Missouri. He dismissed them as defendants in the desegregation case but asked the districts to take blacks voluntarily in exchange for tuition from the state. They never did. That prompted a lawsuit, filed in 1988 by blacks denied admittance to three suburban districts in Missouri - Independence, North Kansas City and Lee's Summit. Because of the Supreme Court ruling, the case can now go to trial. The suburban districts say they're weighing the option of settling out of court. Part of Kansas City's desegregation effort - attracting whites from suburban or private schools to special ``magnet'' schools - has been fairly successful. About 560 new, non-minority students entered the district this fall, just over half the goal of 1,000 but double last year's number. But 74.7 percent of the district's 35,098 students still are minority. Most educators think the numbers will never balance until some black students go to other districts. Missouri City, with just 105 students in elementary and junior high, became the first testing ground because its superintendent thought it was the right thing to do. ``It's been very, very successful,'' said superintendent Jay Jackson. ``Our kids benefit, too, you know.'' Missouri City's success has reassured other suburban districts, said George Feldmiller, a lawyer for those districts. One of their biggest worries has been that the Kansas City district, criticized for mismanagement, would try to run their schools, Feldmiller said. Missouri City prevailed in refusing to accept the oversight of a Kansas City monitoring committee. Many people in the suburbs, and some blacks in the city, say the real answer is to improve Kansas City's schools. The Rev. Nelson Thompson, executive director of the Martin Luther King Urban Center and president of Kansas City's chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, acknowledges that many black parents want to send their kids to the suburbs. But he contends many others agree with him that busing is a bad idea. ``They're just going to be put into an environment that is hostile,'' Thompson said. ``The people in the suburban districts don't want them there.'' He said the real issue is the racial quotas a federal judge has placed on Kansas City's magnet schools. They have resulted in some black students being turned away from schools in their neighborhoods. ``We're getting sidetracked from the goal of really helping these black kids,'' Thompson said.

DOC.HEAD: Release of Hostages Allows Frenchman to Keep Wedding Date
With AM-Gulf-Foreigners, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France (AP) - Ex-hostage Christian Sergent has had a good week - freed by Iraq on Monday, married on Saturday. The 36-year-old oil technician came home this week along with 261 other French hostages after being held captive by Baghdad since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Throughout his captivity, Sergent's biggest fear was that he wouldn't keep his wedding date with girlfriend Giselle Jummarra, set for Saturday, her birthday. He made it with five days to spare. ``I'm crazy with happiness,'' Sergent said Saturday. ``I'm going to give up smoking.'' The couple were married in a civil ceremony Saturday in this university town 470 miles south of Paris. Sergent chose another ex-hostage, Pierrot Sanchez, as his best man. Five other freed hostages attended the wedding. Sergent had been in Iraq only one day when President Saddam Hussein's troops stormed into Kuwait. A week later, he was forced to go from an oilfield in the northern part of Iraq to Baghdad. He spent more than three months in captivity as part of Saddam's roundup of Westerners. The Iraqi leader freed the French captives Monday in an apparent attempt to split the multinational alliance facing him in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: A State-By-State Survey of The Hottest Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 18, bgng: Minnesota -, and 24, bgng: Oregon -, to add first names of Boschwitz and Hatfield
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 elections are a dream come true for political handicappers. There are 34 Senate races, 36 governor's contests and 435 U.S. House contests on Tuesday's ballot. Here is the outlook for the closest races, according to a state-by state survey by The Associated Press: Alabama - Gov. Guy Hunt, the first Republican elected governor in the state this century, is bidding for a second term and narrowly leads Democrat Paul Hubbert. Alaska - As a Republican, Walter Hickel was Alaska's second governor. Now he's back, running as an independent and leading Republican Arliss Sturgulewski and Democrat Tony Knowles. Democratic incumbent Steve Cowper is not running. Arizona - Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard, a Democrat, leads GOP developer Fife Symington. Incumbent Rose Mofford, a Democrat, is retiring. California - The big race of 1990, a megabuck contest for governor between Republican Sen. Pete Wilson and former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. A lot of polling with not much agreement, but the latest surveys give a hairline edge to Wilson. The result might have to await a count of absentee ballots days after the polls close. Connecticut - Republican Lowell Weicker lost his Senate seat in 1988. Now he's running for governor as an independent and leading Republican John Rowland and Democrat Bruce Morrison. Florida - Another high-stakes contest for governor. Republican Bob Martinez was at the top of the Democrats' list of vulnerable incumbents. Democrats got another boost when former Sen. Lawton Chiles decided to challenge Martinez. Chiles started out with a big lead, but it's now very close. Hawaii - This usually Democratic state gives the Republicans their best shot at picking up a Senate seat. Rep. Pat Saiki is running a strong race against Sen. Daniel Akaka, who was appointed to succeed the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga. Polls indicate the race is a tossup. Idaho - Republican Sen. James McClure is retiring and Rep. Larry Craig is favored to defeat Democrat Ron Twilegar in the Senate race. Illinois - Republican Jim Edgar and Democrat Neil Hartigan are running neck and neck to succeed GOP Gov. Jim Thompson. In the Senate race, Democrat Paul Simon holds a wide lead over Republican challenger Lynn Martin. Republicans had high hopes for this one, but Simon proved stronger than they thought. Iowa - Republican Gov. Terry Branstad appears to be holding off Democratic challenger Don Avenson. Iowans don't tend to re-elect Democratic senators but Sen. Tom Harkin has a strong chance to break that tradition. GOP Rep. Tom Tauke is within reach of an upset but has been unable to catch Harkin in pre-election surveys. Kansas - GOP Gov. Mike Hayden looked like a sure loser to Democrat Joan Finney a month ago. But her hard line against abortion appears to have hurt her and the race is now a dead heat. Kentucky - Sen. Mitch McConnell has led in all pre-election polls over Democrat Harvey Sloane. But this is a strongly Democratic state and Sloane is given a chance for an upset. Maine - Former Democratic Gov. Joseph Brennan wants his old job back and is challenging his Republican successor, John McKernan. Brennan held an early lead, but the race now is a tossup. Massachusetts - Home of the voter rebellion. Outsider Democrat John Silber has the edge over Republican William Weld in the race to succeed Gov. Michael Dukakis. Sen. John Kerry, fighting to avoid being swept away by the rage that toppled incumbents in the September primary, has opened a double-digit poll lead over Republican Jim Rappaport. Michigan - Gov. James Blanchard is having trouble shaking off a challenge from Republican John Engler. A new poll said Engler was within 4 points among likely voters. Minnesota - Lake Wobegon gone berserk. Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich is viewed as potentially vulnerable to Republican Arne Carlson, who got onto the ballot only five days before Election Day. Carlson had lost the GOP gubernatorial nomination to Jon Grunseth, who was forced out of the race a week ago after allegations he swam nude with two teen-age girls and cheated on two wives. The fallout from the governor's race is considered a factor in the surprising vulnerability of incumbent GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who's in a dead heat with Democrat Paul Wellstone. Nebraska - GOP Gov. Kay Orr once trailed Democrat Ben Nelson but is now even up. In the Senate race, Democratic incumbent James Exon appears to be pulling away from former Rep. Hal Daub. New Mexico - Former Gov. Bruce King, a Democrat, is leading Republican Frank Bond, but not by much. North Carolina - One of the most watched races in the country is the Senate battle between Helms and his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte. Gantt has been ahead in the polls, but the contest has taken a nasty turn in the closing days. Ohio - One of the best Republican hopes for a gubernatorial pickup is this contest between Republican George Voinovich and Democrat Tony Celebrezze to succeed Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste. The race has tightened in the past two weeks. Oklahoma - Democrat David Walters leads Republican Bill Price in the race to succeed GOP Gov. Henry Bellmon. Oregon - Tight races for governor and Senate. Democrat Barbara Roberts holds a narrow lead over Republican Dave Frohnmayer in the race to succeed Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt. In the Senate race, Mark Hatfield was caught by surprise and is in a tight race with Democrat Harry Lonsdale. Rhode Island - The outlook is bleak for GOP Gov. Edward DiPrete, who trails Democrat Bruce Sundlun by 52 points. In the Senate race, Rep. Claudine Schneider's challenge to Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell appears to have fallen short. South Dakota - GOP Sen. Larry Pressler leads Democratic challenger Ted Muenster. Texas - Races don't get much nastier than this contest for governor between Republican Clayton Williams and Democrat Ann Richards. Williams once was far ahead, but the race suddenly closed to a dead heat a week ago. Vermont - Former Gov. Richard Snelling once looked like a landslide winner in his bid to get his old job back. But Democrat Peter Welch has moved within striking distance.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Share Thanksgiving with Troops in Gulf and Meet with Allies
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 4 grafs to add that first lady will join Bush on Mideast trip, include comments from rally speech
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that he and his wife Barbara were looking forward to sharing Thanksgiving with troops he has sent to the Persian Gulf. Bush, speaking at a Republican rally here, accused Iraq's Saddam Hussein of being ``the neighborhood bully'' and renewed his determination to stand firm to drive him out of Kuwait. The president indicated that the first lady also would be joining him on his trip to the Mideast, an eight-day journey that would include stops in Europe. ``Barbara and I are really looking forward to visiting these young people half way around the world.'' Bush also planned meetings with his chief allies in the region. The White House announced the visit on Friday as Bush continued a cross-country campaign trip in which he has blended Persian Gulf rhetoric with partisan politics. Bush today planted an oak on the campus of California Lutheran University and attended a rally for Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, who is locked in a tight gubernatorial race against Democratic San Francisco Mayor Diane Feinstein. As he planted the tree, Bush praised the recently enacted Clean Air Act, which he supported. ``I will sign this landmark legislation as soon as it gets to my desk,'' Bush said. Bush had hoped to sign the bill at today's ceremony, but Democratic congressional leaders - perhaps not wanting Bush to reap political advantage from the event - are not expected to physically send him the bill for signing until after the Tuesday election. Bush will visit Egypt and Saudi Arabia following a trip to Paris for the Nov. 19-21 conference to sign a 34-nation treaty on reducing troops and tanks in Europe, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater announced on Friday. While in the gulf region, Bush will consult with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the exiled emir of Kuwait. Details for Bush's visit, and whether he will visit sailors on U.S. ships as well as troops stationed in Saudi Arabia, have yet to be worked out, said White House spokesman Alixe Glen. She said a White House advance team left Washington on Friday and would not be in Saudi Arabia for several days. The president told a GOP rally in Rochester, Minn., ``These are not easy times. But never have I been more proud of the young men and women - all volunteers - highly motivated, beautifully trained, who are serving halfway around the world than I am today.'' ``And we will not let them down.'' Earlier, he told a Cincinnati audience: ``I will do my level best to bring every single one of them home without a shot fired in anger, but we will not stop short of our stated objectives.'' Those objectives, Bush has said repeatedly over the past few days, are a complete unconditional withdrawal by Iraq from Kuwait and restoration of the government of the emir of Kuwait. The United States has more than 210,000 troops in the gulf region - the largest force sent abroad since the Vietnam war - and Washington plans to send 100,000 more. About 100,000 soldiers have been deployed by other nations. The 13-nation force - including troops from several moderate Arab nations - faces about 460,000 Iraqi troops stationed in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Bush today was to attend a rally at California Lutheran University here for Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., who is in a neck-and-neck race for governor with former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. Later he was to speak at an airport rally in Albuquerque, N.M., for GOP gubernatorial candidate Frank Bond, a former state legislator who is battling former Democratic Gov. Bruce Kings' comeback effort. The president was to end the day in Houston, his adopted home town and his legal voting residence. He will remain in Texas through Election Day morning. For the fourth day in a row, Bush on Friday kept up a verbal barrage against the Iraqi leader, accusing him of inhumane treatment of U.S. diplomats and hostages. ``The brutality against innocent citizens will not be tolerated and ... will not stand,'' he told his Minnesota audience. ``And the world should rise up and demand that those people be let go.'' The White House would not discuss whether it was concerned that Saddam might use Bush's visit to launch an attack on U.S. positions in Saudi Arabia, or any other security concerns. ``If we didn't think it was safe, he wouldn't go,'' said an official, who commented only on condition of anonymity. Bush plans to leave Washington on Nov. 16 for Europe and return from the Middle East on Nov. 23. He will stop first in Prague for the Nov. 17 first anniversary of the nonviolent ouster of the communist government of Czechoslovakia, and will consult with President Vaclav Havel. He then will travel on Nov. 18 to Germany to consult with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at his summer home in Ludwigshafen. Next, in Paris, the president will meet with Gorbachev and other leaders of the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The centerpiece of that summit is to be the signing of a treaty to reduce conventional forces in Europe. He will leave Paris Nov. 20 for Egypt and Saudi Arabia. The Paris part of the trip had been previously announced. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, left Washington today on his own diplomatic mission to Saudi Arabia and Egypt. Baker also planned to go to Moscow next week to discuss the gulf crisis with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.

DOC.HEAD: Heartbroken Colombians Gather To Lament Lost Love Affairs
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of heartbroken Colombians gathered Sunday to commiserate with fellow losers in love by singing romantic songs, crying and listening to consoling words from the governor. ``Happy are the heartbroken who know the thresholds of suffering,'' said Gov. Ernesto Zuluaga of Risaralda state, marking the First National Conference of the Heartbroken in this small town in central Colombia. Carlos Alfonso Victoria said he and friends organized the conference to help others who were betrayed in love. He said he almost committed suicide six years ago after losing his lover and suffering four other failed affairs. On Saturday, about 250 of the dispairing converged on the specially erected ``Wall of Lamentations'' upon which they wrote angry verses of frustrated romance. ``I'm sick of you and your money,'' said one note, signed only ``Susana.''

DOC.TEXT: As Northeastern voters prepare to go to the polls on Tuesday, their mood can best be described as anger - at an enveloping recession, at record taxes and billion-dollar budget deficits, and at incumbents. ``The three biggest issues are the economy, the economy and the economy,'' said Thomas Ferguson, a political science professor at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. ``You're looking at declining real estate values. And you've got a lot of people losing their jobs.'' In Massachusetts and in three Maryland counties, residents will vote on tax-busting referendums. Incumbents in some hard-hit states are running for their political lives - and some quit rather than face the voters' wrath. Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts rode his state's prosperity to the Democratic presidential nomination. But when he lost, and Massachusetts wnt into a tailspin, he raised taxes and said he would not run for re-election. Democratic Govs. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin of Vermont also raised taxes and bowed out of the primaries. Still, Republican candidates seized on their unpopularity, accusing them of budget mismanagement and big spending. Their Democratic replacements tried to disassociate themselves from the incumbents they dubbed as political insiders. Two incumbent Republican governors, John R. McKernan of Maine and Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island, ran for re-election and faced tough challenges. The ramaining four incumbent governors who are up for re-election seem safe. Govs. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania and William D. Schaefer of Maryland, both Democrats, held the line on taxes and both states declared budget surpluses for the fiscal year ended June 30. New Hampshire has no income or general sales tax and Republican Gov. Judd Gregg opposed both. Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York appears assured of winning a third, four-year term despite a record $1.8 billion tax increase; a state credit rating that is the third worst in the nation; and a recent poll that found that 56 percent believed New York was headed in the wrong direction. He faces a weak, campaign-bungling opponent, Pierre Rinfret, an economist and political novice who was chosen when no more prominent politician agreed to run. And Cuomo has been able to stay in front of the issues. ``He anticipated the economic downturn and began to address it last January, talking about how the problems in New York were of a national scope starting from Washington,'' said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. ``He was able to deflect a lot of tension otherwise laid at his doorstep by talking about national political leadership.'' The only question is whether Cuomo can reach or top his record 65 percent of the vote he received in 1986, a boost for a possible run for the presidency. The tightest races appear to be in Massachusetts, Maine and Rhode Island. In Massachusetts, Democrat John Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, and Republican William Weld, a former assistant U.S. attorney general, both campaigned as outsiders who would return the state's economy to good health. Both defeated their party's endorsed candidate in the primary. Silber opposes ``Question 3,'' a referendum that would roll back taxes and some fees to their 1988 level. Weld supports it. Backers say Massachusetts residents already pay the sixth highest taxes in the country and that during the last seven years the Dukakis Administration has increased spending from nearly $7 billion to more than $13 billion. If the referendum is approved, opponents say, it would roll back $1 billion already collected and spent and cost Massachusetts $6 billion over three years, forcing cutbacks in education, programs for the elderly and other services. Referendums in Montgomery, Anne Arundel and Baltimore counties in Maryland would limit annual increases in property taxes to as low as 2 percent a year or would peg them to the previous year's inflation rate. Montgomery County, one of the wealthiest in the nation, is a suburb of Washington. In Maine, U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, a Democrat, is trying to unseat the Republican incumbent McKernan. Brennan charged that McKernan failed to move quickly enough to counter the faltering economy. Brennan served two four-year terms as governor before changing offices with McKernan in 1987. Rhode Island's DiPrete is in danger of losing the governor's office to Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun, a millionaire businessman who is trying to unseat him for the third time. DiPrete reversed himself on a pledge of no new taxes. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., former three-term Republican U.S. senator who is running as an independent for the Connecticut governor's seat, is favored to break the Democratic Party's two-decade hold on the office. In Vermont, Republican Richard Snelling, Gov. Kunin's predecessor, is the favorite to succeed her. The only major races in New Jersey and Delaware are for the U.S. Senate. The Democratic incumbents, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, often mentioned as a presidential candidate, and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, are expected to win re-election by wide margins. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - George Esper is the AP's Northeast Regional Reporter, based in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Church Admits Partial Responsibility for Sexual Abuse of Teen
DOC.TEXT: Two Roman Catholic dioceses have admitted partial responsibility for psychological injury suffered by a 24-year-old man who was sexually abused by a priest as a teen-ager. During opening arguments Friday in a civil trial the man brought against the priest, the man's attorney said the church placed the Rev. Thomas Adamson in positions of power and trust, knowing he had a history of abusing boys. John Hoffman, representing the Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis, told the jury the church placed restrictions on Adamson, but the restrictions and the church's monitoring of Adamson's activities were not effective. Hoffman said church officials had information about alleged contact between Adamson and teenage boys after those restrictions were imposed, but did not check it out. ``We could have, we should have, but we didn't,'' Hoffman said. Hoffman and George Restovich, an attorney for the Diocese of Winona, admitted the church was guilty of negligence and said they will pay damages. But they said the dioceses were innocent of willfully employing an unfit priest. Testimony is scheduled to begin Monday in Anoka County District Court. Adamson's attorney said Adamson accepts full responsibility for his actions and will not deny any of the allegations raised in the trial. The case is only the third case of sexual abuse by a priest to come to trial in the country, said Jeffery Anderson, the victim's attorney. It is also the first case in which a judge has allowed a sexual abuse victim to seek punitive damages from the Catholic Church, Anderson said. The case was one of six sexual abuse cases filed against Adamson, 57, who served parishes in southern Minnesota and the Twin Cities from 1961 to 1984. Four have been settled and one is pending. Adamson now lives in Wisconsin and no longer functions as a priest. One of his alleged victims, who received an out-of-court settlement, was convicted earlier this year of attempted first-degree homicide for traveling to Wisconsin to kill Adamson. Anderson said his client, who did not disclose the abuse until 1989, ``can be treated and he may get better, but he will not be cured.'' Hoffman and Restovich said the church is not responsible for all of the man's problems. They said he had a personality disorder before the abuse occured and came from a troubled family.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan's Fifth Civilian Government Takes Power
With AM-Pakistan-Islam, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The fifth civilian government in 43 years took power Saturday without ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who led her party in walking out on the new Parliament. The 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto and her Pakistan People's Party boycotted the swearing-in ceremony for the legislature after her jailed husband, Asif Ali Zardari, was not allowed to attend. The right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance, which routed Ms. Bhutto in last month's election, took the oath without her. Dozens of police carrying nightsticks surrounded the National Assembly building and forced Ms. Bhutto's supporters across a tree-lined boulevard. Ms. Bhutto initially rejected demands to boycott the opening session of the National Assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament. But she walked out after Zardari did not show up for the ceremony. Interior Minister Zahid Safraz said adequate security arrangements could not be made to bring Zardari from jail in the southern port city of Karachi to the Pakistani capital. Zardari won a legislative seat representing the sprawling Karachi slum of Lyari in the Oct. 24 elections. He has been in jail since Oct. 10 on extortion charges. Earlier this week, a judge ordered that Zardari be allowed to take his parliamentary oath. Parliament Speaker Malik Miraj Khalid ordered the minister to bring Zardari to Islamabad for Sunday's legislative session, when Ms. Bhutto and her parliamentarians were expected to take the oath of office. ``We assume (Zardari) will be brought in and we will take our oath with him,'' Ms. Bhutto told reporters following her party's walkout. Zardari, 38, has been blamed for many of Ms. Bhutto's troubles since her government was ousted Aug. 6. He came under fire during her 20 months in power for allegedly demanding commissions on lucrative government contracts. Less than two years ago, a triumphant Ms. Bhutto was hailed by many as the torchbearer of democracy. Her populist party won the largest bloc of votes in the November 1988 elections, Pakistan's first free polls after more than 11 years of military rule. Ms. Bhutto took over the prime minister's seat occupied by her father before his overthrow 11 years earlier. He was hung two years later for allegedly killing political foes. But only 20 months later, she was fired by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, who charged her government with widespread corruption and political ineptitude that he said had paralyzed Pakistan's Parliament. Ms. Bhutto now faces seven charges of misconduct. If she's found guilty on even one she can be banished from politics for seven years. Ishaq Khan picked a caretaker government from among her bitter foes and former allies. Many belonged to the right-wing coalition that swept the polls last month. Ms. Bhutto said the election had been rigged, but most observers said the fraud was not widespread and would not have changed the outcome. Today, the Pakistan People's Party controls only 45 seats in the National Assembly compared to the democratic alliance's 105. Nawaz Sharif, the alliance leader, said most independent and smaller parties would fall in line behind his coalition. The 41-year-old industrialist will be the next prime minister. He was the alliance's unanimous choice for the post, which will be decided by secret ballot in the assebbly next week. ``It's a distorted democracy, but it's better than nothing,'' said Iftikar Gilaini, a former law minister in Ms. Bhutto's Cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Fire Live Ammunition to Quell Riots; Up to 120 Reported Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Arab and army reports listing higher number of injured. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers firing live ammunition and rubber bullets fatally shot a Palestinian man and at least 89 people were hurt in riots set off by the death of an Arab detainee. Arab reports put the number of injured in the Gaza Strip violence at 120, which would make it one of the highest daily figures during the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising. The clashes underscored a rise in Arab-Israeli tensions since the Oct. 8 Temple Mount killings of 20 Arabs and subsequent stabbing deaths of three Israelis in Jerusalem. The unrest began after soldiers informed the family of Attiyah Abdel Atti Zanin, 36, in the Gaza village of Beit Hanoun that he had hanged himself in prison. Zanin was detained 13 days ago for questioning about activism in the Palestine Liberation Organization, Israeli and Arab reports said. His body was found in Gaza City prison Friday night, dangling from a rope made of blankets, Prison Services spokeswoman Shulamit Meiri said. She said the authorities believed the death was a suicide since he was alone in a cell and there were no other signs of violence on the body. But Zanin's family demanded an autopsy to determine the cause of death. Rumors also spread quickly through the village of 11,000 that Zanin had been killed by soldiers, spurring youths to take to the streets where they stoned Israeli troops, Arab reports said. Troops opened fire, killing Mohammed Izzat Abdullah el Bassiouny, 36, of a bullet wound to the head, the reports added. The army said Bassiouny was 29. He was the 771st Palestinian to be killed by Israelis in the uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are home to 1.7 million Palestinians and some 70,000 Jewish settlers. Another 293 Arabs have been killed by fellow Palestinians as alleged collaborators with Israel, and 55 Israelis and foreigners have been killed. Riots spread from Beit Hanoun to six neighborhoods and refugee camps in the vicinity of nearby Gaza City, the reports added. Witnesses said soldiers sprayed tear gas out of helicopters and used gravel-throwing machines in some spots to contain the violence. The army said 89Palestinians were injured in Gaza, most of them moderately or slightly injured. The military said the shooting was in response to ``numerous riots,'' in Gaza. Four villages and refugee camps in Gaza were placed under curfew. Arab reports said 102 Palestinians were wounded in these clashes. Of these, 49 were struck by live ammunition and 48 by rubber-coated metal bullets, the Arab reports said, citing hospital officials. Another four Palestinians suffered beating injuries. A 4-year-old boy, Zoheir Abu El Nur, of Jebalya, was reported injured seriously in the head by stones from an army gravel-throwing machine. He was rushed unconscious to Tel Hashomer Hospital near Tel Aviv, Arab reports said. Violence also broke out later Saturday in Rafah in Gaza's southern reaches. Assailants threw a firebomb at an Israeli military patrol and troops opened fire wounding 17 Palestinians, Arab reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Roman Catholic Pharmacists Must Observe Moral Code
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II told Roman Catholic pharmacists Saturday they have a moral duty to refrain from providing drugs which can be used, directly or indirectly, against life. In a speech marking the 40th anniversary of the founding of the International Federation of Catholic Pharmacists, the pope said the production, distribution and usage of medicines must be controlled by a ``rigorous moral code.'' The pope did not specify any drugs, but his comments could have referred to birth control and abortion pills, and substances used for euthanasia. Church teaching outlaws artificial birth control, abortion and euthanasia. ``The forms of aggression against life and its dignity are becoming more numerous, especially with the recourse to drugs, while these should never be used against life, directly or indirectly,'' John Paul said in French. ``In distributing drugs, the pharmacist cannot renounce the needs of his conscience in the name of the rigid laws of the market,'' the pope said. ``For the Catholic pharmacist, church teaching on the respect of life and the dignity of the human person, from the moment of conception until its last moments, is of an ethical and moral nature. It can not be subjected to variations of opinions or applied to the whims of fluctuating options.'' John Paul acknowledged that pharmacists may find it difficult to uphold the church teaching, but he stressed ``these fundamental guidelines cannot be renounced.''

DOC.HEAD: Brundtland Returns to Prime Minister Post for Third Time
DOC.TEXT:
Labor Party leader Gro Harlem Brundtland returned as Norway's prime minister Saturday and promptly sought peace with Conservatives who toppled her last two governments. Ms. Brundtland took over after the three-party coalition of former Conservative Prime Minister Jan P. Syse splintered over disputes on the nation's stance for European trade negotiations. ``We have disagreed a lot. Our parties do... But at the same time there is a lot that we agree on in this very important time for Norway,'' she told Syse, who resigned Monday after a year in the post. The new government has 63 seats and needs support among the other five parties in the 165-seat National Assembly to get its policies approved. The Conservatives have twice ousted Ms. Brundtland, but Syse promised ``a reasonable but determined opposition.'' Syse's party favors having the six-nation European Free Trade Association move closer to the 12-nation European Economic Community. The two trade blocs are discussing possibly opening all 18 nations to unrestricted trade after 1992.
But the Center Party fears possible changes in business laws for Norway, a member of the European Free Trade Association. Ms. Brundtland, 51, said her first tasks were to draft a 1991 national budget and define Norway's position for the ECC talks. Ms. Brundtland, a physician and Harvard-educated public health expert, was formally installed by Crown Prince Harald. He is acting monarch while his father, King Olav V, recovers from a stroke. A popular political figure who is usually called by her first name, she was greeted outside her new office by hundreds of Norwegians, many offering her flowers. ``Give me a G! Give me an R! Give me an O! We have Gro!'' cheered some admirers. Ms. Brundtland will present a government policy declaration early next week. Labor's first test may come in dealing with proposed tax reductions for higher income families, which the former coalition parties drafted and still favor. ``It won't be any easier than the last time,'' she said about ruling with a minority government. Ms. Brundtland was forced out of office in 1981 after seven months in office, and again last October after more than three years in the post. Both times, non-socialists held a majority in parliament. She was the nation's youngest and first woman prime minister. Some Norwegians criticized Ms. Brundtland for appointing Thorvald Stoltenberg as foreign minister after he served only 10 months of his five-year term as U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. ``We need his experience as a foreign minister in this very crucial phase for our government and country,'' said Ms. Brundtland. Stoltenberg was foreign minister in the last Labor government. Ms. Brundtland said she may recommend Center Party member Tom Vraalsen to succeed Stoltenberg in the Geneva-based refugee post.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty to Pinching Women, Gets 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to 10 years in prison for pinching two women on their buttocks. Randy Darrell Bowles, 36, was charged with two counts of sexual battery - which was changed last year from misdemeanor assault and battery to a felony. District Judge Clifford Hopper sentenced Bowles to two consecutive five-year terms under a plea agreement Friday. Bowles was accused of grabbing a woman walking in downtown Tulsa and saying ``tweak'' on Oct. 3. Police said the woman hit Bowles on the head with her umbrella, and he walked away. Hours later, Bowles was arrested after another woman screamed and told police he pinched her. Because of Bowles' felony record, he would have faced 20 years in prison on each charge had he been found guilty. Court records show Bowles was convicted in 1979, 1981 and 1982 of indecent exposure. Sexual battery became a felony in Oklahoma last November. The maximum penalty for offenders with no felony record is five years in prison. The maximum penalty under the old law was 90 days in jail on each count.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran of Korean War Hopes For Peace, But Ready For War
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Col. Walter Minor, a Korean War veteran who missed Vietnam, is back on active duty in Saudi Arabia, hoping for peace but ready for war. The 59-year-old country doctor from Fuquay-Varina, N.C., is one of the oldest members of Operation Desert Shield and possibly the only Korean War vet in an army whose average age is closer to 20. ``I didn't get called up. I just volunteered to come,'' he said Saturday. ``I was in the army back during the Korean War and I've been in the reserve ever since. In September, I volunteered to come back for a four-year tour and came over here.'' ``I thought there was a job over here that needed doing. I thought I was trained to do it, willing to come and do it. I'd rather do it than have my kids have to come and do it someday,'' he said. The doctor, who has a son in the army in Fort Wayne, Ind., arrived in Saudi Arabia three weeks ago to serve with the Army's 56th Medical Battalion. He flew home late Saturday to attend his mother's funeral but he said he would definitely be back. ``We got good troops out there,'' he said. ``The morale is good. They're hot and tired and dusty, but they're working hard and doing a good job. I'm very proud of the boys I've got in my unit.'' He predicted that the young soldiers' thirst for battle won't last long if war breaks out. ``I don't think the young ones know what combat is,'' he said. ``If they think combat is glorious, they're wrong. ... They'll cool it in a few days.'' ``I don't want to see anybody fight. I don't want any Iraqis hurt any more than I want any American boys hurt,'' he said. ``I hope it doesn't start but if it does, that's our job.'' Minor said being one of the army's old men didn't bother him a bit. Married at age 18, he said his wife was ``a good old trooper'' who accepted his decision to return to the military. His biggest complaint was about the slow mail service. ``It's a morale factor,'' he said. ``I've been here for three weeks and I haven't gotten anything yet, and I know my wife is sending something every day. I talked to her this morning. She has not received any mail from me yet.'' While on emergency leave, Minor said, he also plans to vote. ``God help the congressman who's raised my taxes,'' he said. ``I've been reading ... that now they won't provide the headstones for veterans. Yet they can vote themselves their own big salary increases, and I think that stinks.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Tough-guy film star Arnold Schwarzenegger got mixed reviews on a tour of a suburban shopping mall during a break from filming ``Terminator II.'' ``He's a lot more sexy inperson than he is on screen,'' said Jackie Johnson, 20, of Hayward, after catching a glimpse of the muscular star in the NewPark Mall in this San Francisco Bay city on Friday. Another woman wasn't happy with his manners. ``You could at least say `hi,''' she called to Schwarzenegger, who didn't respond. Schwarzenegger squeezed a couple of tennis shoes and tried on cowboy hats before security guards escorted him past a group of waving women and out of the mall. Schwarzenegger was filming scenes in nearby Fremont. --- HAMTRAMCK, Mich. (AP) - MTV video jockey ``Downtown'' Julie Brown pranced, prowled and even pilfered her way through the Cadillac assembly plant in this Detroit enclave while filming segments for her cable TV music show. Cheered on like a USO entertainer visiting battle-weary troops, Brown and her camera crews had the run of the General Motors Corp. facility Friday. She chatted with workers and test-drove several Cadillac models. ``Too bad I don't know how to drive,'' she said while rolling off the line in a midnight blue Seville. ``But they've got lots of these suckers back there so they don't care.'' Brown, 28, even found wardrobe accessories in the plant. But the cache of parts she stashed in her jumpsuit were confiscated when she was frisked by a security guard. ``I was going to make earrings out of them,'' Brown said of the foiled theft. --- BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) - Actress Audrey Hepburn, fresh from a U.N. projects tour in Vietnam, said Saturday that officials are working hard to ensure the children of that impoverished nation grow up healthy and well educated. ``People-wise, they are doing things right,'' the goodwill ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund said. Hepburn said she was once on the receiving end of such projects. As a teenager in Holland at the end of World War II, she said she learned firsthand about foraging for food and the difference international help can make. ``I was one of the thousands of kids who got packages of food and medicine to take home from the Red Cross, UNICEF, CARE - the three names I remember so vividly,'' she said. --- AUSTIN, Texas (AP) - Actor Lou Gossett Jr. says he grew up in an integrated New York City neighborhood where black families were as proud of their heritage as Italian, Irish and Jewish families. Now, he says black people need to continue celebrating their heritage. Gossett was the guest speaker Friday at Huston-Tillotson College's 38th annual charter day anniversary. The day commemorates the merging of Huston and Tillotson, two predominately black schools. ``It is vitally necessary to celebrate our heritage in the United States today,'' Gossett told students. He also urged the audience to help America's poor and homeless. Gossett grew up in New York's Brooklyn borough. --- TULSA, Okla. (AP) - Entertainer Wayne Newton's organization has signed a two-year contract to manage a $1.4 million Indian bingo hall that's been closed for six months. Wayne Newton Gaming Inc. has agreed to manage a bingo hall operated by the Seneca-Cayuga tribe in far northeastern Oklahoma, said Sandra Hoy, Newton's director of marketing. The hall will open Nov. 16, but a grand opening ceremony, at which Newton will appear, is scheduled for January, Hoy said. Newton already operates a bingo hall in Santa Ynez, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Laos Arrests Senior Government Officials For Anti-Communist Acts
DOC.TEXT: Police in Laos have arrested two former deputy Cabinet ministers and another government official for trying to overthrow the Communist government, its KPL news agency said Saturday. The report, monitored in Bangkok, quoted the Laotian Communist Party daily newspaper, Pasason, as saying the arrests were needed to protect national law and order. It identified those recently arrested as Thongsouk Saysangkhi, a former deputy minister of science and technology, Latsami Khamphtui, a deputy minister of agriculture and forestry, and an official of the Ministry of Justice. It was not clear from the report if the men were occupying their government posts at the time of their arrests. ``The three wrongdoers committed propaganda against the party and state policy, and conducted activities aimed at overthrowing the regime and causing political disturbances in Vientiane municipality,'' the national capital, it said. The report was incompletely monitored due to reception problems. Laos has been ruled by a rigid Communist autocracy since December 1975. Its Communist allies and neighbors, Cambodia and Vietnam, also have cracked down on dissent in recent months amid worries over the effects of the democratic revolution in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Good Samaritans Sued for Acts of Heroism
DOC.TEXT: Two people who rescued a pregnant woman from an overturned car moments before it exploded are being sued by another accident victim they didn't have time to help. Construction worker James Campbell and police Officer Dale Turner pulled Norma Macias from her car Jan. 30 just before it was hit by another car and burst in flames. Two hours later, Mrs. Macias delivered a 6-pound, 8-ounce girl at a hospital. Anzelma Sanchez-Sianez, 17, who was riding in the same car, is suing Campbell and Turner for negligence. Her lawyer, Paul Jay Bershin, filed suit Oct. 4. Turner was served with the legal papers Thursday as he was going to the Police Academy to be honored with a Medal of Valor. The suit names two other people: Gloria McNeal, whose car hit the overturned car, then allegedly careened into Sanchez-Sianez as she was sitting dazed against the center divider; and Mrs. Macias' husband, Ricardo, who was driving the car when it overturned on the San Diego Freeway. ``I still can't believe this is happening,'' Campbell said. ``I was trying to save lives.'' ``If Campbell had not stopped and been a good citizen, I have absolutely no doubt in my mind all those people would have perished,'' said Turner, a 20-year Police Department veteran. The suit claims Turner, who was en route to work when he saw the early morning accident, was negligent in ``failing to set up flares or warnings to oncoming motorists to indicate that an accident had occurred.'' The suit also claims Turner and Campbell ``permitted Sanchez-Sianez to remain in a position of peril on the freeway.'' It's unclear how Sanchez-Sianez, who spent a month in the hospital, got out of the car. According to Bershin, the family has ``a couple of hundred thousand dollars in medical bills.'' ``The girl's body looks like a road map,'' he said. According to Turner, he and Campbell had only about 60 to 80 seconds to react to the emergency. In the initial moments there was confusion caused by the pregnant woman screaming about her baby. ``The woman (Macias) was screaming for her baby,'' Turner said. ``I was desperately searching in the overturned car for a child, then I looked at her and realized she was in labor. She was having her baby. ``I saw a vehicle coming, flashing its high and low beams. I thought, `Good, the CHP (California Highway Patrol) is here to help.''' Until that moment the men thought the overturned car was on the left-hand breakdown lane. Then they realized it was in the traffic lane. ``I thought, `My God, we're in the fast lane,''' Turner said. ``We grabbed her (Macias') legs and carried her over the divider to safety. As we turned to lift the girl over, the (McNeal) car hit the overturned car and careened off, smashing into the divider and hitting the girl (Sanchez-Sianez). ``We moved as fast as we could in that minute,'' Turner said.

DOC.HEAD: Disputed Mosque Site Calm as Hindus Debate Next Step
With AM-Unholy War, Bjt
LaserPhoto AYO2
DOC.TEXT: Special trains carried people from riot-torn areas near a disputed mosque Saturday as fundamentalist Hindus debated whether to keep up efforts to seize the site. At least 305 deaths have been reported across India in unrest linked to attempts by Hindus to raze the 16th century mosque and build a Hindu temple in Ayodhya, about 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. At least 13 people died Saturday in areas around Ayodhya, including a police constable who had suffered head wounds during Hindu attempts to storm the mosque Friday. Police, meanwhile, arrested a newspaper editor and blocked distribution of 10 Hindi-language newspapers for allegedly misreporting the distrubances that have raged since Oct. 24. The editor of the weekly newspaper Swatantra Chetna was arrested on charges of inciting communal violence through exaggerated reporting, and officials in the city of Varanasi filed court cases against several dailies, the United News of India agency reported Saturday. All the newspapers are published in Uttar Pradesh state, the center of the religious conflict. The agency said 200 journalists who protested the police action in Varanasi were briefly arrested. Police with shoot-on-sight orders patrolled five northern Indian towns under curfew, but did not interfere with people heading toward the bus and train stations in Ayodhya. All rail service to the area was halted last week as part of the government's effort to keep temple activists from reaching Ayodhya. Three special trains were dispatched to the town Saturday. The sectarian violence has brought Prime Minister V.P. Singh's 11-month-old coalition government to the brink of collapse. Singh, who faces a confidence vote Wednesday, lost his majority in Parliament when a right-wing Hindu party withdrew support because of the Ayodhya dispute. In Ayodhya, Hindu leaders debated whether to continue attempts to take control of the 460-year-old mosque, which they claim was built on the foundation of an early temple marking the birthplace of the god Rama. Moslems dispute the history and say relinquishing the mosque would jeopardize hundreds of other Moslem sites. Leaders of the World Hindu Council, the group leading the temple-building project, are split over the best tactic to pursue next. Nritya Gopal Das, an Ayodhya priest and a local leader of the council, has been asking people to leave town, saying they had achieved victory Tuesday when they stormed the mosque and pried a few bricks from its walls and chipped concrete from the domed roof. But a national leader of the council, general secretary Ashok Singhal, has been urging people to stay until the temple is constructed. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems comprise 12 percent. In Bangladesh, authorities relaxed curfews in the capital of Dhaka and Chittagong for 10 hours Saturday after several days of anti-Hindu riots across the predominately Moslem nation. At least four people have died and more than 400 were injured in the violence that started Tuesday in Bangladesh.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge Bush to Lift Trade Embargo on Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Three Republican and five Democratic senators have urged President Bush to lift the U.S. trade embargo on Vietnam, saying it has outlived its usefulness and is penalizing American business in the face of foreign competitors, particularly from Japan and France. ``Trade with Vietnam would foster American interests across the board,'' according to a letter to the president signed by the eight lawmakers. The letter, drafted by Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and sent to Bush a week ago, argued: ``In recent months the United States has become increasingly isolated in its maintenance of the economic embargo against Vietnam. European and Asian businesses are now enjoying unilateral advantages. Some of the most promising construction and development contracts have already been committed.'' The letter noted that ``the government of Vietnam now estimates that $1.15 billion worth of foreign capital has been committed to investment projects in Vietnam. Once again, the United States risks forfeiting a market to our foreign competitors.'' Others signing the letter were Democrats Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Alan Cranston of California, Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, John F. Kerry of Massachusetts and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut; and Republicans Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon. The embargo was imposed on North Vietnam in 1964, and extended to the entire country after the Communists seized Saigon in 1975. Violators face penalties of up to $1 million and 10 years' imprisonment. The U.S. government's resolve on the issue was stiffened in 1978, when Vietnam invaded its neighbor Cambodia to overthrow the brutal Khmer Rouge government there. The Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist guerrilla factions supported by the United States have been fighting the government that Vietnam installed ever since. U.S.-Vietnam relations also have been snagged over the U.S. effort to recover the remains of soldiers killed in the Vietnam War and to account for 1,677 Americans still officially listed as missing in action. But Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach recently pledged heightened cooperation on that issue. The new policy allows for a permanent U.S. team to operate in Hanoi to coordinate the search effort. Moreover, Vietnam has withdrawn most of its forces from Cambodia, and administration officials have credited Hanoi with cooperating with a U.N.-sponsored plan to organize elections and end the civil war there. Citing those developments, business groups have argued for weeks that the political justifications for the embargo have largely vanished. In any case, they say, it is having no significant effect, because European and Asian companies are moving into Vietnam in growing numbers. ``It's another example of America seeking to further foreign policy interests by penalizing American companies and at the same time not achieving the foreign-policy goals,'' said William Archey, vice president for international affairs at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. But so far, such arguments have fallen on deaf ears in the Bush administration, although it is cautiously expanding contacts with Vietnam after 15 years of a nearly total freeze. An aide to Lugar, Andrew K. Semmel, said Saturday the White House had yet to respond to the Senate group's letter. ``And that's not surprising,'' he said. ``There are a lot of different opinions within the administration itself on this.'' In a July policy shift, the administration dropped its diplomatic support for the guerrilla coalition in Cambodia. But it has continued to grant noncombat assistance to the two non-Communist rebel groups loosely aligned with the Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for the deaths of at least a million Cambodians during its four years in power. Many Western countries still maintain sanctions against Vietnam. But most interpret them more liberally than does the United States, particularly in regard to oil. European oil companies have signed deals to develop offshore deposits discovered by an American firm, Mobil Oil Corp., in the early 1970s. Several Japanese trading companies have set up shop in Vietnam, as have French banks and textile makers from Singapore and Canada. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., eager for customers among the 700,000 Vietnamese-born residents of the United States, has twice sent teams to Vietnam and concluded long-distance phone-service deal with the government there. But the State Department has withheld approval. Other U.S. corporate delegations continue to visit Vietnam to prepare for the time the embargo is removed. Among the visitors this year were representatives of Mobil, the Chevron Corp. and Texaco, Inc. Other American firms are exploring mining, fishing, tourism and agricultural prospects. Even when - and if - the embargo is lifted, no one expects a bonanza. Exhausted by decades of war and mismanagement, Vietnam remains one of the world's poorest and most technically undeveloped nations. Its 67 million people also face the additional challenge of a phaseout of the Soviet aid that has helped keep the country afloat. But some analysts believe that if it stays with free-market reforms it has begun, Vietnam could emerge in the long run as a solid economic performer, as have many of its neighbors in Southeast Asia. It is sometimes compared to China 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: On The Road Again, But Not Everyone Wants Bush's Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS four grafs after 11th graf prvs `Even Bush's ...' to include comments from Bush political director. DELETES 12th graf prvs, `Instead, he'll...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Election Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, after raising a record $86 million for Republicans this year, was spending the final days before Tuesday's elections searching for candidates to help and themes to sound. Both seemed difficult to find. The president's final campaign extravaganza was sharply pared as he planned to devote his final energies to helping GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams in Texas, Bush's adopted home state. Bush tinkered through the final week with his basic stump speech - first bashing Democrats and accusing them of making him swallow tax increases, then dropping that approach to fire verbal salvos at Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Bush was to spend Saturday, Sunday and Monday nights at his legal voting residence - a hotel suite here - with a planned foray around the state Monday to drum up support for Williams in his close race with Democrat Ann Richards. The president will vote here Tuesday, then return to the White House to await election returns. ``Have plane, will travel'' was Bush's theme as he took the prestige of the presidency to 112 campaign events from the beginning of his term through Saturday, raising $85.6 million for GOP candidates in 35 states. ``We go to places where they ask us and where we can make a difference,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. But, finally, Bush ran out of places. And campaigning became unlike any he had encountered, with some candidates holding him at arm's length and others repudiating his stand on the budget and taxes from the very podium on which he stood. Stops planned for the past few days in Oregon, Illinois, Nebraska and Arizona were scrubbed. In each of those states, the governors' races were considered too close to call, as was the Senate race in Oregon, according to an Associated Press survey. Even Bush's revised plan to spend Sunday making video appearances at rallies around the nation was scrapped. David Carney, White House political director, said the major emphasis in the final days of the campaign was firing up Republican troops to get out the vote. Asked if Tuesday's election is a referendum on Bush, Carney said, ``absolutely not. It's a mid-term election. It's impossible to say it's a referendum on the president.'' ``Mid-term elections are decided district-by-district,'' Carney said. The White House said the President on Sunday planned to make phone calls from his Houston suite to rallies for congressional candidates in Alaska, Utah, Nebraska, and Maryland. ``At one time, there were 20 or 30 potential locations'' for Bush's final week, said Norman Cummings, political director of the Republican National Committee. Instead, Bush will have 11 events in six days. Cummings said the inability of local campaigns to shoulder the cost of a presidential visit so close to Election Day was a key factor in canceling many proposed appearances. Another problem is the new Air Force One, a Boeing 747 jumbo jet that turns out to be too heavy to land on many American airport runways. ``There are three values of a presidential stop: raising money, pumping up the trip and the attendant publicity and local TV coverage you get,'' Cummings said. But even a presidential visit doesn't ensure a GOP victory. ``The presidential popularity doesn't win or lose elections other than the presidency,'' Cummings said. ``We didn't have these races in the bag when he was at 80 percent and they aren't in the bag when he's at 60 percent.'' With his popularity plunging, Bush suddenly found himself more of a liability than a help to some candidates, particularly in states where taxes were a heated issue. Polls have shown Bush's approval rating dropping to as low as 55 percent in the aftermath of the budget debacle. At the same time, the two campaign veterans who had engineered his 1988 presidential victory - Secretary of States James A. Baker III and Lee Atwater, head of the Republican National Committee - were unavailable to give him much day-to-day guidance. Baker has been preoccupied with the Persian Gulf crisis and U.S.-Soviet relations; Atwater has been sidelined with an inoperable brain tumor. So, much of Bush's political advice in the past few weeks has come from chief of staff John Sununu, fresh from the budget and tax talks that have proved such difficult political terrain for the president.
