Sununu has had the final say - other than the president himself - on both the message of Bush's campaign speeches and his itinerary. The past week has seen a succession of new messages. In Oklahoma on Monday, Bush unleashed a blistering attack on Democrats, seeking to shift the blame for the budget debacle to them. Aides said it would be the theme he would carry through Election Day. But then, abruptly, he dropped it, toning down his attack on Democrats and turning it up on Saddam. Thursday, he was accusing Saddam of being worse than Hitler in some respects - a statement some Jewish leaders said went too far. By Friday, Hitler was out of the speeches. But the president was able to keep the focus on the Iraq confrontation - and away from the tax fiasco - day after day, through Friday's announcement that he would spend Thanksgiving with U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. Why did Bush stop his most strident bashing of Democrats on the budget? ``It's not a change of heart. It's a question of - I think I made my point,'' he said. But Bush told reporters in Orlando, Fla., on Friday to stay tuned: ``I think it's a little too early to say that there will be no more flamboyant rhetoric about the Democrats because I'm absolutely convinced if we had more Republicans, things would be a lot better.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Party Member to Become Envoy to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: An anti-apartheid lawmaker, Harry Schwarz, will take over early next year as South Africa's ambassador to the United States, the government announced Saturday. Schwarz is a member of Parliament from the opposition Democratic Party. He will succeed Piet Koornhoof, whose term expires in January. The Democratic Party is a small party that holds little power in the dominant white chamber of Parliament, which is controlled by the governing National Party. ``After a political career in which I have always been in opposition politics and opposed to apartheid, I find that what I have fought to achieve is now being realized,'' Schwarz said. ``The government has full confidence in Mr. and Mrs. Schwarz's ability to represent South Africa and all its people in a dignified and capable way,'' Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha said. Schwarz said he believed he could serve all South Africans in his new position. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. He is also seeking the lifting of international sanctions imposed on South Africa in protest of apartheid. De Klerk visited the United States last month, and President Bush praised his reform efforts. Schwarz is considered a financial expert for the Democratic Party and was part of a South African delegation at the International Monetary Fund conference in Washington in September.

DOC.HEAD: Party Congress Creates Left-Wing Federation
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party began its congress Saturday hoping to remake its image, but a bomb threat and a strike of conference hall workers marred the event. The staff of Prague's Palace of Culture, the traditional site of party caucuses, walked off the job to protest the congress. The 868 delegates opted to meet in another location Sunday, when the meeting is scheduled to end. An anonymous caller said a bomb had been planted at the congress site, interrupting the meeting for an hour. Police searched the hall but found nothing. In its first day, the congress decided to form a Federation Council to coordinate work of the Czech and the Slovak parties over the next two years, as well as any other political party wishing to join the federation in the future. There was also balloting for leadership roles within the Communist Party. Miroslav Grebenicek, 43, a newcomer to the party leadership, defeated former chairman Vasil Mohorita to become the Czech candidate for the party chairmanship, the official news agency CTK reported. The vote appeared to confirm the party's attempt to shed the image of Communist orthodoxy. Mohorita was close to the government of Milos Jakes before the country's peaceful revolution ousted Communists from power in November 1989. But later, Grebenicek openly endorsed rival Slovak candidate Pavol Kanis and the final vote for the party's top post - to take place Sunday - seemed a foregone conclusion. ``I think Mr. Kanis is much more qualified for the job than I, and I will be happy with remaining the number two for the time being,'' Grebenicek said at a news conference Saturday. According to new rules, the two leaders will alternate the chairmanship every two years. Jiri Svoboda, a well-known film director leads the Czech Communist party, while Peter Weiss, an established left-wing reformer, heads the Slovak party. Establishment of the Federation is also a strong signal to other Czechoslovak left-wing groupings to cooperate as genuine political pluralism develops. In spite of running second in the country's free elections in June, Communists were kept out of the current government coalition. Earlier this week, the Left Alternative, headed by veteran dissident Petr Uhl, and Obroda (Renewal), another left-wing group in Civic Forum - the country's leading political grouping - were expelled from the movement for ``not abiding by its political viewpoints,'' The move was seen as an attempt by Civic Forum's new chairman Vaclav Klaus to transform the loose democratic alliance into several clear-cut political parties after parlimaentary elections in 1992. ``Our program has a lot to do with some left-wing oriented groups in the Civic Forum,'' Kanis toold journalists Saturday. ``To think civic intiatives can replace political parties is premature,'' he said. The Communists gained 13.5 percent of the vote in the June elections. But their membership has been shrinking, reaching a record low of 450,000, analysts have said.

DOC.HEAD: Brando Murder Case on Verge of Trial as Sister Recovers From Overdose
DOC.TEXT: The privacy actor Marlon Brando attained at his hilltop mansion has dissolved in the five months since his pregnant daughter's lover was shot to death there. Brando's son, Christian, is about to go on trial for murder and the troubled life of his daughter, Cheyenne, has taken center stage as she recovers from a drug overdose in a Tahiti hospital. Miss Brando, 20, is the key witness to events which led to the death of 26-year-old Dag Drollet. But she fled to Tahiti a month after the killing, gave birth to a child and has refused to return to testify. Authorities in Tahiti also have barred her exit from the island, charging her as an accomplice in the murder. Marlon Brando flew to Tahiti Friday to be with his daughter. Christian Brando's trial was scheduled to start Monday, but the international legal tangle concerning Miss Brando's testimony has caused a delay. Prosecutors say they can't win the case without her testimony. The 2nd District Court of Appeal blocked the trial but could let jury selection begin Monday or seek more time to study the case. Christian Brando's lawyer, Robert Shapiro, said Cheyenne's drug overdose would further delay the trial. ``This has put a damper on everything,'' Shapiro said. ``The concern of everyone is for Cheyenne's health and recovery and the criminal case seems less important.'' Drollet was found sprawled on a sofa at the Brando home with a single bullet wound in his cheek on May 16. Police said he had a TV remote control in one hand and a cigarette lighter in the other hand. Brando's defense team disputes that report and has hired forensic experts to recreate the death scene. Christian Brando told police the killing was an accident. ``I shot him, man, but not on purpose,'' he said. At another point he was quoted as saying, ``I did it because he hurt my sister.'' Christian Brando also told police he did not like Drollet, saying ``death is too good for the guy.'' Before Miss Brando left the country, she told police, ``It's a murder, in case you don't know it.'' Prosecutors say Christian Brando decided to kill Drollet because he had been physically abusing his sister. He is charged him with premeditated first degree murder. They intend to introduce as evidence information about his past and his involvement with guns. But Shapiro said his client is guilty of no more than involuntary manslaughter. He suggests the gun accidentally went off when Christian and Drollet fought over it. Miss Brando's version of events has never been clear. She has given at least five depositions in the United States and Tahiti. In one deposition, she accused her father of complicity, saying Marlon Brando ``was fixated with the Godfather and that he was crazy on the subject.'' She later retracted that statement. Cheyenne's life has been a focus of attention from the start of the Brando affair. The young woman was said to be emotionally disturbed, drug addicted and still suffering the effects of a near fatal auto accident in 1989 which smashed her face. She was seven-months pregnant the day Marlon Brando dialed 911 to tell police there had been a shooting at his Mulholland Drive mansion. Marlon Brando is expected to testify at his son's trial. The attorneys' first chore will be to find jurors unaffected by the blitz of publicity that has surrounded the case. ``I think that will be impossible,'' Shapiro said. ``I can't imagine anyone in this community who hasn't heard about this case.'' ``This whole thing has got this star quality. It has an aura around it,'' Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop said. ``I think there will be a lot of people who want to sit on a jury like this because they think it's exciting.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Trip Will Lay Foundation for Military Action Against Saddam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Baker remarks on trip; no pickup. May stand
DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.TEXT: Launching a fast-paced trip to seven countries, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Saturday he would ``lay the foundation'' for military action against Iraq if economic measures failed to persuade Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. Baker planned to consult over eight days with leaders of a wide array of Arab and European nations, including a stop next Thursday in Moscow to see Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We would like to know under what conditions and subject to what restraints they would be willing to consider certain types of actions,'' Baker told reporters aboard his U.S. jetliner. ``The purpose of the trip,'' Baker said, ``is to discuss with our coalition partners strengthening the full range of measures that w have employed to isolate Saddam Hussein ... political measures, economic measures and military measures, and thereby to lay the foundation for the possible exercise of all options.'' Baker added: ``this will improve the prospects for peaceful resolution, and, at the same time, permit us to be prepared to consider all options if peaceful ones don't work.'' Baker also stressed the United States had the right of self-defense under the U.N. charter. President Bush has been pointing in that direction recently with angry denunciations of the Saddam, the Iraqi president, for taking more than 100 Americans hostage and blocking food and other supplies from reaching the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Bush said last week that in some ways Saddam has been more brutal than Nazi Germany's Adolph Hitler, who ordered mass exterminations during World War II. Baker's silver and blue plane, packed with senior White House, Pentagon and State Department officials, stopped here for refueling before flying on to Bahrain where Baker will hold talks Sunday with Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa and other leaders of the Persian Gulf mini-states. From there he moves on to Saudi Arabia, where more than 100,000 U.S. ground troops are defending the world's richest oil-fields. He will see Saudi leaders and also the ousted Emir of Kuwait, Jabir al-Sabah. Before returning home next Saturday, Baker will have consulted with Soviet, Chinese, British and French officials and others. Together with the United States, these nations are the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. Baker did not rule out an escalation of the economic and political pressures the United States and most of the rest of the world have put on Saddam since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But, like the president of late, Baker put increased stress on military action even while declining to say what specifically the administration has in mind. An escalation of bellicose rhetoric from Bush, Baker and John Sununu, the president's chief of staff, has heightened a sense of expectation that military force may be used to try to pry Kuwait away from Saddam. Bush said he had ``had it'' with Iraq's treatment of American hostages and diplomats. On Thursday he said, ``I don't think the status quo can go on forever.'' On the other hand, the president also told reporters in Orlando, Fla., that ``I'm not trying to sound the tocsin of war.'' And on Friday, he said his hope was that U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, now more than 210,000 strong, can return home ``without a shot fired in anger.'' Amid the buildup in tensions, the Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia, France and others have adopted a softer tone, with an emphasis on finding a channel to negotiate with Saddam. The Saudis also have indicated a willingness to strike a compromise. Baker said the Soviets were committed to full implementation of the 10 resolutions adopted by the Security Council against Iraq. Beyond that, Baker said he would reserve any comment until he saw Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow. He said he would report his findings to President Bush on his return. Asked if Saddam understood the possibility of an attack to loosen his grip on Kuwait, Baker said ``You are dealing with someone who is very difficult to predict, so I can't read his mind.'' And yet, Baker added, ``I think we have made it extraordinarily clear we are unwilling to rule out the use of force. I think most people believe that.'' Baker will stop in Cairo on Tuesday to meet with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, a staunch ally in the campaign against Iraq. While there he also will meet with Chinese Foreign Miniser Qichen Qian. Baker's other stops are Turkey, Britain and France. He is due to return to Washington next Saturday, take a breath, and get ready for another spate of overseas travel, attending a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris Nov. 19-21, visiting the troops in the gulf with Bush over Thanksgiving, and accompanying the president to South America in early December.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Requests 35 Percent Pay Cut for All Employees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, bgng: UPI's negotiations..., to CLARIFY that announced cut applies to those not covered by guild contract. SUBS 14th graf pvs, Dahl said, to include number of non-union employees covered by guild contract and to UPDATE with when results of vote will be known
DOC.TEXT: A Wire Service Guild official said Saturday the union will recommend members turn down a United Press International request that employees take a temporary 35 percent pay cut as a preliminary to sale of the financially struggling news service. Chris Dahl, secretary-treasurer of guild, said the UPI proposal for a 90-day pay cut would be submitted to union members for a vote, but ``we will recommend rejection.'' Dahl said ``things are so desperate at this point we don't think this (wage cut) will be enough either. The situation is very bleak unless UPI can come up with a buyer very fast.'' Dahl said UPI officials made the request for the 35 percent cut during eight hours of negotiations in Philadelphia on Friday attended by Dahl and guild president Kevin Keane. The meeting ended without resolving the wage issue. ``It's not a bitter situation at all,'' Dahl said in a telephone interview from New Haven, Conn. ``We'd love to see the company stay afloat, but I'd be lying if I said we were optimistic.'' UPI's negotiations with the guild coincided with UPI's announcement Friday that all management and employees not covered by the guild contract will have their wages cut by 35 percent over the next three months. The pay cuts take effect Sunday. The Washington-based news service also changed company policy so that non-union employees could be dismissed without advance notice or severance pay. UPI spokesman Milt Capps on Saturday declined to reveal details of negotiations between the news agency and the guild, but said ``We are asking support from both non-guild and guild members'' in the organization's latest economy moves. UPI Executive Vice President Pieter Vanbennekom, in a message to all members of the staff Friday, said ``All these drastic measures are necessary to bring UPI immediately to cash flow self-sufficiency and to stabilize the company during the next few months to be able to effect a sale of UPI in the shortest possible order.'' The news service has changed ownership three times in the past eight years and is now owned by Infotechnology Inc. Last week, Infotechnology announced a management shakeup and disclosed financial problems that could result in the sale of its businesses. The company also owns Financial News Network. In September, UPI announced that it was closing bureaus in five states and said Oct. 21 that it will dismiss an unspecified number of employees as it concentrates its reporting in 15 of the most populous states. Dahl said UPI did not propose additional layoffs. ``They are so hand-to-mouth at this point that layoffs aren't the answer.'' He said the guild will recommend rejection of the 35 percent wage cut because ``we're already down to bone as it is.'' He noted that the guild accepted a 25 percent reduction in salaries during a 1984 financial crisis. Dahl said UPI has about 250 union members. It has another 600 non-union employees, including about 100 who are covered by the guild contract. Ballots will be mailed to union members on Tuesday, and results of the vote should be made known around Nov. 16, Dahl said. Capps said UPI also may ask news organizations that buy its services to accept higher rates. Vanbennekom said in his staff memo that there have been at least six preliminary expressions of interest in buying UPI, some from ``blue-chip companies.'' ``To bring the process to a successful conclusion, we need the breathing space these measures will provide,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Movies Made by Will Rogers to be Released
DOC.TEXT: Will Rogers, who never met an outlet for his humor that he didn't like, including the movies, will begin playing to modern audiences come spring when four of his comedies are released on video. Officials from 20th Century Fox and CBS-Fox Video announced the release of the four video cassettes Friday during the Will Rogers Days celebration that commemorates the Oklahoma native's birth. Rogers, who died in 1935 in an Alaska plane crash, made 75 movies, 21 with sound. The four movies to be released are ``Ambassador Bill,'' ``A Connecticut Yankee,'' ``Mr. Skitch'' and ``Doubting Thomas.'' James Griffiths, senior vice president for 20th Century Fox, said they were among 2,000 classics the company has stored in its California movie library. ``To flood the market at any point in time wouldn't be good for the films,'' he said. ``But sometimes we need a kick in the butt to remind us what we have here.'' He got the kick from Rogers' son, Jimmy, who said he has regretted since ``Dad went to the happy hunting ground'' that his father's career as an actor is frequently forgotten. ``Nobody remembers him as an actor,'' Rogers said. ``You hear very little about his career in the movies. If you ask dad what his career was, I think he would have said he's an actor.'' Some of Rogers' movies now are shown at the Will Rogers Memorial in Claremore, and Jimmy Rogers said he can tell people still like them. ``You go in there when there's quite a group of people watching and I tell you, there's a lot of laughter,'' Rogers said. ``They're funny. They're great stuff.'' Mindy Pickard, a spokeswoman for CBS-Fox Video, said the movies being released were selected because they were timeless. She said ``Doubting Thomas'' is a ``classic battle of the sexes'' and ``Ambassador Bill'' is a political satire. ``They're all comedies. They all hold up,'' she said. ``We picked films that had relevancy to us today.'' Griffiths said he anticipated more movies would be released in the future. Rogers was famous for many aphorisms, including his oft-cited - and oft-misquoted - epitaph: ``I joked about every prominent man in my lifetime, but I never met one I didn't like.''

DOC.HEAD: Opponent Crashes Hatfield News Conference, Asks for Debate
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield's opponent crashed one of his news conferences and got in the last question by asking Hatfield to debate him Sunday. Hatfield, who has refused such requests from Democrat Harry Lonsdale, walked away without responding. ``I'm conducting a press conference, not a circus,'' Hatfield said later when asked what he thought about Lonsdale's visit Friday. When Lonsdale appeared, Hatfield stumbled over his words before regaining his composure. Lonsdale stood silently as Hatfield criticized Lonsdale again for supporting Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh in 1985 after the Indian guru pleaded guilty to federal crimes. Lonsdale's claim that he was merely defending religious freedom doesn't wash, Hatfield said. ``The issue isn't religious freedom, it's a question of judgment,'' he said. Lonsdale later criticized Hatfield for witnessing a shooting last year in Washington, D.C., and failing to report to police. ``As a citizen he had an obligation. As a senator he had no excuse,'' Lonsdale said. ``We all make mistakes and do things we regret. But Mark Hatfield should reflect on his own failings before he criticizes my judgment.'' At a separate news conference, Gary Kahn, Lonsdale's campaign counsel, called for a three-county task force to investigate a burglary at Lonsdale's home last week. ``What appears to be a politically motivated crime of this nature is unprecedented in the history of Oregon politics,'' Kahn said. ``For this reason, the Lonsdale campaign is today asking for a special task force to be set up.'' The Deschutes County sheriff's office said the investigation has failed to turn up any suspects. Kahn stressed he was not accusing the Hatfield campaign of committing the burglary. Julie McGregor, a spokeswoman for Hatfield, said the senator feels that ``it's unfortunate that such a crime should occur so close to an election, but it's equally unfortunate that Lonsdale is trying to lay blame on Hatfield supporters.'' He said files were ransacked during the burglary and a copying machine at Lonsdale's home was used extensively during the crime. Among the items taken in the burglary late Tuesday or early Wednesday were a computer and computer disks containing financial information on Lonsdale campaign contributors. Also taken were video and stereo equipment, a typewriter and a telephone. A kitchen door was forced open to gain entry to the home 12 miles west of Bend. A preliminary sheriff's investigative report on the burglary said clues found at the scene included foot prints, tire tracks, a cigarette butt and two threatening calls left on the Lonsdale answering machine before the crime.

DOC.HEAD: Quake-Proofing Design Study Set for Golden Gate Bridge
DOC.TEXT: The Golden Gate Bridge made it through the big 1989 earthquake without any apparent damage, but bridge directors think a $100 million quake-proofing project would be a wise investment. ``Quite frankly, that's a good bargain,'' said director Jim Harberson. He said replacing the 53-year-old Golden Gate would cost about $1 billion. A committee of bridge directors voted Friday to spend $550,000 for a design study on a project that would srengthen the bridge so it can withstand an earthquake with a Richter scale magnitude of 8 or greater. The retrofitting project would cost $75 million to $100 million, and financing remains ``the big question,'' Harberson said. The October 1989 earthquake registered 7.1 on the Richter scale and claimed 67 lives. It knocked out a section of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Leads Wellstone in Latest Poll
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz has increased his lead over challenger Paul Wellstone, according to a poll published Saturday. The Pioneer Press-WCCO poll indicated that 49 percent of 760 likely voters polled last week preferred Boschwitz, while 40 percent favored Wellstone. Eleven percent were undecided, and the margin of error was 4 percentage points. A Star Tribune-KSTP-TV Minnesota Poll published Oct. 24 showed a closer race. That poll found that 48 percent of those questioned chose Boschwitz compared with 45 percent for Wellstone. The margin of error was 4 percentage points. Boschwitz has felt the backlash of voter discontent in the wake of problems that plagued Republican gubernatorial hopeful Jon Grunseth. Grunseth withdrew from the race after allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls in 1981. Democrat Wellstone began the campaign as a little-known college professor and activist, but benefited from the Grunseth fallout. Wellstone has tried to exploit a nationwide anti-incumbent mood. Boschwitz has labeled Wellstone a big-spending liberal whose proposals would cost the taxpayers an additional $600 billion a year and derail federal budget-balancing efforts.
DOC.HEAD: Chiles Leading in Florida Race
DOC.TEXT: Two new polls indicate that Democrat Lawton Chiles is leading in his attempt to unseat Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. A Florida Opinion Poll released Saturday by The New York Times newspapers in Florida gave Chiles a 47-40 edge, with 13 percent undecided. The margin of error was 4 percentage points. And a survey released Friday by Florida NBC affiliates showed Chiles with a 44-38 lead over Martinez, with 18 percent undecided. The margin of error was 4 percentage points. Martinez's campaign manager, J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, said all other polls indicate the race is neck-and-neck.
DOC.HEAD: Oregon's Packwood Wants Out of Montana Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Bob Packwood of Oregon doesn't want to be a part of Democratic Sen. Max Baucus' re-election campaign. Packwood is being featured in Baucus commercials that defend his voting record against allegations from GOP challenger Allen Kolstad, the state's lieutenant governor. The ad is in response to one by Kolstad that alleged Baucus voted for a $50 million tax break for Phillips Petroleum in 1986. Packwood, former chairman of the Senate Taxation Committee, is quoted as saying Kolstad is wrong and that Baucus wasn't responsible for including the tax break in a bill. Elaine Franklin, Packwood's chief of staff, said she called Baucus' campaign manager after seeing the ad Friday ``and said it would be our preference that Sen. Packwood is not in this race.'' Paul Risley, Baucus campaign spokesman, said the ad would continue. And Kolstad spokesman Stuart Brown said Kolstad's original ad also would continue. Franklin said she didn't know Packwood's letter about Kolstad's allegations would be used in a TV commercial. However, she said Packwood didn't hesitate to provide the statement.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Gives Voinovich 13.5 Point Lead
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate George Voinovich has a 13-point lead over Democratic Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., according to a new poll. But both campaigns cast doubt on the Ohio Poll survey. ``I don't believe it. I know we're doing well, but I don't think we're doing 13 points,'' said Voinovich, who served as mayor of Cleveland for a decade. And Natalie Wymer, Celebrezze's deputy press secretary, called the poll ``just not believable.'' ``Our own internal polls for the same period of time show us dead even,'' she said. The Ohio Poll is jointly sponsored by the Dayton Daily News, The Cincinnati Post and University of Cincinnati. It was conducted by the university's Institute for Policy Research. Results showed Voinovich was supported by 52.3 percent of the likely voters surveyed, while Celebrezze drew the backing of 38.8 percent. Another 8.9 percent were undecided. The margin of error was 3.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Crumbling Warsaw Pact Divides Its Tanks, Conventional Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes, details. Weapons levels to be reached in 40 months, Hungarian minister denies firm timetable for dismantling Warsaw Pact. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BP4
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the crumbling Warsaw Pact agreed Saturday on a plan to divide up their tanks and other conventional weapons, paving the way for an East-West accord covering all of Europe. Hungarian Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky called it the ``first step toward a new system of security in Europe,'' replacing the Cold War confrontation that plagued Europe for more than four decades. The accord cleared what Western officials had said was the last major hurdle to an agreement limiting the number of tanks, armored vehicles, aircraft and artillery in Europe. It is to be signed in Paris this month. The 34 nations of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe are set to sign a major East-West conventional arms reduction agreement Nov. 19 in the French capital. ``It will be a new beginning to unite Europe,'' Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski of Poland said after the signing. The agreement came at a time when the future of the Soviet-led bloc - which also includes Czechoslovakia, Romania and Bulgaria - is in question as former loyal allies reorient themselves toward the West. East Germany, a former pact member, was absorbed into a united Germany. Hungary and Czechoslovakia want the alliance to end its military role by the middle of next year, and to remain only as a loose political grouping. ``As a military organization, I would not bet that it would last as long as the end of next year,'' Jeszenszky told reporters. Later, in a news conference, he cited a ``growing general agreement'' among members to end the Pact's military role. Skubiszewski told reporters, ``The Warsaw Pact will disappear because it will no longer correspond to the need of that part of Europe. It has lost its sense.'' However, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky said the agreement signed Saturday had nothing to do with the Warsaw Pact's future as a military alliance. ``The Warsaw Pact lives and fulfills a useful function,'' he said. In June, leaders of the Warsaw Pact countries meeting in Moscow decided to change it from a primarily military to political organization, he said. Kvitsinsky substituted at the last minute for Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. He said Shevardnadze could not come because of commitments in the Soviet Union. He denied that they were connected with ethnic violence in the republic of Moldavia, which borders Romania. Warsaw Pact experts agreed in Prague, Czechoslovakia, last weekend on how to divide among themselves the 20,000 tanks and other conventional weapons they may keep within the agreement between East and West. The Western NATO alliance will be allowed to keep similar levels of weapons, but will have to destroy far fewer than members of the Eastern alliance. Czechoslovak officials said after last week's meeting that the Soviets will keep 13,150 of the 20,000 tanks, 150 fewer than they had wanted. Most of the other Warsaw Pact countries will keep between 1,000 and 2,000 tanks. The levels must be reached in a period of 40 months after the agreement is signed in Paris. Hungarian officials aid one final issue to be settled dealt with how many tanks the Soviet Union must place in storage. Both East and West must store about 15 percent of their total number of tanks. The Soviets wanted assurances they would not have to store proportionally more than any other country. U.S. officials have said President Bush will attend the Paris summit meeting. His presence was contingent on a conventional weapons treaty being ready for signing. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will travel to Moscow this week for talks with Shevardnadze and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that will touch on some remaining issues to be worked out in the conventional weapons agreements. Kvitsinsky said that various minor issues remain to be resolved, but declined to specify them. The conventional forces treaty does not limit the number of soldiers each side may have in Europe. The Budapest meeting was held on the date on which officials had intended to hold a Warsaw Pact summit in the Hungarian capital. The summit was postponed at Soviet request. Kvitsinsky and Jeszenszky said the summit meeting would be held after the Paris summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, but would not say exactly when. Hungary has already served notice it will leave the military part of the Pact next year even if it is not dissolved by then. But Jeszenszky denied at the news conference that any such firm timetable had been set.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd at Funeral Shouts `One Settler, One Bullet'
LEADS thruout to UPDATE with quotes from funeral and Conservative Party march; ADDS background; MINOR EDITING; CHANGES byline.
DOC.TEXT: Shouts of ``one settler, one bullet!'' rang out Saturday as about 3,000 blacks attended the funeral of Zeph Mothopeng, leader of the militant Pan Africanist Congress. The black opposition group follows a more radical philosophy than the African National Congress and some other groups opposing the white-led government. The phrase ``one settler, one bullet,'' refers to killing whites. Mothopeng, a popular anti-apartheid activist who was jailed several times for his activities, died last month at age 77 after a lengthy illness. He split from the ANC three decades ago to help form and later lead the Pan Africanist Congress, which refuses to recognize the white-led government and opposes sharing power. Joe Slovo, leader of the South African Communist Party, and representatives of the Canadian, Swedish and British governments attended Saturday's ceremony. Youths in congress T-shirts escorted the coffin into the stadium as the crowd chanted. When Slovo, who is white, arrived, some in the crowd shouted, ``One Slovo, one bullet!'' At one point in the service, about 50 people began chasing a black man accused of being a police agent and beat him until Pan Africanist Congress officials intervened. The crowd blocked journalists from getting near the scene and ordered photographers not to take pictures. Speaking of Mothopeng, Bishop Stanley Mogoba, leader of South Africa's Methodist Church said, ``Although he was sickly, he was morally tough and had a clear vision on what was unfolding in the political arena, still intending to contribute to the liberation struggle.'' In recent years, the Pan Africanist Congress' struggle has been largely ineffective. It is overshadowed by the much larger and more moderate ANC, which is involved in talks with the government aimed at sharing power between blacks and whites. The Pan Africanist Congress opposed the talks. Some 35 miles to the north, about 2,000 right-wing Conservative Party supporters marched through Pretoria to demand that whites vote on President F.W. de Klerk's efforts to end apartheid. Conservative leader Andries Treurnicht chided de Klerk for talking to the ANC, saying he is ``the only Western leader negotiating himself and his party from power.'' The Conservative Party favors strict segregation and contends de Klerk has acted without the support of a majority of whites. No violence was reported. Earlier Saturday, two bombs exploded near dawn in the Orange Free State city of Bloemfontain, about 210 miles southwest of Johannesburg. Police said the two blasts about an hour apart damaged rail lines and halted commuter traffic, but caused no injuries. No group or individuals claimed responsibility. The ANC said its regional conference began Saturday in Bloemfontain, and a spokesman suggested that right-wing elements may have set the bombs to try to disrupt it. A police spokeswoman said a train full of police had been scheduled to travel on the damaged lines at about the time the explosions occurred. She said the police trip had been canceled previously. Extreme right-wing groups have been accused of other bombings of ANC and government targets.

DOC.HEAD: Flight Delayed in Misunderstanding Over Passenger's Note
DOC.TEXT: A note written by a disturbed passenger delayed a United Airlines flight for two hours while the jet was evacuated so FBI agents and bomb-sniffing dogs could search the plane, officials said. Thirty passengers were evacuated Friday from the Chicago-bound plane after the note was mistakenly interpreted as a bomb threat. ``It wasn't a threat,'' said Art Kollias, airport operations manager. ``If anything it was a misunderstanding.'' Kollias said an elderly immigrant with a history of mental illness wrote the note to express a concern for his personal safety to the flight crew. The note was written in broken English and included the word ``sabotage,'' so the crew thought it was a threat, he said. Authorities did not identify the man or release the full contents of the letter. The flight originated in Cedar Rapids. The other 28 passengers flew to Chicago after the plane was checked and no bombs were found. The passenger and his companion were questioned by the FBI and later released.

DOC.HEAD: Former West German Chancellor to Meet Saddam Hussein, Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt said he will tell Saddam Hussein during their meeting this week about how isolated the Iraqi leader has become in the world community. Brandt also planned to meet with some of the 400 German hostages held in Iraq and hoped to deliver messages to captive diplomatic delegations from their governments. The former chancellor said he will travel to Iraq on Monday at Hussein's invitation. He said he did not know exactly how long his visit would last, but he planned to stay a few days. ``I have reason to believe he still is not a great deal informed about the degree of his isolation,'' Brandt told reporters Friday, when he concluded a one-week U.S. speaking tour before returning to Germany. Brandt, who won the 1971 Nobel Peace Prize for helping improve East-West relations, said he will travel to Baghdad as a private citizen, not as a government representative. Brandt, who was chancellor from 1969 to 1974, remains prominent in German politics and is a leading figure in that country's Social Democratic Party. He heads Socialist International, a world organization of Western socialists and social Democrats. He would not say what he hoped to accomplish during talks. The volatile Gulf crisis began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``He said that he would explain to me how he looks at the Gulf situation and the Middle East as a whole,'' Brandt said. Brandt said that after the meeting he will report to the German government, U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar ``and anyone else who is interested in my trip.'' He said he hoped to meet with some of the 400 Germans among thousands of foreigners detained by Iraq since the U.S.-led military buildup in the region. The hostages include a former Brandt aide, Claus Sonksen, the ambassador to Kuwait and Bahrain. The governments of Norway and other countries have asked him to meet with their captive diplomats as well. Brandt said he did not plan to deliver any messages from Washington, but would not rule out meetings with U.S. diplomats before departing for Baghdad. The former chancellor said he would not be accompanied by former Italian Prime Minister Emilio Colombo or former Belgian Finance Minister Willy de Clercq, as had been discussed earlier.

DOC.HEAD: 36 Governorships Up For Election, All Of House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 9-13 to update with weekend campaigning; breaks story into two takes.
DOC.TEXT: Disgruntled voters pick a new Congress and 36 governors Tuesday in midterm elections shadowed by twin threats of recession at home and war in the Middle East. But for all the combustible ingredients - and unexpectedly close races involving Republican Sens. Jesse Helms, Mark Hatfield and Rudy Boschwitz - few incumbents seem likely to lose in 34 Senate races, 435 House contests and 36 statehouse races on the ballot. And only marginal changes seem likely in the size of Democratic majorities in Congress and among the nation's governors. The California governor's race is the biggest prize of the campaign season, pitting Republican Sen. Pete Wilson against former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein in a $35 million contest. The nation's most populous state is expected to gain as many as seven House seats after the 1990 census, and the new governor will share power with the Democratic-controlled legislature in deciding the make-up of the new congressional districts. Other closely watched gubernatorial campaigns are in Texas, where Republican Clayton Williams was in a close race with Democrat Ann Richards, and Florida, where late polls had former Sen. Lawton Chiles leading GOP Gov. Bob Martinez. Not on the ballot but scarcely ever on the sidelines this fall has been President Bush. He campaigned for more than 80 GOP candidates but triggered a period of Republican disillusionment when he flip-flopped on tax increases during budget negotiations with Congress and abandoned his 1988 pledge of no new taxes. There was no shortage of campaigning the final weekend before Election Day. Bush stumped in California for Wilson, whom he praised as an environmentalist and credited with a ``big part in our decision'' to impose a 10-year moratorium on off-shore oil drilling off the California Coast. Feinstein campaigned by train through the San Joaquin valley. In Oregon, Democrat Harry Lonsdale crashed Hatfield's news conference and issued one more call for a debate. Hatfield made no response, but later told reporters, ``I'm conducting a press conference, not a circus.'' Helms sought to strip his race to its essentials: ``The real question is do you want liberal Harvey Gantt or conservative Jesse Helms to cast your vote in the Senate and that's the question the people of North Carolina have to ask,'' he said. Gantt, a black man trying to unhorse one of the Senate's best-known conservatives, referred to the desegreation battles in the 1960s as he appealed for votes. He said he sees a need to build bridges of understanding because people are in danger of ``drifting back to overt racism.'' An estimated 19 House seats will migrate from states in the industrial Northeast and Midwest to the Sun Belt before the 1992 elections, elevating interest in this year's legislative races and raising the stakes in the gubernatorial battleground states. An estimated $1 million has been spent by two candidates for a state legislative seat in Pennsylvania, where Democrats hope to take control of the Senate and monopolize the state's reapportionment process. More than 6,100 legislative seats are up for election around the country. Voters in 43 states and the District of Columbia will decide 236 ballot questions, including ``Big Green,'' an environmentalist-backed measure in California. ``You could have the contradictory result of overwhelming public anger toward the people in government and a very high re-election percentage of incumbents,'' says Larry McCarthy, a GOP consultant active in campaigns from Florida to California. McCarthy says polling indicates that upwards of two-thirds of the voters believe the country is headed in the wrong direction, and others say the level of antipathy toward incumbents is extraordinarily high. Says Paul Tully, political director at the Democratic National Committee: ``When we've seen voters get more nervous, more anxious, they grab for stability'' and vote for the incumbent candidate. California aside, all eyes are on these races: -North Carolina's Senate seat, where Gantt is locked in a close race with Helms. Helms is running a late-campaign commercial showing a white worker with a job rejection letter, a reference to the civil rights bill that Helms opposed and Bush vetoed with a claim it would lead to hiring quotas. -The Texas governor's race, a $33 million battle between wealthy oilman Williams and Richards that's close in the pre-election polls. Williams disclosed Friday he had paid no income taxes for 1986 ``when our whole economy collapsed.'' -Minnesota's tumultuous gubernatorial campaign, where Republican Jon Grunseth dropped out of the race in late October over allegations that he had once gone swimming nude with teen-age girls, and had an affair during both of his marriages. After days of bickering, a state party dominated by conservatives turned to moderate Arne Carlson. The GOP still has realistic hopes of ousting unpopular Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Rudy Perpich.
DOC.TEXT: In the House, Democrats hope to pick up as many as 10 or 12 seats and pad their 259-176 majority. But with the exception of incumbents tinged by the savings and loan crisis, such as Republican Alfred McCandless in California, or personal scandal, such as Arlan Stangeland in Minnesota, relatively few incumbents seem to be in serious difficulty. The most competitive races are for the 18 Republican and 11 Democratic seats without incumbents. A small group of potential 1992 Democratic presidential candidates is on the ballot. Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and Sens. Sam Nunn of Georgia, Al Gore of Tennessee and Bill Bradley of New Jersey are all favored to run up landslide re-election victories. As always, the two sides harbor hopes of late-blooming upsets: Democrats claimed a surge in Kentucky, where Harvey Sloane is running against GOP Sen. Mitch McConnell. Republicans hoped to surprise Democratic Sen. John Kerry in Massachusetts. But after months of campaigning, hundreds of millions of dollars in expenditures and seemingly endless negative campaign commercials, there seems little likelihood of anti-incumbency fever sweeping the nation. Democrats quickly portrayed themselves as the party of ``tax fairness'' and Republicans as protectors of the rich during the October budget debate, and the party benefited in pre-election polling. But lately, Bush has helped shift the campaign focus away from the budget and softening economy and toward the Persian Gulf, where he has deployed more than 200,000 American troops as a bulwark against Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The result has been an apparent shift back to some GOP candidates. Abortion is playing a role at the end of a tight Florida gubernatorial race. Chiles stayed away from the issue until a debate last Monday night in which he said he would ``trust the women of Florida'' to make their own choice. Martinez is a foe of abortion. Polls in two states favor independent candidates over major party rivals for governor. Former GOP Sen. Lowell Weicker is seeking a political comeback in Connecticut and former GOP Gov. Wally Hickel in Alaska. Illinois, Ohio and Massachusetts are among 13 states where no incumbent is on the ballot. One incumbent whose defeat seems certain is Rhode Island Republican Gov. Edward DiPrete, lagging far behind in the polls in a third-time rematch with Democrat Bruce Sundlun. The fallout from the Minnesota governor's race has settled on veteran GOP Sen. Boschwitz, locked in a tight race with liberal Democrat Paul Wellstone. The other endangered Republican is Hatfield of Oregon, a veteran of 40 years of politics. Democrat Harry Lonsdale has depicted him as a Washington elitist out of touch with his state. Hatfield fought back with advertisements recalling Lonsdale's supportive comments in the mid-1980s of an Indian guru whose top aide was convicted of arson and poisoning. The lone Democratic incumbent in difficulty appears to be Sen. Daniel Akaka in Hawaii, appointed after the death of Spark Matsunaga earlier this year. Republicans hope Rep. Patricia Saiki can win the seat and offset any losses elsewhere. The Democrats hold a 55-45 edge in the Senate. GOP candidates are favored to retain all three open Senate seats on the ballot: Reps. Hank Brown in Colorado, Larry Craig in Idaho and Bob Smith in New Hampshire. GOP veteran Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who will be 88 when his new term starts, has no major party opposition. Democrat J. Bennett Johnston won election earlier this fall in Louisiana's unique open primary system. Democratic freshman Sen. Paul Simon is favored to win re-election in Illinois and Sen. Tom Harkin is favored less securely in Iowa. In House races of interest, three blacks are running competitive races as Republicans: Gary Franks in Connecticut, former Cincinnati Mayor Kenneth Blackwell in Ohio and Al Brown in Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Examiner Says Remains in Car Those of Gainesville Woman
DOC.TEXT: The ``Lady of the Lake'' mystery appears to be solved with the identification of skeletal remains inside a Ford sedan hauled from the bottom of Lake Lanier, officials said Saturday. Fulton County Medical Examiner Gerald Gowitt examined the remains and said the bones and a skull apparently belonged to Susie Roberts, who drove off in a car with a friend in 1958 and never returned. Gowitt declared that the bones were those of Mrs. Roberts using her approximate weight and height. A more positive identification was unlikely, he said. ``With the evidence we have, we're as certain as we can be,'' he said. The rusted car was found Thursday in the northeast Georgia lake by workers building a bridge. The light blue car was mangled by construction equipment that dug it up, but its tires were still inflated, authorities said. Workers washed mud out of the car when they came across the remains, said Hall County Sheriff Dick Mecum. The car had a 1958 license plate, corresponding with the woman's disappearance, Mecum said. A car carrying two women ran off the road into the lake in 1958. The body of a woman believed to have been one of the occupants was found about a year later, but the car and the other woman weren't recovered, Mecum said. ``We were pretty sure it was her,'' Hugh Roberts, 49, said Saturday. ``It's sad, but it's a relief to know.'' Roberts, one of Mrs. Roberts' sons, and his brother, James Roberts, 51, both of Gainesville, were teen-agers when their mother disappeared. She was 38. The car's license plate was registered to Mrs. Roberts, her older son said. His sister found evidence Friday in county archives that matched the license plate, he said. Investigators found a watch stopped at 11:30 - about the time the two women are believed to have been driving home from a dance in nearby Dawsonville. ``We believed she was in the lake, but then we heard she might be in Chicago, then in Florida,'' the younger Roberts said. ``We wondered if she survived but had amnesia and never knew where to go.'' Authorities now believe a woman's body found near the bridge about a year after the accident is that of Delia Mae Parker Young, Mrs. Roberts' companion in the car. The decomposed body was buried unidentified in the 1970s, said John Ward, whose family mortuary kept the remains about 20 years in the hope someone would identify her. Hugh Roberts said the family will hold a memorial service for his mother, but he said details had not been finalized.

DOC.HEAD: Differing Reports Say Rwandan Rebel Leader Injured or Dead
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda's army commander was quoted by Ugandan newspapers Saturday as saying the leader of an anti-government insurgency has been wounded, but rebel officials said he had been killed. A statement from the rebel Rwandan Patriotic Front said leader Fred Rwigyema died after stepping on a mine Oct. 2, the second day of the invasion. Rwanda on Thursday claimed to have defeated the rebels in heavy fighting in the nation's northeast. The Rwandan government said it had pushed the insurgents back into Uganda. However, Henry Rwigyemera, a local official near Uganda's southern border with Rwanda, said in an interview that no rebels had returned to Uganda since Rwanda claimed victory. He described such claims as lies and propaganda. Rebel representatives in Brussels said on condition of anonymity that the news of Rwigyema's death was kept secret for fear of lowering the morale of the guerrillas. But Ugandan newspapers reported Saturday that Rwigyema was seriously wounded during a helicopter attack on rebel forces and was taken to the United States. The newspapers, quoting Rwandan army commander Lt. Col. Deogratius Ndabimana, did not describe Rwigyema's injuries or say when or where he was injured. The reports in the Star and Munno newspapers also did not say who evacuated Rwigyema, a former Ugandan deputy army commander, or where he was taken in the United States. Officials at the U.S. Embassy in Kampala, Uganda, could not be reached for comment. In Washington, U.S. officials said they could not confirm whether Rwigyema was dead or alive. They also denied, on condition of anonymity, that Rwigyema had been brought to the United States for treatment. The insurgents said Rwigyema was killed in the northeastern region around Kagitumba near the Ugandan border. The rebels have a base camp in the area. The front also announced two other rebel leaders were killed by a land mine on Oct. 23. The statement did not say who was currently leading the insurgents. The rebels said they still controlled the Kagera National Park in the north, which makes up about 15 percent of Rwanda's territory, despite the government claims it has driven the insurgents out. The front said it was ready to talk with the government about the future of Rwanda, a former Belgian protectorate. But the rebels said they could still launch attacks. Last week, the Belgian government said it had negotiated a cease-fire between the government troops and the rebels, but the truce has yet to become effective. Belgium and France sent paratroopers to Rwanda to protect their nationals after the insurgency began. Belgium's last paratroopers returned Saturday. Rwigyema, who was 34, was a major general in Uganda's army before leading the invasion of Rwanda by several thousand refugees, mainly of Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe. The rebels accused Rwanda's government of corruption. They said they wanted to replace it with a democracy in which all ethnic parties could participate. They sprang from the hundreds of thousands of Tutsis, including Rwigyema, who fled Rwanda in the late 1950s and early 1960s. In those years, the majority Hutu gained control in a power struggle that left more than 10,000 Tutsi dead. An estimated 250,000 Rwandan refugees live in Uganda.

DOC.HEAD: President Signs Head Start Expansion
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday signed bills to expand the Head Start pre-school program and provide funds for childhood immunization. The Head Start legislation authorizes $20 billion over the next four years for Head Start - enough to serve all eligible poor children for the first time in the program's history. At current funding levels, the program serves only 20 percent of the eligible children. Head Start, widely acclaimed by educators and a focal point of Bush's campaign promise of a ``kinder, gentler'' nation, prepares disadvantaged 3-and 4-year-olds for elementary school. As a presidential candidate, Bush promised to fully fund the program for all eligible children. His administration, however, proposed lower spending levels than the bill that Congress passed and sent to him. The bill Bush signed Saturday authorizes $2.4 billion for Head Start in 1991, rising to $7.7 billion in 1994. That compares with an appropriation of $1.39 billion in 1990. The measure will also allow 30 percent of the 5-year-olds who are not in public kindergartens to attend Head Start programs. It further calls for $20 million for 1991 for a follow-through program to help elementary school children build on their Head Start experiences. In addition, the bill authorizes grants to states to help low-income families pay fuel bills. Total grants would be limited to $2.15 billion in 1991, $2.2 billion in 1992, and sums as necessary in 1993 and 1994. Bush also signed legislation authorizing $205 million in 1991 and sums as necessary in 1992-95 to help states purchase vaccines and run immunization programs for children. The government estimates that about half the nation's children receive immunizations through the grants. In addition, the bill authorizes $34 million in 1991 for federal vaccine research, development, testing and distribution.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Leads Military Operations Meeting
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein presided over a meeting of senior officials Saturday to discuss military operations in southern Iraq, the official Iraqi News Agency said. Attending were Izzat Ibrahim, vice president of the Revolutionary Command Council; Taha Yassin Ramadan, first deputy prime minister; Deputy Prime Minister Sadoun Hammadi; Information Minister Latif Jassim; and Hussein Kamal, minister of industry and acting oil minister, INA said, monitored in Nicosia. An unspecified number of army commanders also attended, the agency said. It gave no indication of what was discussed, reporting only that ``President Saddam Hussein today presided over a meeting to discuss part of our troops' theatre of operations in the south of Iraq,'' which includes Kuwait. Last week, Saddam told his military commanders at another meeting to be prepared for war at any time. A multinational force, composed largely of U.S. troops, assembled in Saudi Arabia after Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Top Officials Stress Need to Impove China's Image
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs to ADD report of meeting between Chinese leader and Taiwan party member
DOC.TEXT: China's top leaders have ordered an all-out public relations drive to improve the country's tarnished image abroad, official reports said Saturday. ``They discussed how to better present China to the rest of the world under the present situation,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said. It apparently was referring to lingering criticism of the Chinese army attack in June 1989 on student-led demonstrators for democratic reform. Although the industrialized democracies have begun softening sanctions against China, foreign tourism and investment remains down. Five of the six members of the Communist Party's powerful Standing Committee took up the image-building issue at a closed-door meeting at the Great Hall of the People with delegates from around the country. Party Secretary Jiang Zemin, Premier Li Peng and committee member Li Ruihuan made important speeches during the meeting, Xinhua said. The report did not provide details of their speeches. Xinhua said Standing Committee members Song Ping and Qiao Shi also met with delegates at the five-day meeting on overseas publicity. The report did not mention Yao Yilin, the other member of the party's top decision-making committee. ``The delegates agreed that, in view of the situation, more efforts should be made to better present China to the rest of the world in order to acquaint people more with the country and thereby increase their understanding,'' Xinhua said. ``They all agreed that foreigners and overseas Chinese are very different from people in China in lifestyle, way of thinking and expression, as they live in different societies. ... Therefore, they agreed, these characteristics need serious studies and should be dealt with differently. Domestic methods should not be simply copied.'' The delegates said Chinese from all walks of life must help project a favorable image to the rest of the world. ``The work of overseas publicity should be done not only by the press people, but also by those engaged in economics, foreign trade, science and technology, culture, education and tourism,'' Xinhua quoted the delegates as saying. ``In addition, leaders at all levels and in all departments concerned should attach great importance to this work and place it on their daily agenda.'' In a separate development, a Taiwan magazine reported that senior Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping extended a hand to Taiwan earlier this year by meeting with a member of the country's Nationalist Party. It would be the first time that a Chinese leader was reported to meet a member of the party since the Chinese Communist revolution in 1949. The monthly news magazine, Journalist, said Deng met in May with Teng Wen-yi, a former aide to Taiwan's Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and a former classmate of Deng. Chiang was defeated by the Communists, and he fled with Nationalist forces to Taiwan. The respected magazine ran a photograph of the two men shaking hands. It quoted Teng as saying that Deng told him in the meeting at Beijing's Great Hall of the People that he hoped China could reunify with Taiwan within three years.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls in Central United States; Indian Summer in the East
DOC.TEXT: It was beginning to look a lot like winter in the central United States, but summer-like weather prevailed east of the Mississippi on Saturday. Heavy snow fell in parts of Colorado, Nebraska, Kansas and South Dakota Friday and Saturday in the first wintery blast of the season. Southwestern Colorado got up to 15 inches of snow in some spots and at least five inches blanketed the Denver area. Numerous traffic accidents were reported, some causing minor injuries, officials said. ``We've had everything from accidents to accidents with injuries to cars in a ditch to jackknifed semis,'' said Barb Onken of the State Patrol in Marshal, Minn. Snowfalls in western Nebraska included about eight inches in Keith and Chase counties. At least six inches of snow fell in some parts of South Dakota and Kansas. Snow also fell in southwest Minnesota and northwest Iowa. Rainshowers extended from Wisconsin to the southern high plains. Thunderstorms over eastern New Mexico produced dime-size hail. Another cold front scattered rainshowers into the Pacific Northwest. Dry conditions prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunshine from California to Montana. Heavier precipitation amounts for the six-hour period ending at noon EST included eight-tenths of an inch at Quillayute, Wash. Two-thirds of an inch fell in Concordia, Kan., and more than half an inch at Salina, Kan., and Gage, Okla. Temperatures were in the 70s as far north as Michigan and New England and were as high as 80 degrees in the middle Mississippi Valley. Temperatures were in the 70s and lower 80s in the Southeast. Record high temperatures Saturday included 79 degrees in Newark, N.J.; 78 in New York City; 77 in Philadelphia, Pa., Concord, N.H., and Providence, R.I.; 75 in Boston and Williamsport, Pa.; and 72 in Portland, Maine. Temperatures from the Rockies to the Pacific Coast were in the 30s and 40s at midday. Temperatures in the California valleys and the southwestern deserts were in the 60s and 70s. Lows dipped below freezing in other parts of the West and from the Plains to Minnesota. Lows in the teens were reported in the Great Basin, the northern Rockies, North Dakota, Montana and Wyoming. The nation's morning low was 4 degrees below zero at Yellowstone Park, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Scars From Flood Still Evident Five Years Later
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `It even ...' to CORRECT spelling to Michael, sted Michaels.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Darwin and Phyllis Michael thought they were safe when 10 inches of rain fell in the mountains near their home five years ago. Their house was 27 feet above and 600 feet away from the South Branch River. But their home was demolished when the South Branch and several other rivers in eastern West Virginia overflowed their banks on Nov. 4, 1985. The record-breaking floods killed 47 people and caused $570 million in damage. The Michaels knew they were in trouble when the water began gushing into the second-floor bedroom of their home in Petersburg, 60 miles east of Parsons. They wound up riding their attic like a raft and spent the night clinging to the limbs of a walnut tree. At dawn the next day, they found themselves 200 yards from what used to be their home. There was nothing left. The bricks were gone. The cinderblock foundation was gone. The concrete slab the house sat on was gone. ``It even pulled the footers out of the ground,'' Darwin Michael said, still amazed at the force of the water. Five years haven't erased the memory of the flood for area residents. ``The flood is still very much on their minds. It's still a topic of discussion every day,'' said Ron Castle, a Parsons businessman whose television and appliance store was gutted. The flood came after nightfall with little warning. The water poured down the narrow valleys with brutal force, twisting railroad tracks into corkscrews and scouring farmland. Trees, automobiles, buildings and bridges were washed away. The debris battered homes and businesses to pieces. More than 3,500 homes and 180 businesses were destroyed and hundreds of thousands of farm animals were killed. Forty-three bridges were destroyed and 80 more were damaged. The area's economy is still hurting from the flood. Most business owners had no flood insurance and were forced to take out federal Small Business Administration disaster relief loans. Jane Barb, 57, owns a drug store and four rental properties in Parsons and estimates her debt at more than $200,000. ``The SBA owns me lock, stock and barrel,'' Barb said. ``I will never live to get out of debt. Everything I have is mortgaged to the hilt.'' She's among the success stories. Marywin McClain Smith, editor of the weekly newspaper The Parsons Advocate, says just 13 of 96 businesses in the Parsons area escaped damage in the flood. Since then, 18 businesses in town either failed to reopen after the flood or opened only to close again. Among the casualties were the only two downtown department stores. Her husband, George Smith, said at least two other businesses are in trouble because of the flood and disaster relief loans ``made more with the heart than with the head.'' The Michaels used their life savings and some volunteer help to build a replica of their house. But this time they built on a hill 700 feet above the river and a mile and a half away from it. The Michaels are still working on their house. ``People will be working for 10 years,'' said Tucker County Clerk Nina Buchanan. Buchanan said she was still working on her own home in Parsons. Work also continues on public buildings and other structures damaged by the flooding. Steve Simpson, state public assistance officer for the Office of Emergency Services, says the Federal Emergency Management Agency has provided $62 million to rebuild roads, bridges, water plants and sewer systems. About $16 million in work remains undone. While the rebuilding continues, many flood survivors also must cope with the fear that floods will come again. Many report being drawn to the riverside during heavy rains, as if standing there will hold the water in its banks. ``I do it myself,'' said Frank Brown, director of the Potomac Highlands Guild mental health center in Petersburg. ``I don't mind a hard rain. But by the second day, I start looking. People are very touchy about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Acknowledges Setback in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Black nationalist Nelson Mandela said Saturday that his visit to Japan represented a possible setback in an otherwise successful international tour to seek support for his movement. He also blamed white security forces for murders during black factional violence in South Africa, and he said his African National Congress might consider taking up arms again if the bloodshed continues. On his international trips, Mandela has asked foreign countries to help support the ANC, which he helps lead as deputy president. The ANC is the most powerful South African group opposing that country's white-led government. During his stop in Japan, however, government officials told him they would not give grants to political parties. Mandela made his comments during a press conference in Kuala Lumpur. He said he was happy with his visit to Malaysia. On Friday, he met with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and asked for financial support.' Mahathir said he could not make an immediate pledge because the matter would have to be discussed with the Treasury and other government agencies. However, Malaysian officials did offer expertise in housing as well as technical and training facilities. Referring to black factional violence in South Africa, Mandela said the murders were orchestrated by the white security forces to undermine the power of the ANC. About 760 people had been killed in fighting between two black movements since September. Mandela said certain sections of the security forces did not wish to see the ANC gain strength and succeed in negotiating a peaceful settlement. The ANC and other groups are negotiating with the South African government to give majority blacks a say in their country's political system. The black leader did not elaborate on his statement about the possibility of taking up arms again. He only said the situation would be watched closely. Mandela, who arrived in Malaysia on Thursday, leaves Sunday for Brunei on the last stop of this six-nation tour.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Talks Environment While Promising To Sign Clean Air Bill
Precede THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 6 grafs with new info and editing to update with New Mexico rally; pickup 2nd prv, ``At the same xxx; subs 14th graf, ``The president was xxx which was 9th graf in prv version beginning ``Bush headed xxx to update; NO FURTHER PUBLIC APPEARANCES PLANNED; MAY STAND FOR AMS
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared at a campaign rally Saturday that the United States will stand firm against Iraq until every hostage is returned home. ``The United States is united and we will prevail,'' he said. ``If the United States can't do it nobody can.'' Shouting at times to be heard over a group of about 20 anti-war protestors, the president referred to his plans to visit the Middle East over the Thanksgiving holidays. ``Barbara and I have a lot to be thankful for,'' he said, ``and we will be with those troops on Thanksgiving Day and I will give them the thanks of everybody here and all the American people.'' Bush's brief appearance in a chilly airport hanger in Albuquerque was on behalf of gubernatorial candidate Frank Bond and other New Mexico GOP candidates. His pre-election campaign day had started earlier in California where he pledged to sign a landmark bill that would usher in ``a new era for clean air.'' At the same time, Bush voiced opposition to a sweeping environmental measure, known as ``Big Green,'' on the California ballot that would curb use of pesticides and chemicals. ``When it comes to the environment ... in order to keep our environment green, we don't have to be Big Green,'' Bush said, noting that GOP Sen. Pete Wilson, in a tight race for governor of California, also opposes the measure. The controversial ballot proposition, supported widely by environmental organizations, would phase out cancer-causing pesticides, ban ozone-depleting chemicals and reduce gaseous emissions that contribute to global warming, among other provisions. The measure is opposed by water, timber, agricultural and manufacturing industries. Bush's Environmental Protection Agency chief, William Reilly, later said he did not have a public position on Big Green. He told reporters it has some laudable provisions, but he also cited its costs and said ``It is not sound scientifically.'' ``Obviously, its goals ... are laudable. It reflects a very high degree of concern ... a sense of urgency that people feel'' about the environment, Reilly said. ``If Big Green does pass, we will work with it to try to ensure that it is integrated with our national laws as effectively as possible,'' Reilly added. The president was flying on to Houston later Saturday night and was to spend Sunday and Monday and part of Tuesday, Election Day, in his adoptive home state of Texas before flying back to Washington. In remarks at a rally for Wilson on the California Lutheran University campus, Bush also said he was looking forward to visiting the troops in the Persian Gulf when he travels there over Thanksgiving. He used a tree-planting ceremony at the university to highlight the historic Clean Air Act of 1990, which he promised to sign. ``We are on the verge of a major domestic achievement for all Americans. And I can now say to Californians is that I will sign this landmark clean air legislation as soon as it gets to my desk within the next few days,'' Bush said. Bush called the legislation, which would stem acid rain, urban smog and toxic industrial pollution, ``the most significant air pollution legislation in the history of this country.'' ``We are on the verge of a new era for clean air,'' he said. Referring to the bill's requirement for a phase-in of vehicles that run on alternative fuels, Bush said ``In a short time since we issued the clean air challenge, we've seen a revolution in thinking about alternative fuels. The time is right, the people are ready, and industry is responding.'' The Clean Air Act represents the product of a year's worth of technical negotiations by administration and congressional representatives. It marks the first passage of major anti-pollution regulations in 13 years. Environmental groups have lauded the bill, despite the fact that the final version discarded tougher provisions, particularly in the area of auto emissions, that they had pushed. They expressed satisfaction with the bill overall after accusing the Bush administration of blocking some of the tougher provisions that had won strong support in the Senate. Wilson has developed a strong enough environmental record to win the endorsement of some environmental groups in his race against Democrat Dianne Feinstein. He has been a strong advocate of coastal protection, bucking both the Reagan and Bush administrations and also has backed protection of scenic rivers. Wilson opposes Big Green. Feinstein, who supports the initiative, had less of a clear record on the environment as a mayor of San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Runs Against Liberalism, Gantt Against Racism
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Sen. Jesse Helms on Saturday cast his fight against Democrat Harvey Gantt as a classic battle of right vs. left, while Gantt, who is black, harkened back to past civil rights victories as he appealed for votes. Helms, who has been running a little behind Gantt in the polls, told supporters in Asheville: ``The real question is do you want liberal Harvey Gantt or conservative Jesse Helms to cast your vote in the Senate and that's the question the people of North Carolina have to ask.'' He was joined by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, who told Helms' supporters, ``I am here today because I hate to see someone crucified by the liberal eastern media and the liberal North Carolina media.'' Gantt, bidding to become the nation's first black Democratic senator, told voters in Charlotte he wants to keep people from ``drifting back to overt racism.'' Gantt, who was the first black student at Clemson, said he learned early on ``we could change the face of the South.'' He recalled the desegregation battles of the 1960s, and said they presented a chance ``to bring about real positive change by standing together.'' He said Helms wants ``to scare people to death, to be divisive, to say things he knows are not true.'' ``I pledged that I would not insult your intelligence, but that I would appeal to your higher instincts,'' Gantt said. ``... All we can do is trust the people of this state ... and hope the state's insulted by this kind of campaign. It's in your hands.'' Helms, meanwhile, renewed his charges that Gantt has lied about the senator's record. ``Harvey Gantt won't tell the truth. The liberal press won't tell the truth, so what's a person like me to do? All I can do is count on you,'' he told his supporters. ``If he (Gantt) has told the truth one time in this campaign, I don't know it,'' Helms said. ``... He is so unfamiliar with the truth I wouldn't trust him with anything, certainly not a Senate seat.'' A poll released Friday showed Gantt favored by 47 percent of those surveyed and Helms supported by 41 percent. The survey had a 3.7 percentage point margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavian Republic Rejects Soviet Aid to Control Ethnic Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new quotes, parliament resolutions. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: Moldavia on Saturday rejected new Soviet help to battle a wave of ethnic unrest in this southern republic that left at least three separatists dead. It issued its own demand that the militants disband. In Moscow, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Moldavian republic and separatist representatives agreed to urge a ``moratorium on all earlier decisions'' that led to the conflict, the official news agency Tass said. It was not immediately clear if that would include the republic's June declaration of autonomy from Moscow. In an internal challenge to the republic's leaders, Russian and Ukrainian separatists were seen on television blocking roads Saturday night around Dubossary, Bendery, and Grigoropol in the eastern area along the Dniester River. Busloads of people sat idle, their path blocked by barricades made of tractors and construction equipment. A state of emergency was declared there Friday. Moldavian police and Interior Ministry forces set up checkpoints, apparently to control activists' movements, officials in Kishinev, about 700 miles southwest of Moscow, said Saturday. At least three separatists were killed Friday in the region where roughly 200,000 ethnic Russian and Ukrainians began blockading roads and demanding autonomy Friday. Another report put the death toll at six. Reports conflicted on how they were killed. Parliament created a commission Saturday to investigate the shootings in the area, which separatists declared the ``Dniester republic'' on Sept. 2. No reports of further violence emerged Saturday. Gorbachev, trying to carry out political and economic reforms, is beset by restive republics demanding greater autonomy or even independence. All but one of the 15 republics have declared some form of autonomy. More than 1,000 students marched Saturday in the Moldavian capital of Kishinev in support of the government and pledged to fight the Dniester activists and other Gagauz separatists in southern Moldavia. The Gagauz, a Turkish Christian minority numbering about 150,000, declared autonomy Aug. 18 and announced elections last week for their own government. Two-thirds of Moldavia's 4.3 million residents are ethnic Moldavians and share a language and culture with neighboring Romania. The others are mainly Russians, Ukrainians and Byelorussians. Both the Gagauz and Dniester separatists complain of discrimination by Moldavians. The republic voted this year to make Romanian its official language, an act the internal separatists cite as evidence of discrimination. In Kishinev on Saturday, Parliament passed a resolution asking all volunteer forces throughout the republic to disperse and return home. The lawmakers set up committees to verify compliance with the order. Volunteer brigades of Gagauz, Moldavians, and Russians and Ukrainians reportedly were armed with knives, sticks, metal rods and firebombs. The Moldavian parliament Saturday asked the Kremlin not to send any Interior Ministry troops to the Dniester region. Moldavian Prime Minister Mirca Druk earlier declined an Interior Ministry offer to dispatch troops to the eastern region, legislators said Saturday.
