Between 500 and 800 Soviet Interior Ministry troops are deployed in the Gagauz area, but none in the Dniester region. In Moscow, Gorbachev and other Kremlin leaders, including Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and legislature speaker Anatoly Lukyanov, met with Moldavian President Mirchu Snegur and representatives of the Gagauz and Dniester areas, Tass said. ``The participants ... agreed on the necessity to take immediate measures for restoration of law and order,'' it reported. They agreed to form a conciliation commission to try to resolve the Gagauz and Dniester conflicts ``Resolution of the conflict would consist of establishing a moratorium on all earlier decisions taken by the sides that led to the conflict, and immediately declaring the volunteer forces illegal,'' Tass said. It was unclear what decisions would be covered by any such moratorium. Ryzhkov later said in a television interview the Kremlin will follow developments in Moldavia closely and take more resolute steps if decisions taken there prove ineffective, Tass reported. Moldavia's interior minister, Gen. Ion Kostash, told parliament Saturday three people were killed and nine wounded, all Russians or Ukrainians, on Friday in Dubossary. Tass, quoting Soviet Interior Ministry officials in the Gagauz city of Komrat, said six people were killed and 30 injured. Kostash said he earlier had sent about 250 troops to Dubossary under orders from Druk after between 100 to 200 Russian and Ukrainian separatists seized three government buildings and barricaded the city's only bridge across the river. He said his troops fired tear gas and warning shots, then charged the crowd to disperse it. But nobody was killed on the bridge, Kostash said. Tass quoted Vyacheslav Sipchenko, a member of the Dubossary City Council, as saying Moldavian troops clubbed residents, and many of the victims suffered gunshot wounds. Kostash said the Russians and Ukrainians may have been shot while trying to seize weapons from a Soviet army depot in Dubossary.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Says Richards ``Hiding Under Rock'' in 1986
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams on Saturday defended his admission that he paid no income taxes for 1986 while his Democratic opponent continued to call upon him to release his tax records. Williams described 1986 as a lean year for many Texans, yet one in which his Democratic rival, state Treasurer Ann Richards, drew ``a fat government paycheck.'' Meanwhile, a poll published in Sunday's editions of the Houston Chronicle showed Richards gaining ground on Williams as the campaign nears its end. The poll showed Williams was favored by 44 percent of those surveyed, while 39 percent backed Richards. Thirteen percent were undecided and 3 percent backed other candidates. The Oct. 28-30 poll by the University of Houston's Center for Public Policy, surveyed 767 of 1,042 likely voters who had been interviewed for a Chronicle poll in September. The earlier poll showed Williams favored by 48 percent and Richards by 33 percent. Both surveys had a 4 percentage point margin of error. Richards, campaigning in Brownsville, said she could not predict who would win the election, but said her continued gains in the polls was an encouraging sign. ``I can't call this election, and I think it's going to be real, real close, but I think he's got real serious problems,'' Richards said. Williams, campaigning in Harlingon on Saturday, said Richards didn't understand the hard times many Texans suffered during 1986. ``I'm just bothered that somebody who was drawing a fat government paycheck, sitting in Austin in 1986, was hiding under that rock,'' he said. Williams, a millionaire whose business interests include oil and ranching, on Friday disclosed that he paid no taxes in 1986 ``when our whole economy collapsed.'' ``I didn't get a paycheck in 1986 because I was trying to keep my business afloat, trying to pay interest on bank loans and trying to survive,'' he said. Richards then renewed her call for Williams to release his income tax returns, and said, ``I paid my income tax in 1986. How about you?'' Her press secretary, Bill Cryer, said: ``In 1986, I can understand he was going through some hard times. But everybody in Texas was. And we all paid our taxes then.'' Reggie Bashur, a Williams spokesman, said Williams had complied with tax laws and ``I don't think the people of the state of Texas care'' to see his tax returns. Williams and Republican Sen. Phil Gramm criticized Richards for making an issue of Williams' tax returns. ``Ann Richards has discovered miraculously that 1986 was a bad year, that Clayton Williams and the oil business lost money in 1986,'' Gramm said. ``What rock has she been hiding under?'' Williams also reiterated his call for a constitutional amendment that would ban a state income tax unless voters supported the tax in a referendum. He said he would veto a state income tax, and criticized Richards for refusing to say whether she also would veto one.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Shakespeare Company Calls It Curtains for Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with closing performance, remarks by director, other. Picks up 10th graf `Its case ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Shakespeare Company, which had two smash hits with ``Les Miserables'' and ``Nicholas Nickleby,'' called its curtains in London on Saturday in a cost-cutting move highlighting tough times for the British arts. Following its sellout evening performance of the play ``Singer,'' the company closed its two London theaters at the Barbican Center until March 1991. It will continue its season in two theaters at Stratford-upon-Avon, Shakespeare's birthplace. ``With your help and God willing, we'll be back,'' the company's artistic director, Terry Hands, told the Barbican audience. It was the first time the state-subsidized company has taken such a step. The event was greeted with a mixture of sadness as well as applause for the company's determination. ``Let's lift a glass to, if you like, the future and our return,'' Hands told the audience before they went out to the lobby to join cast members for one last drink in London this year. The move is expected to save $2.53 million for the company, now $5.85 million in debt. The company is the largest of many theater organizations around Britain to be fighting for survival in today's cost-cutting, recessionary climate. On Monday, Vanessa Redgrave, Glenda Jackson and Dame Peggy Ashcroft were among the British stars to launch a nationwide campaign at London's Albery Theatre to spotlight the financial woes of the theater industry nationwide. The Shakespeare company receives annual subsidies of $11.8 million. It says it needs $19.3 million to be in the black. Hands consistently argued that the company's grant has kept pace neither with inflation, running at 10.9 percent, nor with the specific recommendations of an independent report saying the company was underfunded. Annual worldwide revenue from the musical ``Les Miserables,'' which opened at the Barbican in October 1984, brings the company nearly $2 million a year, but Hands points out that the show won't run forever. Amid widespread sadness at the company's closure in London - depriving the city of up to six plays - is some speculation that the company has, in part, been its own worst enemy. Its case ``is not helped by espousing the palpably second rate,'' David Lister wrote in The Independent of ``Moscow Gold,'' the company's new play about Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Howard Brenton and Tariq Ali's play, a satire with a cast of 33, opened Sept. 26 to bad reviews and has performed poorly at the box offices. ``Moscow Gold'' was one of three new company plays to receive blistering reviews in London this year. Only Peter Flannery's ``Singer,'' starring Antony Sher as a concentration camp survivor turned London slumlord, won acclaim from critics and audiences, playing to 99 percent capacity in the 1,162-seat main auditorium. ``The company needs to look hard at its new play policy,'' Benedict Nightingale wrote in The Times of London. He said defiantly uncommercial plays are not necessarily worthwhile, and urged the company to take time for ``unromantic self-examination.'' In 1988, Hands' staging of the musical ``Carrie'' was derisively received during its company tryout in Stratford-upon-Avon. It subsequently closed on Broadway afterfive performances, even though the company made $420,000 in a pre-arranged deal with producer Friedrich Kurz. Last year, critic John Peter in London's Sunday Times coined the name ``The Really Frightful Company,'' referring to the declining quality of Shakespearean verse-speaking. But when the company is on target, its productions equal the best to be found in the English-speaking theater. Last season was highlighted by major revivals of Shakespeare's ``Othello,'' directed by Trevor Nunn, and Henrik Ibsen's ``The Master Builder,'' starring John Wood.

DOC.HEAD: Police Briefly Detain 85 in Leftist Protest
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand leftist radicals marched through Berlin on Saturday, and police said they briefly detained 85 people after minor clashes with some of the demonstrators. Members of Berlin's large anarchist scene marched through the downtown section of what used to be East Berlin and rallied at the central square, Alexanderplatz. About 5,000 people took part in the march. It was held to protest what demonstrators said is rising racism and nationalism in the united Germany. There were minor scuffles with police and rock-throwing incidents during the rally. Police said they briefly held about 85 people. There were no reports of serious injuries. The radicals say they are committed to an anarchist state in Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Medicare Chief Orders Probe of Florida HMOs
DOC.TEXT: The overseer of the nation's Medicare program ordered an investigation of Florida health maintenance organizations with federal contracts to scrutinize marketing and patient practices. Richard Kusserow, inspector general for the Health and Human Services Department, will conduct the investigation, which was prompted by media reports of abuses and inquiries from two Florida congressman. Much of the attention will focus on Humana Gold Plus, by far the state's largest HMO for Medicare beneficiaries. The Gold Plus plan, which has about 200,000 clients, has been the subject of 5,440 complaints since June 1987, ranging from improper enrollments to failure to provide service. The Gold Plus plan was cited twice last year by the Health Care Financing Administration, Medicare's parent agency, for violating medicare regulations, including improperly denying claims, enrollment problems and excessive payment delays. Gail R. Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, said Friday she picked Kusserow to investigate. Medicare placed a moratorium on Humana's plans to expand into other parts of Florida pending the outcome of the investigation. Other complaints against Gold Plus involved bills the plan did not pay or decisions that left patients harassed by bill collectors. The government pays Humana a fixed fee monthly for each enrollee. Patients are to receive complete health care services and prescription drugs at little or no cost and aren't supposed to have to fill out insurance forms. Wilensky said she decided to launch the investigation after she was contacted by Florida Congressman E. Clay Shaw Jr. and Larry Smith and learning of media reports about patients complaints about Gold Plus. Shaw and Smith wanted to ensure HMOs were following federal regulations, she said. Humana spokesman Tom Noland dismissed the investigation as politically motivated. He said he couldn't respond to Medicare's concerns because the organization has not received anything in writing. ``If they ask us to do something, how can we do it if we don't know what it is?'' he said. The HMOs could lose their federal contracts to provide for Medicare patients if the investigation uncovers wrongdoing. Other punitive action could be brought by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: President's Approval Rating Drops to 52 Percent, Polls Says
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's approval rating plunged 24 percentage points since August to 52 percent, a poll released Saturday showed. Fifty-nine percent of those surveyed approved of Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf crisis, down significantly from 75 percent who approved in August, just after Iraq invaded Kuwait and troops began to roll into the region. The New York Times-CBS poll showed the president's overall approval rating at 52 percent, down from 60 percent during the second week of October and 76 percent in August. Only 41 percent said the United States should take stronger military action against Iraq, with 50 percent opposed to stronger military action. The popularity of Congress also declined. Only 23 percent of those polled approved of the way the lawmakers are handling their jobs, compared with 27 percent in October and 42 percent in January. The poll included a random sample of 1,445 adults interviewed by telephone Oct. 28-31. It has a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Four Americans, Three French Soldiers, Three Irish Freed From Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with Kangi background, RECAST, CORRECT second reference to Barner. Picks up 23rd graf `She said . ..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Four freed American hostages, three French soldiers and three Irishmen flew to freedom Saturday after Iraqi authorities released them from captivity. One of the freed Americans - among thousands of Westerners still trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait - had been held as a ``human shield'' at an Iraqi installation. The four did not speak to reporters, except to say they were tired. In Baghdad, the four were identified as: Dr. Abdul Kangi, 50, from Glencoe, Ill.; Raymond Gales, from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, whose hometown was not immediately available; and Michael Barner, 49, of Woodsworth, La.; and Randall Trinh, 49 of Hacienda Heights, Calif. Trinh had been held at an undisclosed strategic site in Iraq. The Baghdad government has held some Americans and other Westerners at such sites to deter any air attack by foreign forces. The commercial Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad carried 77 other evacuees, mostly Arabs. U.S. Embassy officials who met the flight in Amman said the Americans would return home Sunday. Arrangements were made for the French soldiers to leave for Paris on a scheduled Air France flight late Saturday. Airport sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Americans would fly to New York via Cyprus and London. The French soldiers, who were turned over to the French Embassy in Baghdad after Iraqi troops captured them Monday, walked into the arrival lounge followed by the four Americans. French diplomats hustled the three soldiers to a VIP lounge, while U.S. Embassy officials rushed the freed Americans into a glassed-in arrival lounge. The embassy said they were receiving counseling. A French Embassy spokeswoman expressed appreciation for Iraq's ``good gesture'' in freeing the three soldiers, but added that they were allowed to depart freely because all French citizens are now able ``to leave Baghdad at any time.'' More than 250 French citizens were released by the Iraqis last week, but thousands of other foreigners are still prevented from leaving. Three men who identified themselves as Irish joined the French soldiers in the transit lounge. They refused to disclose their names, but one, carrying an Irish passport in his hand, confirmed, ``Yes, we were hostages.'' Irish Embassy officials were not available for a comment. A U.S. Embassy official said the four Americans were released ``for humanitarian reasons.'' Iraq said Thursday they were being freed because they were ``sick and elderly,'' although three were listed as being 50 or under. U.S. Embassy sources in Baghdad said Trinh suffered an acute stomach ulcer. They said Barner suffered from a neurological disorder. If the other two were ill, their ailments were not disclosed. In Glencoe, Kangi's wife, Fatima, said she and her husband were Tanzanian-born Moslems who became American citizens about eight years ago. She said they went to Iraq with their two sons on a religious pilgrimage on July 30. She and the children were allowed to leave Iraq on Sept. 5, but her husband, director of radiation therapy at Chicago's Mercy Hospital, had to stay behind, she said. The four returning American men were accompanied by two members of an American group called the Fellowship for Reconciliation, who had been in Baghdad for more than two weeks seeking the release of Americans. They are Tarek Mohammed Al-Heneidy, a businessmann from Rockport, Mass., and a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Michael Kenny of Juneau, Alaska. Heneidy told reporters that Iraq's release of the hostages was a ``clear sign that a peaceful solution was very possible if world governments pushed for peace.'' Pat Humphries, Barner's sister, said she didn't know why her brother had been released. She said her mother had talked to him by telephone at least once a week during his captivity. ``Every time he called, he was treated very well. One day he called and he'd just got through eating roast and mashed potatoes and gravy. The food situation in Baghdad must not (have been) as bad in Baghdad as it was in Kuwait,'' she said in the interview in Alexandria, La. Prospects for freedom improved for some of the other captive foreigners on Saturday. Iraq's National Assembly voted 225-25 to allow the 700 Bulgarians remaining in Iraq and Kuwait to leave. Toose who voted against the request said that Bulgaria was not neutral but was allied with the multinational efforts to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. The assembly earlier approved a similar request by President Saddam Hussein to allow French citizens to go home. More than 250 French nationals left on Monday. Iraq's National Council speaker, Sadi Mehdi Saleh, told Irish and Italian parliamentarians that Baghdad would soon announce an offer to free all the captive foreigners in exchange for a guarantee that Iraq would not be attacked. Baghdad had made similar offers in the past. About 1 million foreigners fled Kuwait and Iraq after the invasion, but an estimated 2 million others remain in the two countries. They include about 1,000 Americans. At least two former leaders were launching efforts to win the release of their countries' citizens. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt was going to Iraq on Monday at the invitation of Saddam. Brandt won the 1971 Nobel Peace Prize for helping to improve East-West ties. Japan's former prime minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, arrived in Baghdad Saturday. Although his trip is private, it has the support of his government.

DOC.HEAD: Lee Harvey Oswald's Escort Gets Second Look at Murder Weapon
DOC.TEXT: The man who was Lee Harvey Oswald's police escort the day he was gunned down got a second look at the murder weapon 27 years later, this time in a courtroom. ``Looks a little diffeent when it's not pointed at you,'' said Jim Leavelle, 70. Leavelle is the man in the light suit and hat whose image was captured by cameras when Oswald was killed by Jack Ruby on Nov. 24, 1963. Friday, Leavelle was an interested observer who showed up for a probate trial to determine ownership of the .38-caliber Colt Cobra. Leavelle was a 43-year-old detective when he was assigned to provide an escort through the basement of the Dallas police station for Oswald, who days earlier was arrested for the assassination of President Kennedy. ``I saw (Ruby) when he came out of the crowd,'' Leavelle said. He said he was holding Oswald by the belt and tried to jerk him out of the line of fire as Ruby emerged from a crowd of reporters. But Ruby ``took two quick steps, and pow,'' Leavelle said. Ruby's brother, Earl Ruby, and Ruby's former attorney, Jules Mayer, are battling for control of the gun in court. The trial began last week. Ruby bought the Colt Cobra for $62.50 in a Dallas gun shop. Mayer said it is now worth more than $100,000. Ruby was convicted of murder in 1964 and sentenced to die in the electric chair, but the conviction was overturned two years later. Ruby died at age 55 before a new trial could be held.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique Lawmakers Approve End to One-party Rule
DOC.TEXT: The national parliament has approved a new constitution that ends 15 years of one-party rule, eliminates the death penalty and changes the country's name, Mozambique's news agency reported Saturday. The constitution takes effect at month's end. It meets key demands of the rebel Mozambique National Resistance, which has been fighting the government for 13 years. But the rebels released a statement Saturday rejecting the document, saying it reflects the ideology of the ruling FRELIMO party, rather than the Mozambique people, and leaves too much power with the president. The rebels proposed discussing revisions at peace talks expected to resume soon in Rome. Their war with the government has killed 600,000 people and left about half the country's 15 million people in need of donated food. In its report, the national news agency AIM said all 181 People's Assembly deputies present voted for the new constitution Friday, ending debate that began Oct. 5. The document changes the country's name to ``Republic of Mozambique,'' dropping the word ``People's.'' In addition, the parliament's name changes to ``Assembly of the Republic.'' FRELIMO's policy-making Central Committee had previously recommended the changes. Approval by the FRELIMO-dominated parliament had been expected. FRELIMO has been the sole legal political party in the southeast African nation since Mozambique gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The FRELIMO party was Marxist, but it has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. The new constitution removes all references to FRELIMO's ``leading role'' in the country. After the vote, President Joachim Chissano led the assembly in singing songs from FRELIMO's guerrilla war against Portuguese colonial rule, AIM reported. The new constitution permits formation of multiple political parties and calls for secret balloting in national elections, which would be on a majority vote system rather than a proportional representation system. A majority vote system means the top vote-getter wins, while a proportional system allocates parliamentary seats on the basis of the percentage of votes a party receives. In presidential elections, a candidate would have to gain at least half the votes to win. A runoff would be held if no candidate received 50 percent. The new constitution also prohibits political parties based on regional or ethnic ties, and requires all parties to re`ect violence. It guarantees press freedom, including the right to set up newspapers; workers' right to strike; an independent judiciary; and the ``right to life,'' which abolishes the death penalty. Chissano said July 31 he wanted a multiple party system in place for parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for next year. He previously had opposed a multiparty system, saying it would encourage tribalism and waste the country's scarce resources.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Opposition Demands that Former Communists Quit Power
DOC.TEXT: The major opposition alliance in economically devastated Bulgaria pledged at a mass rally Saturday that it will wrest power from the former Communist Party and form a government. ``We want the posts of premier and ministers in key ministries,'' said Petar Beron, leader of the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces. Tens of thousands of supporters cheered Beron and other speakers at the rally in front of the downtown Alexander Nevski Cathedral. The crowd yelled, ``Down with the BSP!'' - the initials of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, the renamed Communist Party. Bulgaria is undergoing its worst economic crisis. Staple foods and other basic commodities are rationed or unavailable. Inflation is rising, and a large segment of the population is living beneath subsistence level. ``We will not concede that those who have exploited us to this day can continue to do so,'' said Konstantin Trenchev, leader of the opposition trade union Podkrepa. Contrary to developments elsewhere in Eastern Europe, the former Communists won a majority of 211 of 400 parliamentary seats in Bulgaria's first free multiparty elections in June. The Union of Democratic Forces won 144. Saturday's rally was held to mark the anniversary of the first major demonstration against the hard-line Communist regime of longtime dictator Todor Zhivkov. A week later, Zhivkov was toppled. Beron described the November 1989 leadership changes as an ``attempt by a more far-sighted group in the Communist Party to avoid the fate of other Communist parties in Eastern Europe.'' Opposition lawmakers suggested on Saturday that the governing Socialist Party's majority in parliament could be ended with the help of Socialist advocates of political and economic reforms. Beron said the opposition now holds the presidency and has as its members the mayors of Sofia, Plovdiv and Varna - the three largest cities in this former Soviet satellite nation of about 9 million people. ``What remains now is the government,'' he declared. In parliamentary debates on Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov's government program this week, the opposition refused backing sought by the Socialists. ``The government belongs to the political force that enjoys the support of society,'' Beron told Parliament on Thursday. He referred to recent opinion polls which estimated the Socialists had 40 percent support, compared to 52.75 percent in the June elections. At the rally, speaker after speaker demanded punishment of ``the guilty ones for the national catastrophe.'' Stoyan Ganev, parliamentary floor leader of the Union of Democratic Forces, declared: ``We want to take over the country's government as soon as possible. The BSP's program is economically deficient, legally and politically unsubstantiated. It is cruel in the social sphere, and that's why we have no right to say `Yes.'''

DOC.HEAD: Eddie of ``Munsters'' TV Show Charged in Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Allan Lilley, known as Butch Patrick when he played Eddie in the 1960s television series ``The Munsters,'' was arrested on a charge of stealing $130 from a limousine driver, police said. Lilley, 37, of Austin, Texas, was arrested Friday, police said. Police provided few details but said Lilley was a passenger with another man in the limousine and no weapons were involved. ``Lilley contends that the driver was less than cordial and he kept getting them lost,'' said Nicholas Kerkeles, who defended Lilley at his arraignment. ``A fight began and Munster, er, Mr. Lilley, apparently took the wallet, claiming that the driver shouldn't have been paid in the first place.'' The actor, who played the werewolf-like son of Herman and Lily Munster on the show, and John Patrick Sullivan, 33, of Chicago were charged with robbery of the driver at a gasoline station in suburban Glen Ellyn. Lilley was released on $1,000 bail. He told DuPage County Judge Bonnie Wheaton he makes a living attending conventions and making personal appearances as his former television character. Now rerun in syndication, ``The Munsters'' ran from 1964 to 1966. Lilley's telephone number was not listed with directory assistance in Austin.

DOC.HEAD: California Governor's Race and Initiatives Dominate Western Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS editor's note to correct that reporter is Northwest regional writer sted Midwest. Also sent in advance Nov. 1 as b0519, a 3rd Ld-Writethru with updates, corrections and additions.
DOC.TEXT: The West's liveliest election scene is in California, where a high-stakes governor's race shares the ballot with propositions for sweeping environmental reforms. But contests elsewhere are anything but dull. California is just one of five Western states where the incumbent governor is stepping down to leave a wide-open race, and ballot initiatives in several states address abortion, nuclear energy, gambling and legalized marijuana-smoking. In California, the contest to succeed retiring Gov. George Deukmejian is a neck-and-neck race between Republican Pete Wilson, a two-term U.S. senator, and Democrat Dianne Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor. Wilson and Feinstein have raised a total of more than $38 million in the costliest governor's race in state history. Battling in TV and radio spots to reach the 13 million voters of the nation's most populous state, Wilson bills himself as a ``compassionate conservative'' while Feinstein calls herself ``the candidate of change.'' California's other big election issue is a proposition called ``Big Green,'' a far-ranging package of environmental reforms. It would ban offshore oil-drilling and cancer-causing pesticides, reduce air pollution, and create an elected post of state environmental czar. Another measure would restrict timber clear-cutting and purchase $742 million worth of old redwood forests. ``It will make California a far better, a far safer place,'' said Albert Meyerhoff, an environmentalist who helped write ``Big Green.'' The timber, agricultural and chemical industriesdisagree. Saying the measures would cripple the economy, they have countered with less drastic propositions of their own. Californians also will consider two propositions to limit the number of terms its state legislators can serve. Colorado, too, will vote on term limitations; that proposal would not only limit state legislators, the governor and other state officeholders to eight years in office, but also would impose a constitutionally questionable cap of 12 years for U.S. House and Senate members. In Oregon, an initially sleepy contest to replace retiring Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt has perked up. Recent polls showed late-starting Barbara Roberts, the state's Democratic secretary of state, gaining on Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer, a Republican. In Alaska, Democratic Gov. Steve Cowper is stepping down, leaving a competitive race between former Anchorage Mayor Tony Knowles, GOP state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski and former Gov. Walter Hickel, who is running as an independent candidate. Arizona's Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford also is retiring. Polls give former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard a lead over GOP real estate developer Fife Symington. In New Mexico, GOP Gov. Garrey Carruthers, prohibited by law from serving a second consecutive term, has opened up a race between former Democratic Gov. Bruce King and former state Rep. Frank Bond. Five Western governors are seeking re-election. All are Democrats, and all are expected to win. They are Govs. Roy Romer of Colorado, John Waihee of Hawaii, Cecil Andrus of Idaho, Mike Sullivan of Wyoming, and acting Nevada Gov. Bob Miller. U.S. senators expected to win re-election bids include Ted Stevens, R-Alaska; Pete Domenici, R-N.M.; Alan Simpson, R-Wyoming; and Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. Other Senate races: -Polls show Sen. Daniel Akaka, D-Hawaii, in a dead heat with GOP challenger Rep. Pat Saiki. -Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., is neck-and-neck with Democrat Harry Lonsdale, a relatively unknown businessman who erased Hatfield's early lead with an aggressive campaign funded mostly by his own money. -In Idaho, Republican Sen. James McClure is retiring, and conservative GOP Rep. Larry Craig is favored over former Democratic state Sen. Ron Twilegar. -In Colorado, GOP Rep. Hank Brown is favored over Democrat Josie Heath, a Boulder County commissioner, to succeed retiring Republican Sen. Bill Armstrong. Two House races merit special notice. In Oregon, GOP Rep. Denny Smith is faltering in a rematch with Democrat Mike Kopetski, who lost by just 707 votes two years ago. A recent poll put Kopetski ahead by 10 points. In Washington, first-term Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, a Democrat, is fending off Republican challenger Bob Williams. He accused the usually liberal Unsoeld of selling out to the conservative gun lobby by sponsoring a bill to legalize American-made assault weapons. Some Western ballot measures: -A Colorado initiative would allow small-stakes gambling in three towns: Cripple Creek, Central City and Black Hawk. -A Nevada proposition would leave questions of abortion to voters, not the Legislature, by requiring that changes to a current law protecting abortion rights be made only by a statewide vote. -Alaska's anti-drug activists are sponsoring an initiative to criminalize marijuana-smoking. If approved, it will likely be challenged. The Alaska Supreme Court has ruled that the state constitution's privacy clause protects Alaskans' right to smoke small amounts of pot at home. -Educators nationwide are watching Oregon's school-choice proposal, which would allow parents $2,500 in tax credits for teaching children at home or sending them to private rr parochial schools. Also on the Oregon ballot: two anti-abortion measures, a strict recycling measure, and a proposed shutdown of Oregon's only nuclear plant. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - David Foster is the AP's Northwest Regional Reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Humorist Minnie Pearl Honored For 50 Years On Grand Ole Opry
DOC.TEXT: Humorist Minnie Pearl celebrated her 50th anniversary Saturday night on the Grand Ole Opry, receiving a congratulatory telegram from the White House. The message from President Bush and first lady Barbara was read during a special 60-minute segment of the Opry. Some of country music's top stars gathered on stage for the tribute. ``We are pleased to join your many friends in honoring you,'' the Bushes told Miss Pearl, 78, in the note. ``God bless you. I love every one of you,'' Miss Pearl said. Wearing her trademark gingham dress and straw hat with its $1.98 price tag dangling, Pearl greeted the Opry crowd and the live cable television audience with her standard salutation, ``How-deee! I'm just so glad to be here!'' One of several taped tributes aired on the show came from entertainer Dolly Parton, who said ``I love you. I miss you.'' To which Pearl responded, ``I wear a hat so folks can tell us apart.'' Country stars Roy Acuff, Chet Atkins, Hank Snow and Grandpa Jones gathered on stage. The show was taped by cable television's The Nashville Network. Edward Gaylord, chairman of Opryland Inc., presented Miss Pearl with a statuette shaped like a microphone with her trademark hat perched on the side. ``Minnie Pearl is the reason we bought Opryland,'' Gaylord said, explaining that her spirit influenced his purchase of the entertainment park in 1983. Acuff, 87, who has performed with Pearl throughout her career, sang his famous song ``Wabash Cannonball'' at her request. ``This is a special night for all of us,'' Acuff said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged In Fatal Beating Of Egg-Throwing Teen-Ager
DOC.TEXT: A man was charged Saturday in the fatal beating of a teen-ager after an egg hit his car Halloween night. Dennis Moriconi Jr. faces a manslaughter charge in the slaying of Timothy Doucette, police said. Doucette, 18, a landscaper from Somerville, died Thursday, 24 hours after he was beaten while trying to protect a friend, police said. Doucette was with several other youths who threw eggs at each other and at passing cars Wednesday night. A driver jumped out of his Cadillac and chased the teen-agers when an egg hit the car. According to a witness, the driver said: ``Who threw that at my car? You punks think you're funny.'' The man grabbed one of the youths when Doucette intervened. ``Then this guy turned his anger on him (Doucette), punched him a number of times, pushed him into a metal pole,'' police Lt. Ken Coye said. The driver drove away after the beating. Moriconi, 19, of Medford was scheduled to be arraigned Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Arrests 59 as Extremist Recruiters
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 59 men for distributing literature recruiting for a Moslem extremist organization, a senior security officer said Saturday. Gen. Nabil Abada, security chief in Assiut, a stronghold of religious militancy in southern Egypt, said the men were arrested on Friday carrying leaflets encouraging young men to join the Islamic Gamaat, or Islamic Groups. It is an illegal, loosely knit organization composed mainly of groups that favor immediate application of Islamic law in Egypt. The government says the organization leans toward violence to achieve its ends.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Three Times Lucky, John Kennedy Jr. Passes NY Bar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CLARIFY effect of Connecticut exam.
DOC.TEXT: The third time was the charm for John F. Kennedy Jr., who passed the New York state bar exam after two highly-publicized failures, a newspaper reported Saturday. ``The Hunk Finally Does It!'' trumpeted the New York Post's front page. If Kennedy had taken strike three on this try, he would have been out as a prosecutor in the office of Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau. Morgenthau allows his assistants three shots at the test. Official word about the test will come from the state next week, the Post said. The newspaper quoted informed sources it did not identify. The son of slain President Kennedy also took the Connecticut bar exam and learned Friday he had passed it, but passing that test would not have allowed Kennedy to practice law in New York and save his job. Kennedy, 29, graduated from New York University Law School in 1989. He earns $30,000 a year as a prosecutor. Kennedy could not be reached for comment at the Manhattan district attorney's office. A spokeswoman at the office said the district attorney does not allow his assistants to speak to the press.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Woman Says Bible Forbids Paying Lawyer
DOC.TEXT: A woman was locked in jail because she says the Bible forbids her to pay her lawyer. Jackie Gordon got 30 days in jail and a $500 fine Tuesday after a judge found her in contempt of court. The Isabella, Mo., woman refused to pay a $4,692 judgment awarded June 1 to the lawyer who helped her win custody of her granddaughter. Ms. Gordon filed an appeal of the contempt citation Thursday with the Oklahoma Supreme Court. Lawyer Dana Lyons helped Ms. Gordon win custody of her 2{-year-old granddaughter. Ms. Gordon says a New Testament passage prevents her from employing an attorney. ``Luke 11:45 lays out exactly what Jesus thought of lawyers,'' she said, referring to a biblical narrative that says: ``And He said, `Woe to you also, lawyers! For you load men with burdens hard to bear, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.' '' Tony Jack Lyons, the lawyer representing Ms. Lyons, quotes scripture, too. ``In Romans 13 there are several verses which say that God wants you to submit to civil authority,'' he said. Records show the attorney's fee is based on 37 hours of service at a rate of $125 an hour.

DOC.HEAD: Horror Stories Overflow Keating Grand Jury Transcript
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The hefty ...' to ADD that grand jury transcripts were unsealed Friday.
DOC.TEXT: Grand jury testimony against Charles Keating Jr. brims with stories of pressure to sell junk bonds at Lincoln Savings branches, bank examiners bamboozled and elderly people left broke. Keating headed the Phoenix-based development company American Continental Corp., which owned Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. He is accused in civil suits of looting the thrift. A grand jury indicted him on criminal fraud charges involving the sale of American Continental junk bonds to Lincoln depositors. Prosecutors say more than 17,000 investors lost $250 million on the bonds. The case focuses on 20 who lost $1.1 million. Echoing earlier congressional testimony, an Office of Thrift Supervision examiner said Keating continued to have uninsured bonds sold at Lincoln branches even though he knew the magnitude of Lincoln's problems. ``If this institution is taken over, you guys will be faced with a $2 billion loss,'' the regulator, Alex Barabolak, quoted Keating as telling him in October 1988. Lincoln was seized six months later, a day after American Continental sought bankruptcy protection, rendering the junk bonds worthless. Douglas J. Lagerstrom, a bond salesman for American Continental, was one of many employees who described how pressure to sell junk bonds began at the top. He said the bond representatives were entertained by Keating and his wife at the developer's sumptuous resort. Lagerstrom said someone asked Keating if he could imagine any way to make the place more beautiful. ``I can put a bond office in front of it and sell bonds,'' Lagerstrom quoted Keating as saying. The hefty grand jury transcript unsealed Friday totals 4,600 pages, weighs 45 pounds and stands 2{ feet high. It includes testimony taken from 89 witnesses between April and September. Prosecutors got a 42-count indictment against Keating, American Continental President Judy J. Wischer, Lincoln chief executive Robin S. Symes and Lincoln President Ray C. Fidel. Keating, 66, and the others pleaded innocent. They remain free on bail. Fidel's former secretary, Kathi Richardson, testified that while federal bank examiners checked company records in an 11th-floor office at Lincoln's Irvine, Calif., headquarters in 1986, executives worked one floor below manufacturing documents to make Lincoln look healthy. ``I was told to keep the examiners as much as I could up on the 11th floor so they wouldn't notice the activity going on on the 10th floor,'' she told the grand jury. Richardson said she helped Wischer ``clean out'' documents from bond files to be examined by regulators in early 1986. The files lacked required underwriting summaries and when they arrived from Phoenix, secretaries typed underwriting papers for Wischer to insert, she testified. Richardson said the office joke was that no one could even move furniture without Keating's OK. She described Fidel and Keating as wary of leaving a paper trail. ``Mr. Keating doesn't like files,'' Richardson said she was told. Much of the testimony came from elderly investors who switched money from insured certificates of deposit at Lincoln to the uninsured, unsecured American Continental bonds. Their plight more than anything has caused Keating to become the central figure in the nation's thrift debacle and what one of his lawyers called ``the most vilified man since Richard Nixon.'' ``We trusted Lincoln,'' said 66-year-old John Brunner, who lost $76,000. ``It was like going into your doctor's office. We trusted them.''

DOC.HEAD: Agent Says Baseball Owners Agree to Pay Players $280 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `New look ...' to CORRECT explanation of new-look free agency.
DOC.TEXT: Big-league baseball owners agreed to pay players $280 million in compensation for conspiring not to hire free agents after the 1985, 1986 and 1987 seasons, a leading agent said Saturday. The head of management's Player Relations Committee and a union lawyer denied that a settlement had been reached. Richard Moss, former general counsel for the player's union who represents several dozen players, said the 26 clubs agreed to pay $280 million to settle three collusion cases covering the three offseasons. Moss said 16 players, including Jack Clark of the San Diego Padres, Jack Morris of the Detroit Tigers and Gary Gaetti of the Minnesota Twins, would be be granted new-look free agency as part of a settlement. New-look free agency means a player has the option of keeping his current contract or leaving his team. Chuck O'Connor, head of the Player Relations Committee, said discussions had intensified but a deal had not been reached. ``Until everything is agreed to, nothing is agreed to,'' O'Connor said. Union lawyer Stephen Fehr said ``it appears now that there is the possibility of a settlement'' but said ``it will probably be at least a month'' until it could be finalized. A $280 million payment would amount to $10,769,230 for each of the clubs, by far the largest payment ever made by teams to players in the history of sports. After six seasons in the majors, a player can become a free agent, entertain offers from other clubs and sign with the team of his choice. Two arbitrators have ruled that owners suppressed salaries by boycotting free agents after the 1985, 1986 and 1987 seasons. They have awarded preliminary damages of $113 million but have not yet ruled on a variety of damage claims. Teams once again started signing free agents after the 1988 season, but the players' union claims salaries are lower than they would have been without the boycott.

DOC.HEAD: Small Bag of Cocaine Found in Shuttle Processing Building
DOC.TEXT: NASA tried to determine Saturday who is responsible for a small bag of cocaine discovered in a hangar where space shuttlesare readied for launch, a space agency spokeswoman said. ``This is the first time cocaine has been found in a Kennedy Space Center facility and it is considered an isolated incident,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. She said the cocaine was found Friday under a desk in one of the maintenance areas in the Orbiter Processing Facility, where shuttle repairs are performed. ``It was a very small amount,'' Ms. Malone said. Officials had not determined who the cocaine belonged to and no arrests had been made, she said. The investigation is led by a team of security officers from NASA, Lockheed Space Operations Co. and EG&G Florida Inc. Lockheed holds the multibillion dollar Kennedy Space Center contract to prepare shuttles for launch and landing. EG&G provides security services for the space center.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Charges DOE With Wrongful Action At Savannah River Site
DOC.TEXT: Greenpeace accused the Department of Energy of bypassing environmental review requirements on a South Carolina plutonium processing plant. Greenpeace officials said the Energy Department failed to complete an environmental impact statement on the plant at the Savannah River site, where idled government nuclear operations are located. The environmental group said it believed the government wanted the new plant to replace the safety-troubled Rocky Flats plant in Colorado. ``Without any public discussion, without an analysis of the environmental impact, DOE is taking the first step toward moving Rocky Flats to Savannah River,'' said Stephen Schwartz, legislative coordinator for the Greenpeace Nuclear Free Future Campaign. The plant will undergo environmental reviews, but they will be done later than usual, said DOE spokesman Rick Ford said. Such reviews, required by law, typically are done before construction is begun. ``The thinking at the time was that this was an addition to an existing facility, so the full environmental impact statement process was not needed,'' Ford said. Officials had not decided whether a full environmental report is needed, Ford said. If a full report is not done, the plant could begin operation in June 1991, he said. The Savannah River site, near the Georgia border, produced tritium gas for nuclear weapons before its reactors were idled in 1988 for DOE-ordered safety upgrades. The new plant had been under construction for seven years. Plutonium scrap would be dissolved into weapons-grade plutonium and the purified scrap made into metal buttons to store for future use. ``This gives us the capability to handle scrap that has accumulated over the years that we haven't previously been able to handle,'' Ford said. TheEnergy Department has acknowledged it is considering closing Rocky Flats and transfering some of its operations to Savannah River. But the new plant couldn't replace Rocky Flats because it couldn't handle the same volume.

President Bush will be sharing Thanksgiving with troops he has sent to the Persian Gulf and meeting with his chief allies in the region. The White House announced the visit on Friday as Bush continued a cross-country campaign trip in which he has blended Persian Gulf rhetoric with partisan politics. He arrived in Southern California early today and planned to address GOP rallies here and in New Mexico before flying to Houston later tonight.
